title: 'How Lucky Is This Community' - Connect Talbot Project Celebrated For Its Success
author: Natalie Jones; Njones@Chespub.Com
content:
'How Lucky Is This Community' - Connect Talbot Project Celebrated For Its Success

 September 21, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; Njones@Chespub.Com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 856
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CORDOVA - More than 60 representatives from the U.S. Department of Agriculture took a field trip to the Eastern Shore Wednesday to celebrate the continued progress of Easton Utilities' Connect Talbot project.Headed by Easton Utilities, the Connect Talbot project is extending broadband to unserved portions of Talbot County. The USDA provided significant initial support for the rural connectivity initiative in July 2020 when the agency awarded Easton Utilities $13.1 million in grant funding for the project.Wednesday's activities kicked off at Triple Creek Winery in Cordova, where USDA representatives took in technical demonstrations and checked out stations designed to show broadband deployment.Guests enjoyed a hands-on experience with field crews showcasing their work, including all components from initial construction techniques, plowing, drilling, aerial lashing and the installation process connecting service to the side of the home.Demonstrations were followed by a customer panel sharing the positive impacts of broadband service made possible by the Connect Talbot and lunch on the winery grounds.In the afternoon, federal, state and local officials gathered to praise Connect Talbot's progress so far.Laurel Leverrier, the assistant administrator of the USDA's rural utility service telecommunications program, expressed gratitude for the opportunity to see the work being done on the ground in Talbot County - the first trip of its kind for her."It's very clear being here and meeting with you all and hearing from folks that you're serving of what a community focus your organization has," she said of Easton Utilities. "I think part of it is the type of entity you are - you're municipally owned and operated I think it's really unique, and I think, 'How lucky is this community to get to benefit from the services you provide.'" Sen. Johnny Mautz, R-37, emphasized the significance of prioritizing broadband accessibility for children in Talbot County."To put the power of the internet in the hands of our children is just phenomenal.And the investment that's been made; when we first talked about this, it would never pay for itself, you can't get the revenue or return out of the investment and what you're putting in - that's very true, that's not going to happen right away," he said. "But I will guarantee you over the years, we will see benefits beyond anyone's imagination for what you've been able to do for our area."Mautz thanked the USDA for providing supplemental funding for the project, the cost of which has now risen significantly.Talbot County Council Vice President Pete Lesher acknowledged that prior to the project's kickoff, the county's 37,000 residents were divided between "digital haves and digital have nots." But with the USDA funding and efforts from local government and Easton Utilities, rural addresses across the county are being connected."This is our proudest moment," he said. "This is delivering on the American promise of a land of equal opportunity. This is transforming the lives in our community.This is creating prosperity in our corner of rural America."Also expressing gratitude was Easton Mayor Megan Cook, who emphasized the importance of the infrastructure in providing rural residents with connectivity and accessibility to enjoy the benefits of education, social interaction, health care, remote work, entertainment and more."Connectivity, interconnectedness, support, community - these are all pieces of the same puzzle, and they all become more important with each passing day," she said. "It's our ability to look out for each other, and help where and when we can, to reap what we sow - that is truly essential."Easton Velocity has made significant progress installing and providing broadband service to significant portions of Talbot County.As of early September, Easton Velocity has completed more than 50% of the mileage construction mileage and offered access to more than 1,750 locations.According to Easton Utilities, 920 of these locations have already subscribed to service and are enjoying the benefits internet service offers.Since the initial grant funding in 2020, various grant funding sources now total over $30 million. The project will now provide access to 4,400 locations and is estimated to cost $40 million.The scope and timeline of the project are reflected on a real-time interactive map.The project is on track for completion in advance of the grant requirement deadline of Dec. 31, 2026, according to Ted L. Book, vice president of Easton Velocity.Hugh Grunden, Easton Utilities' president and CEO, closed out the celebration with appreciation for the wider community effort to bring broadband to the county's rural areas."It's about partnerships - we could not have done this alone, the county couldn't have done it alone," he said."So when you partner with the likes of the USDA, the state of Maryland, Talbot County, the Town of Easton, Easton Utilities, whether it be for the engineering, the funding or the execution, that's how it works."

title: Local health care 'excellent'
author: Staff Writer
content:
Local health care 'excellent'

 August 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 356
 Words 

 Read News Document

 We've all heard negative comments about our local health care facilities. I'm writing to relay my recent firsthand experience with our local health care system.On Aug. 17, I experienced symptoms of a stroke and called 911. The ambulance arrived within minutes, and the EMT assessed my symptoms as a suspected stroke. They asked me if I had a preference of where they took me, and I asked their recommendation. Based on the severity of my symptoms they suggested University of Maryland Medical System Chester River Hospital. The EMT remained vigilant through the entire trip.
Dr. Lukas met us in the vestibule at Chester River Hospital to evaluate my condition and determine whether I should stay or go to another facility for more intense care. It was recommended I remain at Chester River for continued evaluation. Nurse Agnes provided constant monitoring. Dr. Lukas checked back every few minutes to make sure I was stable. The staff welcomed my husband and daughters who remained at my bedside.
Dr. Lukas said I would be transferred to a more acute-care facility and asked for my preference. They found me a bed in Easton hospital.
Best Care Ambulance transported me to Easton promptly the next morning. The EMT who rode with me had extensive military and over 25 years professional EMT experience. Our driver was a retired Black Hawk helicopter pilot. I knew I was in great hands.
The nurses, doctors and staff at Easton Hospital were exceptional, highly skilled professionals with a pleasant, caring attitude.
I was not a likely candidate for a stroke. I exercise regularly, eat right and have no pre-existing health conditions. Easton hospitalist Dr. Devkota and neurologist Valentin knew this and ordered extensive tests to find the cause of my stroke. They found I have a rare genetic blood disorder that causes blood clots, hence the stroke.
To all the naysayers and critics I say, acute care doesn't get better than the experience I just had. I often get asked by real estate buyers, "How is your local health care"? Now I have firsthand experience to tell them; it's excellent.
Thanks to all who helped with my care and recovery.
CINDY GENTHER
Rock Hall

title: St. Michaels Tourism Advisory Board holds first meeting
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
St. Michaels Tourism Advisory Board holds first meeting

 January 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 538
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — After months of controversy surrounding its creation, the St. Michaels Tourism Advisory Board held its first meeting at the Boy Scout Cabin in St. Michaels Thursday morning.During this meeting, members of the board, the St. Michaels Business Association and residents of the town came together to discuss the future and current condition of the tourism industry.
The board discussed potential budgets, marketing and branding strategies including combining various websites, and getting a better understanding of the tourists who are visiting and the tourists the board would like to bring to St. Michaels.
Timothy Law, the representative of retail businesses on the board, said as a business owner he is really excited for the work the board will produce.
"I love St. Michaels, and today was a huge stride forward to really understanding tourism and promoting our spectacular destination. I think it's a great group of people and we've got a great diversity of thought and diversity of background. It was just a very positive first step."
The idea of a tourism board was brought forth during a commissioners candidate forum hosted by the St. Michaels Business Association last April, when representatives of the Business Associations stated a need for marketing assistance due to a decrease in revenues within the last year.
The purpose of the board, according to a town memo, would be to assist the town in its efforts to encourage businesses to locate or remain in the town and to make recommendations to the commissioners. The board would also "work closely with the Talbot County Tourism Board on a unified, regional marketing approach."
The board has seven members serving four-year terms, all appointed by the commissioners. Membership includes residents not associated with a business and representatives from the lodging, eating/drinking, retail or service, marinas, museums and nonprofit sectors.
The members of the board were elected by the Commissioners of St. Michaels and include:
Brian Ball, managing director for the Wildset Hotel, to represent lodging.
Chris Agharabi, chief executive officer of Ava's Hospitality Group, to represent restaurants.
Katie Blaha, advancement manager of the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum, to represent nonprofits/museums.
Michael Morgan, owner and president of St. Michaels Marina LLC, to represent marinas.
Timothy Law, owner of American Holiday Shop, to represent retail.
Craig Bertolett, chief operating officer of COLUMBIA Technologies, and Michael McMillan, associate clinical professor of accounting at the University of Maryland, as two representatives for the residents of St. Michaels.
Included in the board is St. Michaels Commissioner Katrina Whittington as acting representative for the commission.
On Thursday, the board discussed the importance of a unified marketing message and the potential benefits of public Wi-Fi for data collection. Board members emphasized the need for a clear target audience and suggested a short-term plan to focus on digital marketing.
Ball said it's important for people to understand how tourism effects all aspects of the town's economy.
"St. Michaels is very much a tourism-based economy and it really affects everything we do from local government to all the businesses and all the restaurants and hotels," Ball said. "I think that this (board) is a very valuable economic tool to use to help the town grow."
Plans were made for the next meeting to include presentations on budget allocation and marketing strategies. The next meeting will be held on Jan. 30.

title: China has ailments made incurable by Leninism
author: George Will
content:
China has ailments made incurable by Leninism

 September 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: George Will | Page: A7 | Section: Opinions 
 
 733
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON - Vladimir Lenin, who died 100 years ago as of next Jan. 21, was having a good 21st century because the Chinese Communist Party emulated him. For four decades, the CCP's primacy was compatible with China's economic advance. Now, however, China has ailments partially caused by, and made incurable by, Leninism.In Russia, then in Mussolini's Italy, Hitler's Germany and elsewhere, including modern China, Leninism provided a new model of government: the party-state. Except China cannot be both modern and Leninist.Modernity requires social openness, and a nimble response to information and innovations that move faster than bureaucracies can or want to move.Karl Marx's only relevance to the CCP is in Lenin's reaction against Marx. The party-state was Lenin's obstinate rejoinder to Marx, who believed that Russia, a peasant society, lacked the material preconditions - principally, an industrial proletariat - for a revolutionary consciousness.Lenin insisted that a "vanguard" party, tiny but enormously ruthless, and possessing revolutionary consciousness, could pound the masses into material for transitioning to communism.Hence Lenin's party-state.Such a state has, however, two incurable defects: All policies are subordinate to the primary objective of maintaining the party's dominance. And the party incubates society's elites, who insinuate themselves everywhere into allocating wealth and opportunity. Absent market signals, this produces cascading inefficiencies in the allocation of society's human and material resources.With Leninist ham-handedness, Beijing recently highlighted its economic disarray by suppressing data confirming it. Having reported a youth unemployment rate of 21.3 percent in June - or misreported what might have been above 30 percent - Beijing released no data about youth unemployment in July, thereby fueling speculation about how much worse it now is.China is misleadingly said to have a "hybrid" economy of government planning leavened and disciplined by market forces. This suggests more orderliness than actually exists. Market forces are casually disregarded by the CCP's innumerable tentacles. China's "industrial policy" - pervasive government entanglement with private-sector enterprises - is a road to private-sector serfdom.Under the Leninist brutality of dictator Xi Jinping's "zero-covid" policy, a single covid-19 case could cause the lockdown of a city of millions, with devastating economic consequences. But most devastating is Leninist economic normality in a party-state. The Economist: "If spending is weak because households and entrepreneurs fear the party's intrusive policymaking, their spirits will not revive until Mr. Xi commits to self-restraint - a commitment that he cannot credibly make. The party lacks the power to limit its own power." In a recent three-year period, the Economist reports, China produced enough cement to turn Britain into a parking lot. But analyst Edward Luttwak, citing "at least 100 grossly under-utilized airports and the many highways that are mostly empty of traffic even in crowded China," says supposedly "semi-private" joint ventures are essentially CCP ventures.They are financed by "loans of the local branches of state banks, whose managers could not just say no to local party bosses, who could choose to invite them to sumptuous dinners in pretty company or to lock them up for corruption investigations as they saw fit." Hence today's Everest of domestic debt, (China's developers' debts equal about 16 percent of the nation's gross domestic product) and stagnation. The Economist says "short-term growth is no longer" the CCP's priority. National "greatness" is. But Leninism precludes this as Xi values loyalty over competence: "China used to tolerate debate about its economy, but today cajoles analysts into fake optimism. The fact that China's problems start at the top means they will persist." Writing in Foreign Affairs, Ian Johnson of the Council on Foreign Relations says Beijing's "strategy of accelerating government intervention in Chinese life" - an "obsession with control" - means "political ossification and ideological hardening" in a society devoid of "self-critical reflection." These are fruits of Leninism.Also in Foreign Affairs, Adam S. Posen, president of the Peterson Institute for International Economics, notes that "the autocrat's Achilles' heel is an inherent lack of credible self-restraint." In Xi's China, there is "widespread fear not seen since the days of Mao - fear of losing one's property or livelihood, whether temporarily or forever, without warning and without appeal." This is a recipe for social paralysis.The Leninist CCP is the nation's neurological system, and is making China sclerotic. In his 1964 biography of Lenin, Louis Fischer, an American foreign correspondent, recalled that a participant in Lenin's autopsy said that blood vessels in his brain were so calcified that "when struck with a tweezer they sounded like stone." China's regime has a Leninist brain like that.Reach George Will at georgewill@washpost.com.

title: Waterfowl Festival looks forward
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Waterfowl Festival looks forward

 May 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 815
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Deena Kilmon, the new executive director of the Waterfowl Festival, is excited to bring fresh energy and invite a new generation into the mission of the organization.Some changes are already visible. The Waterfowl Festival has welcomed a new staff and opened a new gift shop at the Armory, which houses the festival organization.
"We are laying the foundation for the future. If you think you know the Waterfowl Festival, I bet you don't. I invite people to come down to learn not only about the work we have done, but the work we want to do," Kilmon said.
For three days every November, about 20,000 visitors come to Easton for the annual Waterfowl Festival, which features art sales, demonstrations, educational events and more.
But the Waterfowl Festival is a year-round effort, with the organization also hosting a variety of events and supporting conservation nonprofits.
More new developments can be expected soon, Kilmon said, some of which are with the Armory building itself.
One of the big ways she wants to begin a new era for the Waterfowl Festival is by revitalizing the Armory's massive space.
There is a walled off stage at one end, and Kilmon wants to bring the proscenium arch back into use.
There are also rows of historically accurate new windows that will surround the Armory's drill space. They give the whole auditorium a kind of face lift.
"These are what the Maryland Historical Trust paid for. So it looks the same on the outside as it did to the 97-year-old building. We have just applied to the county to fix the roof. Once we fix the roof, the vision is to fix the stage," Kilmon said.
Kilmon's Assistant Director Sammie Mooney, who has a background in professional and community theater, wants to invite a whole new generation of the community into the building and maybe even rent it out.
Mooney is excited to connect with younger members of the waterfowl festival scene.
"I don't think I am trying to develop anything brand new, but bringing in newer people, the younger generation for the longevity of the festival," she said. "We want to do so many things with the building because it kind of sat here. It is an amazing building. We want it to become kind of a community center where events are always going on."
One such event is inviting in photographer Kristin Rutkowski, who created the portrait project "Her Helm" of women captains who ply the waters of the Chesapeake.
"It is all about the water and literally fits right in our mission," Kilmon said. "She will be here June 7, and I have another guy who wrote a book about raptors. He should be here in July. That is the kind of stuff we are bringing in. We could show a film here."
Organizers' passion to attract people to the Waterfowl Festivals' activities comes from the festival's mission and from the land itself.
"I love the Eastern Shore, the culture. When I was 14, I read James Michener's "Chesapeake" and totally fell in love with the romantic version of the Chesapeake Bay," Kilmon said.
She said her whole family loves to get out on the water and enjoy the open spaces.
"At the festival that is what we do. Try and conserve those spaces and make them available to and accessible to everyone," Kilmon said.
The organization does this through more than just hosting the annual festival and hosting events. The Waterfowl Festival has also invested millions of dollars into conservation efforts.
"We support organizations that do that work. There have been three or four dozen organizations over the years. It is well over $5 million since 1971," Kilmon said.
Their latest gift was to the Wellington WMA in Somerset County. They are taking farmland and turning it back into wetlands, partnering with private donors, the state and Ducks Unlimited.
Kilmon mentioned that there is a grant program for conservation organizations.
"It is a mini grant program for up to $5,000, and we are awarding about five of those. Say you are a little organization with conservation and education and there is no other funding for a project they want to do. We have already set this money aside at the Mid-Shore Community Foundation," she said.
She invited interested individuals and organizations to go to the Waterfowl Festival website to find a 30-minute application to receive a grant.
Becoming the new executive director has widened her eyes as to what the festival has done, Kilmon said.
"The legacy is insane. People have forgotten some of the players have passed or moved away, but some of their children are still here. What we are doing now becomes even more critical to this generation. They thought it was a crisis in '71, but what is it like now? It is beyond a crisis," she said.
"What I think is critical is re-engaging with our community and bringing in a new generation to make sure that the legacy of the festival continues," Kilmon said.

title: State reports early deer season results
content:
The Maryland Department of Natural Resources reports that hunters harvested 16,607 deer during the early portion of the 2023 archery and muzzleloader seasons. The harvest was an 18% decrease from last year's official harvest of 20,267 deer for the same period. The annual deer harvest fluctuates from year to year for a number of reasons, including hunter effort, weather conditions, availability of natural foods like acorns and current population size of the herd, DNR said.

title: Country Cooking: Fresh baked bread on a cool fall day
author: MARIE SAVAGE
content:
Country Cooking: Fresh baked bread on a cool fall day

 October 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE | Section: Life 
 
 1772
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The temperatures are dropping slowly. What a great time to begin making fresh bread.The family will love the warm kitchen with great smell of fresh baked bread. Have plenty of whipped butter on hand with jam, jelly or honey to smear on top.
In the winter, I will feature my favorite biscuit recipes. Contact me to feature your family favorites to share.
Here are six tips to consider when baking your breads.
Place a small ovenproof dish with water in the oven when baking to help prevent the crust from getting too hard or brown.Use margarine or oil shortening to grease the pans as margarine and oil absorb more readily into the dough or batter.To make self-rising flour, mix 4 cups flour, 2 teaspoons salt, and 2 tbsps baking powder.Hot water kills yeast. One way to tell the correct temperature is to pour the water over your forearm. If you do not feel hot or cold, then it's just perfect.When making nut bread, they are better stored 24 hours after baking and before serving.Use an empty and clean salt shaker to store flour to be used for shaking when recipes call for it.
BASIC WHITE BREAD
When I began making bread, this was the recipe I used until I felt more confident. Give this a try if this is your first attempt.
2 envelopes yeast, 4 cups water (90-100 degrees), 2 cups sugar, 2 tbsps shortening, 2 tbsps vinegar, 2 tsps salt, 12 cups flour.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Place all ingredients except the flour into the liquid in a large mixing bowl. Stir slightly until dissolved. Add 6 cups of the flour and beat. slowly stir in the remaining 6 cups of flour and let rest for 10 minutes. Place on a lightly floured board and knead for 2 minutes. Let rise until doubled in size. Punch down and let rise again. Shape into four loaves, place into loaf pans and bake in a preheated oven for 40 to 45 minutes. Enjoy.
SOURDOUGH BREAD
4 ¾ cups bread flour (or more as needed), 3 tbsps white sugar, 2 ½ tsps salt, 1 package active dry yeast, 1 cup warm milk, 2 tbsps margarine (softened), 1 ½ cups sourdough starter, 1 extra large egg, 1 tbsp water, ¼ cup chopped onion.
Combine 1 cup flour, sugar, salt and yeast in a large bowl. Add warm milk and margarine. Add in the starter mix. Mix in the remaining 3 3/4 cups of flour gradually; you may need to add more flour depending on the climate. Turn dough out onto a floured surface and knead for 8 to 10 minutes. Place dough into a greased bowl, turn once to the oil surface, and cover. Allow to rise until doubled in volume, about 1 hour. Punch down dough; cover and rest for 15 minutes. Divide dough in half and shape into two loaves. Place loaves on a greased baking pan. Allow to rise until doubled in volume, about 1 hour. Preheat the oven to 375 degrees. Stir together egg and water in a small bowl until well combined. Brush over the tops of loaves, then sprinkle with onion. Bake in the preheated oven until the loaves are golden brown and cooked through, about 30 minutes. An instant-read thermometer inserted into the center of a loaf should read 190 degrees.
HOMEMADE ARTISAN BREAD
3 1/4 cups bread flour (plus more for hands and pan), 2 tsps instant yeast, 2 tsps coarse salt, 1 1/2 cups water (close to room temperature at about 70 degrees).
In a large, ungreased mixing bowl, whisk the flour, yeast and salt together. Pour in the water and gently mix with a silicone spatula or wooden spoon. The dough will seem dry and shaggy, but keep working until all the flour is moistened. If needed, use your hands to work the dough ingredients together. The dough will be sticky. Shape into a ball in the bowl as best you can. Keeping the dough in the bowl, cover the dough tightly with plastic wrap or aluminum foil and set on the counter at room temperature. Allow to rise for 2-3 hours. The dough will just double in size, stick to the sides of the bowl, and have a lot of air bubbles. You can continue with step 4 immediately, but for the absolute best flavor and texture, I strongly recommend letting this risen dough rest in the refrigerator for at least 12 hours and up to 3 days. Place covered dough in the refrigerator for 12 hours — 3 days. I usually let it rest in the refrigerator for about 18 hours. The dough will puff up during this time but may begin to deflate after 2 days. That's fine and normal, nothing to worry about. Lightly dust a large nonstick baking sheet with flour and/or cornmeal. Turn the cold dough out onto a floured work surface. Using a sharp knife or bench scraper, cut dough in half. Some air bubbles will deflate as you work with it. Place dough halves on prepared baking sheet. Using floured hands, shape into 2 long loaves about 9-by-3 inches each about 3 inches apart. Loosely cover and allow to rest for 45 minutes. You will bake the dough on this prepared baking sheet. During these 45 minutes, preheat the oven to 475 degrees. When ready to bake, using a very sharp knife score the bread loaves with 3 slashes, about 1/2 inch deep. If the shaped loaves flattened out during the 45 minutes, use floured hands to narrow them out along the sides again. Place the shaped and scored dough on the flour dusted pan in the preheated oven on the center rack. Bake for 20-25 minutes or until the crust is golden brown. Gently tap the loaves—if they sound hollow, the bread is done. For a more accurate test of doneness, the bread is done when an instant read thermometer inserted in the center reads 195 degrees. Remove the bread from the oven and allow it to cool for at least 20 minutes before slicing and serving. Store leftovers loosely covered at room temperature for up to 5 days or in the refrigerator for up to 1 week.
HONEY SPICE BREAD
2/3 cup packed brown sugar, 1/3 cup 2% milk, 2 cups all-purpose flour, 1 1/2 tsps baking powder, 1/2 tsp ground cinnamon, 1/2 tsp ground nutmeg, 1/8 tsp ground cloves, 2 large eggs (room temperature), 1/2 cup honey, 1/3 cup canola oil. GLAZE: 1/3 cup confectioners' sugar, 2 tesps 2% milk.
Preheat the oven to 325 degrees. In a small saucepan, combine brown sugar and milk. Cook and stir over low heat until sugar is dissolved. Remove from heat. In a large bowl, whisk flour, baking powder, cinnamon, nutmeg and cloves. In another bowl, whisk eggs, honey, oil and brown sugar mixture until blended. Add to flour mixture; stir just until moistened. Transfer the batter to a greased 8-by-4-inch loaf pan. Bake for 50-60 minutes or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean (cover top loosely with foil if needed to prevent over-browning). Cool in pan for 10 minutes before removing to a wire rack to cool completely. In a small bowl, stir glaze ingredients until smooth, drizzle over bread.
AMISH WHITE BREAD
2 cups of warm water (110 degrees), ⅔ cup white sugar, 1 ½ tbsps active dry yeast, ¼ cup vegetable oil,1 ½ tsps salt, 6 cups bread flour.
Dissolve sugar in warm water in a large bowl and then stir in yeast. Allow to proof until the yeast resembles a creamy foam, 5 to 10 minutes. Mix oil and salt into the yeast. Mix in flour one cup at a time. Knead dough on a lightly floured surface until it is smooth. Place it in a well-oiled bowl and turn dough to coat. Cover with a damp cloth. Allow to rise until doubled in bulk, about 1 hour. Punch dough down. Knead for a few minutes and divide in half. Shape into loaves and place into two well-oiled 9-by-5-inch loaf pans. Allow it to rise until dough has topped the pans by one inch, about 30 minutes. Meanwhile, preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Bake the risen loaves in the preheated oven until golden brown for 30 minutes.
COUNTY WHOLE WHEAT BREAD
2 1/2 cup warm buttermilk (body temperature is good), 2 tbsps honey, 1 tbsp dry active yeast, 5 1/2 cups fine grind whole wheat flour, 1 cup unbleached bread flour (plus more as needed), 1 tbsp kosher salt, 1 egg, 3 tbsps unsalted butter (soft), 2 tbsps poppy seeds, 1 egg white mixed with a tablespoon of water.
Warm the buttermilk to body temperature. In other words when you stick a finger into it you shouldn't feel it. Place the buttermilk in a large bowl. Add a tablespoon of yeast and honey to it. Let the yeast dissolve either by whisking it or letting it bloom. Add the whole wheat flour, 1 cup of bread flour, egg and salt. Using a thick handled wooden spoon mix the dough in a circular fashion adding the softened butter once the dough has started to form. Once the dough has formed remove it from the bowl to a clean countertop and knead the dough until it is smooth, elastic and the gluten has formed. Consider this your workout for the day. Roll the dough into a tight ball. Place the dough back into the bowl, cover it with a damp warm towel and set it in a warm place. Set a timer for 1 hour. At the end of the hour punch down the dough and set the timer for another hour. At the end of this hour the dough should be doubled in size. Punch down the dough and divide it in half. Roll it into a ball and either divide it into thirds so you can roll it into logs and braid it or roll it into two big logs. Place the loaves into prepared pans. I always oil and then shake flour into my pans. The thin coating of flour lets the baked bread easily release from the pan. Cover with a warm damp towel and let the dough rise for 40 minutes to an hour. Preheat the oven to 375 degrees. Once the loaves have doubled, brush them with the egg wash and sprinkle with poppy seeds or sesame seeds. You can also dust the tops with flour but if you do this don't use the egg wash. Bake the loaves in the oven for 45 to 50 minutes, rotating them halfway through baking. Remove the loaves from the oven and remove them from the bread pans to a rack and let them cool.

title: For All Seasons partners for suicide intervention
author: Staff Writer
content:
For All Seasons partners for suicide intervention

 March 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Life 
 
 343
 Words 

 Read News Document

 For All Seasons' Center for Learning is partnering with Santé Eastern Shore to offer LivingWorks ASIST (Applied Suicide Intervention Skills Training) on April 7 and 8 from 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. each day at Anchor Church in Easton.This two-day in-person workshop includes interactive learning, hands-on practice, and real-world application exercises to learn the skills to provide a suicide first-aid intervention for someone who has thoughts of suicide. The workshop is designed for all caregivers (anyone over age 15 in a position of trust), including mental health professionals, nurses, physicians, pharmacists, teachers, counselors, youth workers, police and correctional staff, school support staff, clergy, and community volunteers.
Participants will learn how to recognize when someone may be thinking about suicide and take steps to support them, to develop a safety plan to keep someone safe for now and connect them with further help; talk openly about personal and community attitudes and suicide, build confidence and capacity in providing suicide first-aid, understand how attitudes about suicide influence intervention approaches and gain insights into community resources and support networks to sustain long-term suicide prevention efforts.
The training will include breakfast, lunch and snacks each day, as well as all the necessary materials. Participating clinicians will receive 12 Category I CEUs issued by For All Seasons, an approved continuing education provider for Maryland social workers and professional counselors.
The registration fee of $350 is due at the time of enrollment. All registrations are due no later than March 31 at forallseasonsinc.lpages.co/asist-training-2025/. For questions, contact Kelsey Trumbull-Meyers at CenterForLearning@forallseasonsinc.org. Because this training is grant-funded, For All Seasons is required to report program outcomes. Participants will be asked to complete multiple-choice surveys before the training begins and after the training's completion.
For All Seasons provides the highest quality mental health and victim services to children, adults, and families across the Mid-Shore and throughout Maryland. Services are offered in both English and Spanish and include therapy, psychiatry, victim advocacy, 24-hour crisis hotlines, outreach, and community education. For information about For All Seasons walk-in hours, contact For All Seasons at 410-822-1018 or visit ForAllSeasonsInc.org.

title: Country Cooking: Summer snacking
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Summer snacking

 June 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: News 
 
 1108
 Words 

 Read News Document

 School is out, and summer fun is just beginning. Get those sweets and treats ready because the "I'm hungry" crowd has arrived.Ever wonder how kids can sit in school six hours a day with only lunch but when school is closed the "I'm hungry" cry is every two to three hours? It is easier to have snacks prepared and ready to hand out.
Buy a large economy size box of zipper snack bags and fill assorted crackers and chips. Fill another batch with assorted raisins, nuts, dried banana chips and gummy bears. Have small, flavored water bottles ready to simply hand out. I remember those summer shopping carts when I bought the little Kool-Aid flavored drink mixes in as many flavors as possible.
It seems I bought mostly grape and orange flavors. Homemade lemonade and sweet tea were saved for dinner time. At one point in the early '70s, with enough package points, you could order the plastic Kool-Aid pitcher with matching drinking cups for free. The Kool-Aid emblem was on the side of the cups.
Sometimes I would mix a package of Kool-Aid and pour in the ice cube trays, freeze and add to the glass of Kool-Aid for fun. This could also be tasty with a mixture of different flavors with the drink and ice cubes.
Making lunch sandwiches could be fun by using large cookie cutters to cut the bread. Place the cut-out sandwich on a plate and lay chips and pickles on the side. Use toothpicks to push into small chunks of cheese for added fun and nutrition.
FROZEN BANANA BITES
1 cup peanut butter, 4 bananas (sliced into 1-inch rounds), 8 (1 oz) squares semisweet chocolate, 1 tbsp shortening, ⅓ cup toffee baking bits.
Cover a baking sheet with waxed paper. Spoon a thin layer of peanut butter on top of each banana slice. Insert a toothpick through the peanut butter layer into the banana. Place banana bites onto the prepared baking sheet; freeze for 30 minutes to overnight. Melt chocolate and shortening in the top of a double boiler over simmering water, stirring frequently and scraping down the sides with a rubber spatula to avoid scorching. Cover another baking sheet with waxed paper. Remove 2 to 4 banana bites from the freezer at a time; coat each bite with chocolate mixture. Place coated banana bites on the second baking sheet; sprinkle each with toffee bits. Repeat until all the bites are coated. Return banana bites to the freezer until set, at least 1 hour. Allow bites to sit at room temperature for about 15 minutes before serving.
ICE CREAM SANDWICH POPS
6 ice cream sandwiches, 2 bottles chocolate shell topping (such as Magic Shell), 12 popsicle sticks, assorted toppings (such as sprinkles, crushed cookies, nuts, crushed candy bars. We love Oreo cookies.)
Cut ice cream sandwiches in half crosswise. Insert a popsicle stick through up through the center of each cut end. Remove the caps and seals from the shell topping. Place in the microwave and cook for 8 seconds. Pour each bottle shell topping into a glass measuring cup. Dip each pop into shell topping until completely covered, allowing excess to drip off. Dip the top ends in desired toppings and place on a parchment-lined baking sheet. Freeze pops at least 1 hour before serving.
CLASSIC PUDDING POPS
One of my son John's favorite snacks as a kid was pudding pops. You don't really see them in the stores too often anymore. Here is a homemade recipe for that nostalgic sweet treat.
2 cups milk, ½ cup evaporated milk, 1 (3.5 oz) package instant chocolate pudding mix, ¼ cup white sugar.
Beat milk, evaporated milk, instant pudding and sugar in a bowl until thoroughly combined. Pour into ice pop molds and freeze until firm, about 3 hours. Also for this recipe if you are diabetic or making you can prepare it this way. Use zero sugar pistachio pudding, substitute liquid Splenda for the sugar (1/2 tsp) and they are wonderful.
S'MORES POPSICLES
2 cups cold milk, 1 package instant chocolate pudding mix, 2 whole graham crackers (crushed), 1 ½ cups vanilla ice cream (softened).
Beat milk and pudding mix together in a bowl using an electric mixer until thickened, about 2 minutes. Measure 1 1/2 cup pudding and set remaining pudding aside for another use. Sprinkle graham cracker crumbs into the bottom of each ice pop mold; add about 1/4 cup ice cream. Sprinkle another layer of graham cracker crumbs and top with about 1/4 cup pudding. Add a final layer of graham cracker crumbs. Freeze until completely frozen, about 3 hours.
TROPICAL FRUIT ICICLES
½ cups low-fat vanilla yogurt, 1 cup sliced mango, 1 (8 oz) can pineapple chunks (undrained), 1 small banana, 1 orange (juiced).
Blend yogurt, mango, pineapple chunks with juice, banana, and orange juice in a blender until smooth. Pour into ice pop molds; freeze until set, 4 to 6 hours.
PEANUT BUTTER BANANA
ICE CREAM
4 ripe bananas cut into 1-inch slices, ¼ cup peanut butter.
Arrange banana slices on a baking sheet and freeze, 8 hours to overnight. Process frozen bananas in a food processor until evenly chopped; add peanut butter and process until thick and creamy.
STRAWBERRY LEMONADE
1 lb. strawberries plus more to garnish, 1 1/2 cups granulated sugar, 2 cups fresh lemon juice (strained and divided), ice, lemon slices to garnish.
Hull and quarter the strawberries. Place the strawberries in a large bowl, stir in the sugar and ¼ cup lemon juice. Allow to sit, covered for 30 minutes. In a countertop blender, blend the strawberry mixture until pureed. Strain the mixture through a fine mesh sieve to get the seeds out. In a large bowl, combine the strawberry puree with the remaining 1 ¾ cups of lemon juice and 4 cups of water. Add up to 1 additional cup of water to taste if the mixture is too sweet or strong. To serve, stir the lemonade and pour it over ice. Garnish with sliced lemon and strawberries.
HOMEMADE FRUIT POPSICLES
Strawberries, blueberries, raspberries, pineapple and mango are just a few of the fruits you can use here. For this one we will use 2 cups fresh blueberries, raspberries, strawberries and sliced bananas (mixed); 2 cups plain or vanilla yogurt, ¼ cup white sugar, 8 small paper cups, 8 popsicle sticks.
Place the mixed blueberries, raspberries, strawberries, sliced bananas, yogurt, and sugar into a blender. Cover, and blend until the fruit is chunky or smooth, as desired. Fill paper cups 3/4 full with fruit mixture. Cover the top of each cup with a strip of aluminum foil. Poke a popsicle stick through the center of the foil on each cup. Place the cups in the freezer for at least 5 hours. To serve, remove foil and peel off the paper cup.

title: Bridge - Deception by deduction
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - Deception by deduction

 December 26, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: A7 | Section: News 
 
 254
 Words 

 Read News Document

 John Ruskin, who was an English art critic, discussed painters when he wrote, "The essence of lying is in deception, not in words." In bridge, sometimes you lie in words when you make, for example, a psychic bid.During the play, sometimes you lie by false carding. In today's deal, a defender fooled declarer by dropping an unnecessarily high card. However, it helped that he had calculated his "generosity" couldn't cost a trick.
In four hearts, declarer won the first trick with his club ace and cashed the heart ace, "dropping" West's queen.
Worried that East had four trumps, South immediately ran the diamond 10. East kept up the good defense, ducking his king. Suddenly fooled, South repeated the diamond finesse, but East won with the king and gave his partner a diamond ruff.
West cashed the club queen, and the heart jack was the fourth defensive trick.
Cool - but how did West know he could afford to play the heart queen? Well, if South had started with A-Jx-x of hearts, he would have played a heart to dummy's king and taken the trump finesse. So, when South started with the heart ace, East was marked with the jack. Dropping the queen was safe. Also, it couldn't mislead East, because South was marked with four hearts from the auction. (If South had opened one no-trump with five hearts, he would have drawn two rounds of trumps before taking the diamond finesse.)
However, remember, when trying a deceptive defense, be careful not to deceive your partner more than declarer.

Commissioners of Oxford table voting resolution

 OXFORD — Although at the start of a Commissioners of Oxford discussion Tuesday Commission President Norm Bell recommended the commissioners vote that evening on a resolution to clarify the town's voting registration requirements, the commissioners tabled the resolution in a two to one vote."In order to get this right, I think we need more time," Commissioner Katrina Greer said. "I think it would be better to do nothing and write some rules for the election committee, which we can do without a charter change."
The now tabled resolution would amend the town's charter to clarify a person must register with the Talbot County Board of Elections to qualify as a voter in the town. This means a resident would not be able to vote in Oxford town elections if they aren't registered with the county board.
Before the vote was taken, Bell expressed concern that if the resolution is not voted on at the meeting, it could be delayed to the point where, if the resolution is passed, it is not in effect for the town's upcoming election in June when Commissioner Tom Costigan's term is set to expire.
But Bell, who ultimately voted in favor of tabling the resolution, acknowledged the commissioners should not rush into making amendments to the charter regarding voting.
At a public hearing for the resolution Feb. 25, residents shared thoughts on who should and shouldn't be considered eligible to vote in town elections. The discussion, which opened the doors to potential additional charter amendments, led commissioners to hold a work session March 5.
Greer said the work session brought a lot of input, and she said there were still a lot of questions.
"I do not want to pass this in a rush tonight," she said Tuesday.
Costigan, the only commissioner to vote against tabling the resolution, said he felt the resolution addressed a "flaw" in the charter's verbiage.
"All that it did was recognize that the Talbot County system was the most logical way to assure that people are eligible and can vote," he said, adding that the concerns around who is eligible to vote would need to be addressed in another section of the charter.
After the resolution was tabled, Town Attorney Lyndsey Ryan suggested the commissioners write rules for the Oxford Election Board regarding registration, absentee ballots and poll watching.
"The last election we had a livestream for individuals to watch," she said. "If you're going to follow that process again, we should have something established."
Greer said they should hold a work session on the matter, and Bell agreed that a work session should be scheduled.

title: Rabbi Hyman delivers multicultural understanding
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Rabbi Hyman delivers multicultural understanding

 August 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: News 
 
 705
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Easton has been and is blessed with an extraordinarily number of exceptionally talented individuals engaged in a wide range of community service endeavors.One of them is Rabbi Peter Hyman DD (Doctor of Divinity) who is retiring in October after serving 18 years as the first full-time rabbi at Easton's Temple B'nai Israel.
Rabbi Hyman has a long history in walking his talk on promoting greater understanding of and respect for individuals with different religious beliefs and different faith journeys.
There is no more enduring symbol of Rabbi Hyman's commitment to respect for other religious beliefs than a Persian rug he bought in Israel 40 years ago. It is now on display in his office. That rug includes 99 names of God in Arabic. Rabbi Hyman views it as a metaphorical bridge connecting people of different faiths.
He once asked the leaders of a mosque if they could help him translate some of the Arabic words on his rug. They did so, amazed that such an inclusive rug was owned and displayed by a rabbi.
For Rabbi Hyman, it was simply his belief that "building relationships not only creates friendships, but they also cement ties."
A partial list of his local efforts to improve the quality of life in our community and beyond, includes serving as a member, program vice president and president of the Talbot Association of Clergy and Laity. He received an Award of Appreciation for Outstanding and Inspiring Interfaith Work in Talbot County for a Temple B'nai Israel February Lecture Series: "Introduction to Islam."
He was a recipient of the NAACP Dorothy Webb Black Community Service Legacy Award and a recipient of a Governor William Donald Schaefer Helping People Award. He was a member of The Frederick Douglass Celebration Committee and delivered the sermon at the Community Interfaith Worship Celebration, which was a part of the "Douglass Returns" statue dedication.
An author and teacher, he served as a presenter and instructor at Chesapeake College's Institute for Adult Learning and collaborated with Bishop Joel Marcus Johnson to launch a "Downtown Lunch and Learn" program. He was elected to the board of directors at the YMCA of the Chesapeake and appointed chair of the board at the Easton YMCA.
Support for Scouting has been a huge part of Rabbi Hyman's life since he earned his Eagle Scout award, as did his two sons. That is an achievement that has been earned by only 6% of all Scouts since 1912.
He has served as a scoutmaster and a chaplain at Scout World Jamborees in Thailand, England, Sweden and Japan and a National Jamboree in the United States. He was the first national chair for the Messengers of Peace Program, BSA, after having served as a national chair of the Jewish Committee on Scouting and as national Jewish chaplain — Boy Scouts of America. He was the keynote speaker at a national annual meeting of the BSA "Duty to God Breakfast" in Washington, D.C.
He is a recipient of the Silver Buffalo Award for distinguished service to youth awarded by the National Council of Boy Scouts of America. He is also a recipient of the Bronze Wolf Award, which is the Scouts' highest honor. It is presented by the World Scout Committee to recognize the service, commitment and contributions of volunteers to the Scout movement. Not surprisingly Hyman received the award for his interfaith activities and his lifelong commitment to "building bridges between people and nations."
Rabbi Hyman represented the BSA in Saudi Arabia at Saudi Nation Day when they received an award for the work of the BSA with the Messengers of Peace Program. This program promotes service projects through social media in effort to achieve world peace.
Hyman recalls that trip as the most amazing experience of his life because he was welcome in a Muslim country.
While the news of Rabbi Hyman's impending retirement is bittersweet, there is some good news.
He is not planning to leave the Eastern Shore.
Whether he stays here for the short term or long term, one thing is certain. He has made countless selfless contributions to help make Easton, Talbot County, and our world a better place.
Each one of them has earned Rabbi Hyman a well-deserved thank you and Godspeed.
David Reel is a public affairs and public relations consultant based in Easton.

 EASTON - The card game at American Legion Post 77 ended abruptly on Wednesday evening when a duplex located next door caught fire shortly after 5:30 p.m., pulling players from the table and into the action."We were in there playing cards together, and my father said, 'Come outside and see the smoke.' He said, 'Is that my vehicle on fire?'" said Anthony Wilson, a member of the lodge, who stood across the street as firefighters extinguished dwindling embers. (Some members) ran around here and saw the smoke and said there was a fire Then all of us came out and came over here." "(There were) no injuries. Nothing but the dog. Everybody else was gone, except for the guy upstairs. We kicked the door pretty hard, and he finally came out, luckily. Everyone else was out after that, and it was just a matter of time waiting for the fire company."Dispatchers alerted local fire departments about the blaze at 5:46 p.m. About 60 first responders reported to the scene, according to emergency officials at the scene.An official from the St. Michaels Volunteer Fire Department, who was on the scene, confirmed that there were no injuries reported in the incident and that the fire was contained to a single structure, located at 21 South West St. in Easton.Due to the structure's age, he said, safeguards had not been included in its construction, making the duplex susceptible to the quick-spreading fire.Neighbors who gathered at the scene reported that the duplex, which consists of an upstairs and a downstairs unit, had been engulfed in flames at one point in the evening, with fire visible from both upstairs and downstairs windows.Firefighters on the scene included the Easton Volunteer Fire Department, the Oxford Fire Company, the Trappe Volunteer Fire Company, the St. Michaels Fire Department and the Cordova Volunteer Fire Company. title: Lions extend title stretk to four

Lions extend title stretk to four

 May 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: News

 Read News Document

 BERLIN — Queen Anne's County High's girls lacrosse team doesn't have much use for the word pressure.Instead, the themes that are constant companions for the Lions are, expectations and standards.
"They're always the expectations at QA," Lions head coach Kesley Fitzgerald said. "And I put it on our girls, and on myself and coaching staff, to do whatever we can to get us the success that we've gotten in the past, and make sure it keeps flowing into the future."
Queen Anne's kept its rule over the Bayside Conference flowing Monday night, as senior RJ Ensor scored six goals and set up another, pacing the Lions to a fourth consecutive conference championship with an 11-8 victory over host Stephen Decatur.
"I think it's a big honor to hold, and I think it's an expectation for our program," said junior midfielder Haley Cole of winning the conference title. "That's just how we play. It's expected of us. And we all want it. This is just one of the most connected teams I've been on."
Winners of 11 straight, Queen Anne's (12-1) took a lead it maintained from start to finish a little over 4 minutes into play, when Cole set up Charlotte Schmidt's initial goal. Ensor made it 2-0 with a free-position strike 2:27 later.
But the Seahawks (7-6) weren't ready for a repeat of the April 16 meeting between the two teams, when Queen Anne's earned a 16-6 victory in Centreville.
Laila Pascucci (two goals, assist) converted Lo Malinowski's feed to put Decatur on the board with 4:23 left in the opening quarter. Cole answered, snapping a shot from right wing past Seahawks goalie Layla Hamrock (six saves). Pascucci again responded for the Seahawks with 18 seconds left in the first, pulling Decatur within 3-2.
"We knew coming down here it would be more hype for them," Fitzgerald said of Decatur. "The (Decatur) boys just won (13-11 over Kent Island in the boys championship) a big game. You get propelled by that. We knew they were a good program and would make adjustments. And we made adjustments too."
But the Lions took control with a 7-2 surge that started with Ensor setting up Riley Klepper's goal 52 seconds into the second period, and finished with Ensor's sixth goal with 1:24 left in the third period, pushing Queen Anne's to a 10-4 lead.
"Every team wants a lead," Fitzgerald said. "I think we're comfortable with a good strong lead. I would like to have seen us obviously put a few more in, get some more padding, but play a little bit more patient ball. And know when you have the lead in a game of momentum with high emotion that you have to be a little smart with your clock management, even when you're in the second quarter and third quarter."
Helping the Lions establish that solid lead were Bea Holthaus' efforts on the draw, and Cole's all-around play at the midfield.
"Starting with that draw, the possessions are what helped us" Fitzgerald said. "I'm sure Decatur is probably not happy with some of the turnovers that they had. And we really didn't execute off many of their turnovers. But we did get the possessions and I think that probably helped a little bit to feel like we still had control of the game."
Goals from Ensor, Kaitlyn Horney and Kaisa Hickson helped the Lions build a 7-4 halftime lead. That lead ballooned to 10-4 in the third quarter, as Ensor scored three straight goals — two off assists from Schmidt and Hickson.
But late in the third quarter, Queen Anne's drew a 2-minute, non-releasable yellow card and Decatur capitalized. MB Morse (two goals) and Jill Burton (two goals) each scored once in the final 30 seconds of the third, pulling Decatur within 10-6. Morse scored off Pascucci's pass to make it a three-goal difference 1:08 into the fourth.
Queen Anne's killed off the remaining 19 seconds of the penalty. Then with 5:52 remaining, Ensor wheeled from behind the net, made quick stop, pivoted and squeezed a shot between Hamrock and the right post for an 11-7 lead.
"You score that goal and your opponent's looking up at the clock going, 'We got to go, we got to go,'" Fitzgerald said. "That's huge."
Hamrock denied Ensor with 4:20 left and the Seahawks transitioned quickly downfield, where Mara Mills fired a shot past Lions goalie Emma Dulin (six saves) with 4:01 remaining.
Queen Anne's won the ensuing draw. Fitzgerald called time with 3:15 remaining, then watched her team pass and run the ball around to burn clock. Fitzgerald called another timeout with 18 seconds left, and again watched her team play keep away to seal the title.
"Our seniors have never lost a Bayside championship," Fitzgerald said. "That means a lot to our program and I think it's something they should be really, really proud of. I think that's really hard in this women's lacrosse atmosphere around here, where we've got good, strong competition. And it's only getting better. So that means we have to keep putting expectations and the standards high."
Notes: It's the third time in Bayside history a team has won four straight titles, with Queen Anne's doing it twice (2022-25, and 2011-2014) and Decatur once (2006-09).

title: Seminar Focuses On Trends In Pancreatic Cancer Care
author: Contributed
content:
Seminar Focuses On Trends In Pancreatic Cancer Care

 November 24, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 8 | Section: News

 Read News Document

 NEAVITT - Pancreatic cancer is a relatively rare cancer, representing only 3% of estimated new cancer diagnoses each year.However, it is especially lethal. Presently the third leading cause of cancer death, pancreatic cancer kills more than 50,000 Americans every year.For the Mid-Shore Pancreatic Cancer Foundation Inc., supporting efforts to advance the diagnosis and treatment of pancreatic cancer and educating the public about risk factors and symptoms of the disease are key strategies for saving lives.On this year's World Pancreatic Cancer Awareness Day Nov. 16, the Foundation sponsored a seminar, "New Trends in Pancreatic Cancer Diagnosis and Treatment," in the Cadby Theatre at Chesapeake College in Wye Mills.Designed for clinicians involved in patient care, the evening program featured presentations by three leading University of Maryland Medical System oncology specialists: Nader Hanna, a professor of surgery at UM School of Medicine and director of clinical operations for the Division of General and Oncologic Surgery at the University of Maryland Medical Center (UMMC); Yixing Jiang, a professor of medicine at UM SOM and director of GI medical oncology at the Marlene and Stewart Greenebaum Cancer Center at UMMC; and Jason K. Molitoris, an associate professor of radiation oncology at UM SOM, associate medical director at the Department of Radiation Oncology at UMMC, and director of Clinical Hyperthermia Program.Hanna provided an overview of various risk factors for pancreatic cancer, including heredity (indicating a family history of certain genetic mutations) and smoking, and noted that symptoms of the disease, such as weight loss, back pain, jaundice and adult-onset (over age 65) diabetes, most often don't present until the disease is relatively advanced.He also reviewed various diagnostic strategies and surgical approaches, stressing the importance of surgical resection as the most significant factor for survival.Jiang discussed the genetic aspects of pancreatic cancer and how chemotherapy drugs are tailored to address the specific mutations identified in individual patients.She noted that systemic chemotherapy provides curative results for less than 30 percent of patients and that side effects can be very severe. However, in many cases it does improve survival time and also palliates cancer-related symptoms.Molitoris described the role of radiation in treating pancreatic cancer, including challenges caused by the location of the pancreas near other tissues that can be damaged by radiation.He described the criteria for cases in which radiation is employed prior to surgery to shrink tumor size, or after surgery to palliate complications from the disease and improve quality of life."We were really pleased to have a good turnout for this event, and the presenters provided very clear and detailed updates from the standpoint of their practice," said Bill Shrieves, president of the Mid-Shore Pancreatic Foundation Inc."The Foundation does a lot to support pancreatic cancer patients and to raise funds for research on the disease, but as one of our volunteers commented, this event might be the most important thing we've done as an organization.If just one of the clinicians who attended does something different based on the information that was shared and it improves the outcome for a pancreatic cancer patient, that is the best kind of success," he said.Shrieves also credited support from Tidewater Rotary in making the event possible."A generous grant of $5,000 from Rotary's Flags for Cancer Program made it possible for us to offer this event free of charge, and we are very grateful for that support," he said.Established in 2013, The Mid-Shore Pancreatic Cancer Foundation Inc. sponsors and participates in events that raise awareness about pancreatic cancer in the community, and also helps patients and their families in the Mid-Shore region find assistance, financial support and transportation to and from treatments.The group funds research through direct grants or support for other organizations, such as the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network.For more information about The Mid-Shore Pancreatic Cancer Foundation, Inc., visit midshorepancan.org/or call 410-745-9243.

Talbot council mulling $1.1 million request from school district

 May 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 706
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — With less than two weeks until the Talbot County Council adopts its budget ordinance for next fiscal year, education funding hangs in the balance.Talbot County Public Schools is seeking $1.1 million in additional funds for fiscal year 2026 — $600,000 to fill nine new positions and $500,000 for teacher and staff salary increases. The former would add to the district's multilingual and special education staff, while the latter aims to inch the district closer to state-mandated $60,000 teacher salary minimums by fiscal year 2027.
District leaders say it's a "scaled-back" request from its $5.7 million ask of the county earlier this budget cycle.
"We recognize the financial pressures you face," Board of Education President Emily Jackson said at a May 6 budget hearing. "This ask is lean, deliberate and rooted in what's most necessary to keep moving forward."
In the county's budget already is $55 million for TCPS as required by The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's overarching education improvement framework.
Council members are left to mull the best option as they prepare to vote on final amendments to the county's draft $161 million budget. So far, there's no clear decision.
Council Vice President Pete Lesher supported fulfilling the district's full $5.7 million request last month and maintained that stance for the pared down ask at a budget deliberation Tuesday.
"We're going to have to do it sooner or later," Lesher said. "I think it makes sense to do it this year and reduce the pain next year."
President Chuck Callahan said he feels comfortable with honoring the $600,000 part of the request to cover the new positions.
Council members Keasha Haythe, Lynn Mielke and Dave Stepp have all indicated they need more time to consider options.
Any additional funding granted would result in an education supplement to the property tax rate, which is 79 cents per $100 of assessed value.
Talbot County is already mandated by the state to pay $440,000 for teachers' pensions, which will be collected through a supplement of less than half a cent per $100 of assessed value.
Three potential scenarios for tax supplements have been laid out by county staff:
Teachers' pensions only: 0.0045 per $100 of assessed value.
Teachers' pensions and $500,000 for salary increases: 0.0096 per $100 of assessed value.
Teachers' pensions and $600,000 for new positions: 0.0106 per $100 of assessed value.
Haythe said Tuesday she's trying to balance helping the school system with preventing tax increases for residents on fixed income, such as seniors.
"I am in no way, shape or form trying to discount the great work that the school system does and what the teachers do in the classroom," Haythe said.
At last week's hearing, teachers and parents advocated for the council to include the $1.1 million. Lisa Hayes, a parent of three TCPS graduates, said past education investments are paying off now as her children enter the workforce.
"You cannot not fund a budget for our children's education because there is nothing more important than that," Hayes said.
Andy Burke, president of the Talbot County Education Association, which functions as the teachers' union, made his case.
"We continue to see too many educators migrate away to the higher wages and salaries paid in neighboring public school systems," Burke said.
In an emailed statement, TCPS Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones said the district made "very difficult choices" to reduce its request to the county.
Jones noted staff will present the Board of Education with a budget amendment package in June, which will adjust the $86 million unrestricted budget the board OK'd in February.
"We will eliminate most of the new positions we had requested," Jones wrote. "We will scale back our requests and defer programs that will have the least direct impact on our goals for our students."
A final decision by the county on the $1.1 million in question, as well as the entire FY26 budget, is expected at the council's May 27 meeting.
While no clear choice was made during Tuesday's deliberations, county and district leaders did agree that state mandates and formulas are creating the tricky fiscal situation.
"It's just become screamingly clear that there's a disconnect at the state level between the requirements that they're putting on local schools across the state, and the funding formulas that are articulated to county governments to pay for their education," said County Manager Clay Stamp.

author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge man sentenced for child abuse, assault

 February 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Crime 
 
 387
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A Cambridge man has been sentenced to incarceration after being found guilty of charges that stem from an incident with his infant in April 2023.On Feb. 21, Marcus Peak, 28, was sentenced to 28 years of incarceration, with all but 15 of those years suspended, in the Dorchester County Circuit Court. Peak was also sentenced to serve five years of probation with the condition that he not have any unsupervised contact with minors.
In December, Dorchester County Circuit Court Judge William Jones found Peak guilty of of first- and second-degree assault, first- and second-degree child abuse, neglect of a minor and reckless endangerment.
The charges against Peak stem from an incident on April 21, 2023, when Cambridge Police officers responded to assist Dorchester County Emergency Medical Services with an infant who was unconscious and not breathing. EMS treated the infant and transported her to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Cambridge. The baby was then transported to Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore.
According to police, Peak told detectives he had just fed his daughter a bottle and placed her in a bassinet for a nap. He said the baby was asleep.
Peak said that when he returned to check on her later, he noticed the baby's head was tilted to the side with fluid coming from her nose and mouth. He said the baby's eyes were partially opened.
At that time, Peak denied any traumatic event that could have caused injury to his daughter.
Detectives were told Peak had lied and did not inform them the baby had fallen to the floor, striking her head. Peak allegedly then picked the baby up and shook her to wake her up, according to a report from the Cambridge Police Department.
During the trial in December, Dr. Eric Klotz, an emergency medicine physician who treated the child that day, said the child's injuries were consistent with a high mechanism of injury. He said it was one of the more severe head injuries he's seen in his career.
Dr. Joseph Scheller, a pediatric neurologist who was asked by Peak's defense to testify, said it is possible the child's injuries were caused by an accidental fall. He said short falls can sometimes cause serious injury.
According to Maryland court documents, Dorchester County Assistant Public Defender Michelle Moodispaw filed a notice to appeal the case on Tuesday.

title: Core's late goal lifts Bennett to third straight title
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Core's late goal lifts Bennett to third straight title

 October 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 682
 Words 

 Read News Document

 SNOW HILL — James M. Bennett High girls head soccer coach Ed O'Leary knew the final of the regular-season match was deceiving."When we beat them three-nil in Queen Anne's, we knew it wasn't a three-nil game," O'Leary said of the Clippers' Sept. 30 game with Queen Anne's County.
Monday's rematch was much different, but still the Clippers came out on the winning end, as freshman Gracie Core's goal with 3 minutes, 8 seconds remaining lifted Bennett to its third consecutive Bayside Conference championship via a 3-2 victory over the Lions at Snow Hill High's Kelly Shumate Stadium.
"We expected that from Mike (Kern) and Jeff (Anthony)," O'Leary said of Queen Anne's head coach and assistant. "First minute they just were on top, and they were so aggressive. And we like that. And they made us fight for everything. You know what? That's the way it should be."
The first half ended with Bennett (13-0) in a place it had never been all year — trailing.
With not quite 2 minutes remaining, Queen Anne's Shannon Rath drove a direct kick that Clippers keeper Sophia Valenzano (six saves) dove to her left to make an initial save on. But the ball trickled to the right of Valenzano who was still on the ground when the Lions' Kara Ringold rushed in to knock in the game's first goal.
"We came out and we ended up getting that first goal in the first half," Kern said. "It's what we needed. It was very important because we've struggled scoring against the good teams this year. We've scored a lot of goals for the season, but (in) these big games we're having a tough time putting the ball in the back of the net. So getting that first goal was huge."
Queen Anne's goalie Bea Holthaus (seven saves) kept the Lions (9-3-1) in front early in the second half when she came out to intercept a corner kick headed near her goal line. But less than 3 minutes later, Holthaus made a sliding stop on Core, who quickly possessed the rebound and dished a short pass to Rilynn East for the tying goal.
Holthaus and Valenzano each made saves on corner kick 3 minutes apart.
Bennett transitioned downfield. Core came down the right side, was bumped by Queen Anne's Hayden Legg, managed to stay on her feet, and steered a shot past Holthaus into the left side for a 2-1 Bennett lead with 20:41 remaining in the game.
"Bennett's a strong team and we defended them well for most of the game," said Kern of a Clippers team that had outscored the opposition 82-3 this season.
Queen Anne's wasn't quite through though.
With 11:10 left, Madison Horney carried into the box, stumbled slightly through a tackle by Bennett's Taylor Matthews, then while falling, managed to get enough of her right foot on the ball to get it past Valenzano for a 2-2 tie. It was the first time Bennett had allowed two goals in game all season.
"We came back, hung tough," Kern said.
Queen Anne's came within inches of taking a lead when it banged shot off a corner went off the crossbar with 6:22 remaining.
The game appeared headed for overtime. But with the clock approaching the 3-minute mark, Core collected a ball that glanced off a defender, and from right wing, drove a left-footed shot into the left side of the net for the winning goal.
"I hope the crowd enjoyed it because it was a wonderful game," O'Leary said. "We got a little bit lucky in the end. They could have scored but the crossbar. But our super freshman (Core) went and scored a cracking goal at the end."
It was the Lions third straight loss to the Clippers in the championship game, yet Kern — who told his team afterwards "This was better than any practice we could have had," came away encouraged.
"Hit the crossbar on a corner kick and we had bad clear in the back and they capitalized on it," Kern said. "Proud of the girls. Proud how they played. The effort was there. And I think we can build from it moving into the playoffs."

 I don't believe in any of the superstitiousnonsense? thatseemsto be going aroundthese days. Some people have a fear of numbers like 13 and 666. What in the wor l ddoes anumberhavetodowith anything?Not being superstitious, there are times I am slightly confused about life. Something happens that I don't feel I'm in charge of.For example, the other morning, the gracious mistresslof the parsonage entered the living room, where I was sitting on myl easy chair drinking coffee. With alhuge smile, she said, "I got you an apple fritter for this morning." And she gave it to me, smiled at me and then walked away.The following day, I got up and got my coffee, went out to my easy chair in the living room, and started to sip it very carefully.As I was getting situated, the gracious mistress of the parsonage walked in, and I saw in her hand another apple fritter.Again, I got up the following day, went and got my coffee, and sat in my easy chair. In a few mo me nts, in walks lthe grfccio Bs mistress of the parsonage, and in her hand is another apple fritter."Here's an apple fritter for you this morning. I think you'll enjoy it today." She smiled at me, turned around, and returned to the kitc hen.It's not that I can't handle an apple fritter because I can. It's the fact that someone is bringing these apple fritters to me who does not like apple fritters. Something is happening behind the scenes, and I'm anxious to find o ut.The next day, the same thing happened. Now I'm getting to be suspicious. What in the world am I missing here?Not wanting to sabotage my good luck the last four days, I kept silent and enjoyed the fritter. Whatever is behind this, I may never know, but I w ill enjoy it for whatever it is worth.I couldn't help thinking of a Bible verse, "And let us not be weary in well doing: for in due season we shall reap, if we faint not" (Galatians 6:9).Sometimes, the best thing to do is NOTHING and let God have it.Dr. James L. title: Said before, but rarely

Said before, but rarely

 November 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 10A | Section: News

 Who wrote: "Nothing has yet been said that's not been said before."?Today's critical suit combination has appeared in print before, but only rarely. Most players get it wrong. Without peeking at the East-West hands, how would you play the club suit for at most one loser in notrump?North's sequence showed four hearts, at least five clubs and game-going values or more. He announced the "or more" when leaping to six no-trump on round three.South starts with 10 top tricks: two spades, four hearts, two diamonds and two clubs. Clearly, he can afford one club loser but not two. All plays work if the missing clubs are divided 3-2. So you must maximize your chances against a 4-1 break.It looks normal to play the club king and another club, winning when East has the singleton nine, jack or queen.However, there is a better play. You should win the diamond lead with dummy's ace and immediately call for the club 10! If East plays the two or three, you play low. If East plays the nine or an honor, you win with the king and return a club, planning to cover West's card.This line works whenever East has the singleton nine, jack or queen, and when West has the singleton nine.The opening sentence was penned by Terence, a second-century B.C.Roman comic poet who wrote in remarkably pure Latin. In 1649, England's King Charles I was executed for high treason.
In 1933, Adolf Hitler was named chancellor of Germany.
In 1945, during World War II, a Soviet submarine torpedoed the German ship MV Wilhelm Gustloff in the Baltic Sea, killing over 9,000, most of them war refugees; roughly 1,000 people survived.
In 1968, the Tet Offensive began during the Vietnam War as Communist forces launched surprise attacks against South Vietnamese towns and cities.
In 1969, The Beatles staged an unannounced concert atop Apple headquarters in London that would be their last public performance.
In 1972, 13 Catholic civil rights marchers were shot and killed by British soldiers in Northern Ireland on what became known as "Bloody Sunday."
In 2017, President Donald Trump fired Acting U.S. Attorney General Sally Yates after she publicly questioned the constitutionality of his controversial refugee and immigration ban and refused to defend it in court.
