author: Konner Metz
content:
Multiple crashes at Easton intersection lead to resident concerns

 February 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 630
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A recent string of crashes at the intersection of Brookletts Avenue and South Aurora Street have ignited resident calls for traffic and safety improvements.Monday morning, residents Lydia Pinkney and Tony Ruffini stood on the sidewalk of Aurora Street, discussing their safety concerns for the residential area that is home to many families and children.
"You stand out here for about five, ten minutes, you'll see how fast people go," Ruffini said. "It's insane. They don't care, and they're always in a hurry."
According to the Easton Police Department, the intersection has seen three crashes this month, all due to driver error. There were only 13 in the last 11 years, police said.
Town engineers reviewed the traffic light, which was confirmed as operational. In a Facebook post, the police department encouraged drivers to be cautious and stated the intersection will be monitored.
"While this location is being monitored, officers have begun targeted traffic enforcement and will continue to do so at different hours of the day," the department wrote.
Pinkney said she's worried for the safety of her 9-year-old daughter and her dog when walking up and down Aurora Street near the intersection. She says a car has careened into her yard before, and many neighbors have had their parked cars damaged.
Pinkney believes part of the issue is drivers may be unaware it is a residential area.
"The speed limit's 25, and I know people are going more than 25," she said. "Our kids play out here. And what worries me about everything is if … someone's not paying attention or whatnot, them running the red light or just going way too fast and clipping me and my daughter."
Town Engineer Rick Van Emburgh said the town is looking at what it can do with the intersection's traffic light in terms of safety and timing.
Easton's engineers recently adjusted the timing of the intersection's traffic light, hoping to lower the "chances of a collision if a driver attempts to beat a red light," the Easton Police Department announced Tuesday.
Discussion around safety on Brookletts Avenue has been recurring. This month, the town installed four-way stop signs at two other Brookletts intersections, South Harrison Street and Hanson Street. The intersections previously had two stop signs each.
Van Emburgh said thus far, feedback on the four-way stop signs has been positive. Resident Lisa Stone lives next to the intersections and said she's happy with the change.
"I have seen so many near accidents at the intersections, particularly Hanson and Brookletts," Stone said. " … I think that's a good improvement."
The town also added on-street parking lines to Brookletts Avenue, a measure that Van Emburgh said will improve safety on the wide, two-way street.
"The white lines give the drivers cues as to where they're supposed to be in the travel lanes," Van Emburgh said. "Because one of the things that we struggle with is when you have a road that can accommodate on-street parking, but no one's actually parking on it, it looks like a wide-open raceway."
For many neighbors, traffic and safety concerns only grow as developers revamp a nearby property formerly owned by Perdue AgriBusiness. Last week, Easton's Planning Commission approved the majority of a 123-unit proposal for the site along Brookletts Avenue.
Developers had Lenhart Traffic Consulting prepare a traffic impact study, which recommended project approval. Per Planning Commission documents, the study found redevelopment will have "minimal impact on the surrounding road network."
Ruffini said with the new development and an eventual increase in traffic, South Aurora Street "will be a main road before you know it."
Stone, meanwhile, is excited to see the redevelopment, given it includes commercial space and affordable housing. But she's keeping an eye on its impacts to driver and pedestrian safety.
"Hopefully it will just be an increase in traffic and not a decrease in safety," Stone said.

 This month, in community centers, libraries, schools and churches like Bethel AME Church in Centreville, when citizens gather to honor the nation's greatest champions for freedom, justice and equal rights, they also honor the people.In 1915, the historian Dr. Carter G. Woodson founded what is now the Association for the Study of African American Life and History. The following year, he began publishing what is now The Journal of African American History, a publication of history, research and book reviews.
In 1926, Woodson founded "Negro History Week" to honor the history, culture and contributions of African Americans. He chose February to coincide with the birthdays of Frederick Douglass and Abraham Lincoln. In 1976, President Gerald Ford extended the observation to a month, now known as Black History Month.
Woodson believed that history was "made by the people, not simply or primarily by great men."
Local writer, Niambi Davis had the opportunity to contribute to the Black History display at Bethel AME. The subjects, Davis said, "are important and more than just the usual Douglass and Tubman stories; they're the unknown local, national and international folks."
The display is open to the congregation and anyone wishing to attend services. Service begins at 11 a.m. Sunday mornings. The church is located on Washington Road in Centreville.

title: Branson and Perez vie for Denton council seat
author: Tom McCall
content:
Branson and Perez vie for Denton council seat

 October 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 915
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Two candidates have qualified to run in Denton's upcoming Town Council election. They are Lester L. Branson and Angel L. Perez.Branson is 82 and Perez is 38. Perez is the program and events manager for the Chesapeake Culinary Center and the CEO and founder of Caroline Pride. Branson is an optometrist on Market Street.
The winner will serve a five-year term. The election will be held the same day as the general election, Nov. 5, at the Denton Town Office, located at 4 N. Second St. The polls will be open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m.
The Star Democrat spoke to both candidates ahead of the election. Their answers to the paper's questions can be found below.
WHAT IS YOUR POLITICAL EXPERIENCE?Perez: "Here on the Shore, I served as community outreach/Main Street coordinator for the Town of Greensboro. I presented best practices at statewide Maryland Municipal League Conference in my talk titled, 'Partnering for Progress: Municipalities and Community Organizations Working Together,' where elected officials and municipal staff learned about developing partnerships between municipalities and community organizations is critical to providing quality services to a shared constituency. In addition to this Maryland political experience, I also bring fresh ideas from serving as district assistant for a city council in Massachusetts. We created a communication bridge between residents and the City Council and community programs."
Perez went on to list leadership positions he has held with 19 boards and organizations on the Eastern Shore in the past 10 years.
Branson: "I have been mayor five times and on the board for 38 years. So I know everything you want to know."
WHAT MAKES YOU THE BEST CANDIDATE FOR THE POSITION?Branson: "The biggest thing is I have been doing this for 38 years and I know the ins and outs of everything."
Perez: "Over the past 10 years I have dedicated myself to working tirelessly to be part of the solution. I come to run as a candidate to bring people together, connecting with our community and impacting it in a positive way, especially through the creation of different local programs for youth and families. Having the ability to make decisions based on knowledge and data not assumptions, making decisions that benefit everyone in our town. Direct contact with all the different kinds of residents in Denton and knowledge of the situations that our community has, especially our elderly, youth and small business owners. Being able to bring new ideas and perspectives and new ways to help our town grow."
WHY ARE YOU RUNNING?Branson: "I am running because there is a lot of things I'd like to get done. And the five of us, right now, for the last few years, we work so sweetly together, and there is no rift or anything like that. We really get things done for the town of Denton and the citizens of Denton. I am hoping to keep that going."
Perez: "My home, the Town of Denton, has always had a special place in my heart, and I can serve better our community as part of the Town Council. I want to continue to work for my community in a respectful and equitable manner and help our town move towards the future with strong economic growth while maintaining our small town charm."
WHAT CHANGE WOULD YOU LIKE TO SEE IN THE NEXT FIVE YEARS?Perez: "I will actively listen to small business owners to develop solutions together. Also, I will provide support and assistance to the downtown Main Street office to combine efforts to protect and preserve our local businesses. We should keep property taxes low and water costs affordable for all... Our town is full of history and art. The Town Council can create collaborations with organizations that showcase art and history in our town is essential to expand, promote, and highlight the arts and history district in our town by providing them with the necessary support. Thus, making our town, art and history enjoyed by visitors and citizens... For the past 10 years, my work has been focused on seeking the well-being and impacting our youth in a positive way through different programs and community services. As a council member, I will seek to create collaborations and build bridges of communication with different organizations to create, promote and expand programs that help our young people reach their full potential."
Branson: "See the change from the social service building. I really want to see the road to nowhere from Walmart over to 404 is going to be called Commerce Drive. It has gone from $1 million to $3 million to build the road. I really want us to cut taxes again this year. I hope there is a way to get this road money to help with the taxes and not have to double tax the people in town. I am looking for any way that we can make it better for affordable housing for people in Denton... Another big thing is that we are looking with the county, they are going to have to build another middle school. There is a possibility that where Caroline County High School is that there is land to do that out there. In the future, are they going to keep the middle school there or put it somewhere else in Denton or are they going to go out to North Caroline and put it there? ... Another thing is to build water and sewer out in west Denton. There are a lot of houses where their septic systems are going out."

 The recent passing of Treat Williams makes a viewing of "Hair" bittersweet now, but director Milos Forman's 1979 screen version of the hit stage musical is very much worth seeing for the amazing energy that the Vietnam War-era project retains in the transition from live theater to film with Williams' memorable performance no small part of that.MGM+ presents the movie Thursday, Aug. 24.The actor plays Berger, the leader of a band of New York hippies - and a very strong influence on a military draftee (John Savage) who begins to second-guess his plans for a relatively conservative future after being exposed to the very free lifestyle of his new acquaintances. Beverly D'Angelo, Annie Golden and Melba Moore also are in the cast of the picture, which boasts songs that became iconic - including the title tune, "Aquarius," "Let the Sunshine In" and "Good Morning Starshine." "The Idolmaker" (Paramount+ With Showtime, streaming): Director Taylor Hackford's fabulous 1980 drama-with-music is informed by great original tunes and the excellent acting of Ray Sharkey as a would-be songwriter who becomes a self-styled late-1950s talent manager, transforming a naive restaurant worker (Peter Gallagher, also superb, in his movie debut) into a teen idol named Caesare. With success comes strife, though, as the new star becomes overwhelmed by sudden fame. Tovah Feldshuh, Joe Pantoliano and Maureen McCormick (yes, TV's Marcia Brady) also appear.

 QUEENSTOWN — With the recreational use of cannabis legalized, and following requirements being set in place by the State, towns are now working to put forth local regulations to address its use.Queenstown is one of such municipalities detailing outlines in their zoning ordinance for prospective retail and businesses regulations to follow.
The Queenstown Planning Commission's original proposal permitted sites or sales processing to be on the south side of Route 301.
Queenstown certainly has regulations in place for medical marijuana but not for recreational use, Town Manager Amy Moore said.
The Planning Commission recently brought forward an amendment that would limit dispensaries to the north side of town, to infill properties only, according to Town Attorney Lyndsey Ryan.
Similar to current liquor laws to protect children and compromised individuals, the commission originally proposed a blanket 500-foot setback buffer of dispensaries from areas such as schools, libraries and children centers. The council approved sending the dispensary requirement proposal back to the planning commission to revise and reword the intention.
The council noted through communication with the Town of Centreville and discussion with the Queen Anne's Sheriff's Office, since May 2022, the retail cannabis locations in Centreville have not had any notable crime or problems related to cannabis.
In other business, noting rising food costs, during public comment resident Paris Wells expressed interest in changing the town's ordinance to allow for chickens.
Wells noted the benefit of raising chickens as food in the garage and suggested allowances to the town's current ordinance forbidding feathered fowl.
The town's current ordinance against chickens has been in place for decades, but if a petition with 50 percent of residents' support came forward, the council may consider amendments, Commissioner President Alton Hardee said.
The Queenstown Town Commissioners will next meet March 27 at 6 p.m.

title: Museum of Rural Life offers a glimpse into Caroline County's past
author: LINDA EVANS Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Museum of Rural Life offers a glimpse into Caroline County's past

 April 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LINDA EVANS Special to the Star Democrat | Section: News 
 
 428
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Museum of Rural Life brings history to life in a unique way, educating and fascinating young and old with sentimental memories of a beloved county."Representatives of the Smithsonian Institute toured our museum," said museum Director Cathy Spence, "and it was praised for its depiction of housing and heritage in early Caroline County history."
Caroline County celebrated its 250th anniversary March 15 at the Museum of Rural Life, which opened in 1993. The museum is a loving tribute to the late JOK Walsh, president of the Caroline County Historical Society, whose vision helped define the museum.
The Museum of Rural Life offers visitors a rare glimpse into life on the rural Eastern Shore through historic dwellings, which have been preserved and converted into museum space by the historical society.
Among the preserved structures is the Annie Taylor, or Taylor-Brown, House, which was built for merchant-broker Solomon Brown in 1819 and later owned by the Taylors, an African American family.
"JOK Walsh's vision for the Annie Taylor House was to show the assets of our county, to instill pride in the Village Green where homes like Annie Taylor, one of the two oldest homes in Denton, was built and renovated," said Cathy Schwab, president of the Ridgely Historical Society.
"How wonderful to be able to walk the Village Green, to stop in a business located in a renovated home, have candlelight walks at Christmas and to promote tourism and economic development," she continued.
And the historical society has plans to convert other structures into educational spaces as well.
Current president Charles Andrew said that the repurposing of the old Denton Volunteer Fire House, which was first built in 1927, as a Heritage Center will allow the structure to become the County's hub to direct visitors to tour Federalsburg, Greensboro, Preston and Ridgely museums; Milling at Linchester Mill; the Underground Railroad story at the historical society's restored JOK Webb log cabin and Wm Still cottage; and the Ridgely Train Station.
At the Museum of Rural Life, exhibits feature personal details of those who have called Caroline County home over several centuries, from models of steamboats that used to traverse local rivers to the wedding dress of JOK Walsh's mother Mary Ann Walsh.
Historical Society Vice President Rick Schwab said, "history in Caroline County is always spoken here, making the community aware of its beginnings."
The Rural Life Museum is open Saturdays from March through November from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m.
"We encourage you to visit the wealth of information and the grandeur of presentation," said Historical Society Treasurer Carolyn Spicher.
For more information, call 410-479-2055 or visit Carolinehistory.org.

 Q: Someone told me that Julianne Moore started her career on a soap opera. Is that true?A: Yes two of them, in fact. Soon afterward, she joined "As the World Turns," playing the dual roles of Frannie Hughes and her look-alike relative Sabrina. She earned a Daytime Emmy Award for her work on that show, which she did continuously from 1985 to 1988; she then made a return appearance in 2010.
Moore began doing primetime TV parts during her "As the World Turns" run, notably opposite Valerie Bertinelli in the 1987 miniseries "I'll Take Manhattan," then she was hired for TV-movies including "Money, Power, Murder" and "The Last to Go." Around the same time, she also moved into theatrical films with "Tales From the Darkside: The Movie" and "The Hand That Rocks the Cradle," and that became her principal venue from the early 1990s forward, with her eventual win of an Academy Award for best actress for "Still Alice" (2014).
After doing guest stints along the way on "Saturday Night Live" and "Sesame Street," Moore made a particularly significant return to TV by playing former Alaska governor and vice-presidential candidate Sarah Palin in the 2012 HBO project "Game Change."  Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 3.7 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $2.91 per gallon on Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland.Prices in Maryland are 26.5 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 18.5 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has declined 1.8 cents in the last week and stands at $3.472 per gallon.
According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.63 per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $3.79 per gallon, a difference of $1.16 per gallon.
The falling prices may be coming to an end.
"As we edge closer to the end of the year, we're seeing momentum for falling gas prices weaken, which is typical as the national average generally bottoms out between Thanksgiving and Christmas," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "With oil prices rising back above $70 last week, gas prices may have less potential to drop much further, though there may be a second window of lower prices in January or February in some areas, but even that won't last long."
The national average price of gasoline has risen 0.8 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $2.98 per gallon today. The national average is down 7.5 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 7.1 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.

title: Towns need to balance pride in past with future
author: BRANDON WRIGHT
content:
Towns need to balance pride in past with future

 May 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BRANDON WRIGHT | Section: Columns 
 
 805
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Recently, I listened to a webinar about the challenges of planning, land use and economic development in rural areas. Communities frequently struggle to grow and still maintain their character. Balancing economic growth with the community's heritage is among the most significant challenges for elected officials because the two are often intertwined.An industry of consultants has grown up to help communities meet these challenges. Like the consultants, I believe a balance can be reached.
Maybe I am too much of an optimist, but I think opposing groups can find common ground if they are honest and transparent. I served as chief of staff in the Maryland Department of Planning nearly 10 years ago. I met with town council members, county commissioners and local business leaders, all vested in making their communities strong and vibrant. My confidence comes from listening to their hopes, dreams and goals for their communities.
I met with the consultants, too. Everyone wanted the same for the community — the absolute best.
Compromises that are in the best interests of all the various constituencies and stakeholders can be forged, even in rural Maryland like the Eastern Shore. There is no place like it. Its ecosystems and economies are different, even from other rural parts of the state. So much of the economy is dependent on the Chesapeake Bay and the rivers that feed into it. It is teeming with myriad species of animals on land and sea.
The motto of Federalsburg, my hometown in Caroline County, is "Pride in the Past, Faith in the Future." Unfortunately in towns like Federalsburg, more emphasis is placed on the past than the future. Local officials, sometimes pressured by citizens, have these gauzy memories of a better time and place in the community's past and yearn to get back to it.
However, in doing so, they strip decision-makers of any chance at finding the right balance between the past and future, choking off opportunities to attract large employers, employees and all the businesses that spring up to support them both.
As a young boy, I fished for bass and perch on the Marshyhope Creek, the northwest fork of the Nanticoke River. I heard the story that the DuPont Company was looking to build its new nylon factory in the area, and the Marshyhope Creek made Federalsburg an attractive site. Unfortunately, DuPont built its nylon plant on the Nanticoke River in Seaford, Delaware, less than 10 miles from Federalsburg. The plant was constructed outside the town, and Seaford quickly became a company town. The contrast between the two towns is dramatic.
Federalsburg missed out again, this time on AquaCon. An international salmon farming operation would have brought several hundred well-paying jobs, jobs with health care and all the other benefits that help smooth the rough edges of life. AquaCon would have increased revenue to the town, support for existing small businesses and all the different services that make a small town tick.
Town officials, under pressure from citizens, said no to this opportunity. Rather than work with the company to better understand the project and address concerns, the town leaders said no and now another community will benefit from these jobs and the economic development that comes with it.
According to state data, Caroline County is among the most economically depressed counties in Maryland. We can't lay all the blame at the feet of elected leaders for that. I know many of them, and each one cares deeply for the communities they serve; otherwise, they wouldn't do it. The blame, however, should be shared with the voters that elected them and the voters who pushed the elected leaders to say no to investments in the towns that would spur economic growth over fears of the unknown and fears of something different, a break from the past.
Because the citizens share the blame, they are responsible for turning their communities around.
Our rural communities are blessed with resources that other towns and cities envy. We have kind, friendly people who care for each other. We have the greatest renewable resource of all — an unending stream of smart and talented young men and women graduating from our high schools and colleges, prepared to make the world a better place. Let's do everything we can to keep them here.
Let our legacy be that we found that balance that everyone strives for and leave the next generation and the generations that follow a community poised for growth, good jobs and continued access to outstanding education. Let's be sure we live up to the motto, "Pride in the Past, Faith in the Future."
Brandon Wright grew up in Federalsburg and graduated from Colonel Richardson High School in 1997 and Salisbury University in 2001. He was the chief of staff at the Maryland Department of Planning from 2015 to 2017. He now lives in Annapolis, but his family still resides just outside of Federalsburg.

title: Residents get update on Cambridge flood mitigation project
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Residents get update on Cambridge flood mitigation project

 August 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 587
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The City of Cambridge held the first of what it says will be multiple "periodic" public meetings to share progress and get feedback on its flood mitigation project along the shore of the Choptank River.The city's Make Cambridge Resilient Flood Mitigation Project Manager Larry White said the city will continue to reach out to the public throughout the entire design process of the project.
"This is the kickoff," he said. "There'll be other meetings where we get you up to date on what's transpired and what's come out of our studies."
The presentation, which was held at the Cambridge branch of the Dorchester County Public Library on Aug. 21, brought many residents who had questions about how the project, which will stretch from Gerry Boyle Park at Great Marsh to the mouth of Cambridge Creek, will affect their properties and the city in general.
The plan for the project includes three main elements: a living shoreline, earth and rock embankments and stormwater management to alleviate flooding.
The city is funding the two-phase project through the grants from the Federal Emergency Management Agency, a grant from the Maryland Department of Natural Resources, the Resilient Maryland Revolving Loan Fund and city budget funds. In June, it announced that the FEMA had awarded the city $1.7 million for the first phase of the project.
The city said FEMA is also reserving $16 million for the second phase of the project. The total $17.7 million in grant money is being awarded through FEMA's Hazard Mitigation Assistance grant.
During the meeting, representatives from the city, the state, the University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science at Horn Point, and BayLand Consultants and Designers spoke about climate change, flooding and the project itself.
Maryland Secretary of Emergency Management Russell Strickland talked about the importance of mitigating disasters prior to them occurring. He said mitigation cuts down on the need for response and on the costs associated with recovery.
"So this would be what I would call a transformative mitigation project for the city," he said. "And it's important that it be projects like that because that will have a greater result and a greater benefit for more people."
Horn Point Lab professor Ming Li talked about sea level rise across the Chesapeake Bay and increases in flooding. He said working with nature can be better than fighting with it.
"So that's why there's a lot of interest in a lot of places all around the world to look at nature-based solutions," he said.
Megan Barniea, a BayLand senior project engineer, said no design decisions have been made yet, but the plan is to build upon those three main project elements of a living shoreline, embankments and stormwater management.
Horn Point Lab, which is supporting the project, will help to optimize the living shoreline design, assess flood risk reduction, monitor living shoreline performance and evaluate ecological co-benefits of the project.
Barniea said the project partners will be coming back to the public to get feedback on a 30% design plan. The plan, which she expects will be ready to show in early 2025, will include the footprint of proposed features, elevations and dimensions, and a construction cost estimate.
After the presentation, residents asked questions about the project, including how the project will affect private docks and public access to the waterfront.
White said the city and its partners will work with each property owner, and residents will keep access to their docks. He said there will be some public access to the living shoreline.
"I mean it can't be everywhere, but there will be access," he said.

title: Cambridge man found guilty of child abuse, assault
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Cambridge man found guilty of child abuse, assault

 December 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime 
 
 519
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A Cambridge man has been found guilty of first-degree assault and first-degree child abuse relating to an incident with his infant.Marcus Peak, 28, was arrested in April 2023 after his five-week-old child was seriously injured with a traumatic brain injury. He was charged with attempted first- and second-degree murder, first- and second-degree assault, first- and second-degree child abuse, neglect of a minor and reckless endangerment.
The state later decided it would not prosecute for the murder charges. Peak was found guilty by Dorchester County Circuit Court Judge William Jones of the other six counts.
The charges against Peak stem from an incident on April 21, 2023, when Cambridge Police officers responded to assist Dorchester County Emergency Medical Services with an infant who was unconscious and not breathing. EMS treated the infant and transported her to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Cambridge. The baby was then transported to Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore.
According to police, Peak told detectives he had just fed the baby a bottle and placed her in a bassinet for a nap. He said the baby was asleep. He said that when he returned to check on the her later, he noticed the baby's head was tilted to the side with fluid coming from her nose and mouth. He said the baby's eyes were partially opened.
At that time, Peak denied any traumatic event that could have caused injury to the baby.
Detectives were told Peak had lied and did not inform them that the baby had fallen to the floor striking her head. Peak allegedly then picked the baby up and shook the baby to wake it, according to a report from the Cambridge Police Department.
During the trial, Jones heard a variety of testimony, including testimony from doctors and the child's mother.
The mother, Paris Keene, testified that she had left the house that day to pick up their older child from daycare. She said Peak had stayed with the their five-week-old. She said that when she came back, Peak told her the infant had choked on her spit up.
When Keene took the baby from Peak, she realized that the baby's eyes were rolling back, and Peak called 911.
Dr. Eric Klotz, an emergency medicine physician who treated the child that day, said her injuries were consistent with a high mechanism of injury. He said it was one of the more severe head injuries he's seen in his career.
Dr. Joseph Scheller, a pediatric neurologist who was asked by Peak's defense to testify, said it is possible the child's injuries were caused by an accidental fall. He said that while it is rare, short falls can sometimes cause serious injury.
"I am thankful for the judge's consideration," Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard told the Star Democrat. "He gave a very well thought out explanation citing case law and it was obvious that he took significant time to consider the evidence put forth by the state, including expert testimony and other evidence."
Leonard said that a "long form" pre-sentence investigation will be conducted, which may take multiple months. As of Friday afternoon, no sentencing date for Peak was scheduled.

author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Kids show their skills at the Talbot County Fair

 July 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News

 EASTON — The Talbot County Fair celebrated its 41st annual event this week. Hundreds of residents came together to experience the various activities put together by organizers, volunteers and sponsors.The five-day celebration included events such as fashion shows, games, bouncy castles and vendors. Many of these events were hosted for young people with an interest in leadership, community service, arts and agriculture.
The opening ceremony was held on Thursday evening, kids held flags at the center of the Main Show Ring, Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) presented a citation of recognition to organizers of the fair and John Coleman, officer from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, sang "God Bless America."
Linda Brown, host of the opening ceremony, said in the past, Talbot County had to share its fair with other counties because of how small the county was. Today, Brown is proud of the work that the community does to make the fair possible.
"The big thing about this fair is that our community comes together," Brown said. "(I) couldn't count the volunteers that come and do their piece. It could be shavings in a cow barn so that we can have animals. It could be taking a leaf blower and blowing the leaves out of our pavilion. Everybody just jumps in and works together to put on this amazing fair."
Brown said she is proud of the work done by children and young people across the county, which was on full display at the fair.
This included the work of her granddaughter Annette Clougherty, who brought three of her cows for show this year.
Clougherty, 12, said she has deep love for animals and hopes to one day become a veterinarian. Her cows, Reba, Andy and Dolly huddled near a giant fan to cool off from the hot weather.
Clougherty encourages any kid who has an interest in animals to raise the animal of their choice and bring them to a local fair.
"Do your research, learn and don't just chase your dreams so you can get the money and be done with it," she said. "Actually get into it because these guys (her cows), I don't ever imagine them going to the market, they're always mine in my heart."
Clougherty is proud to announce that she is taking her cows to Queen Anne's Fair, which is a big step for her family.
In a different stall, Bailei Caldeira, a young pig farmer, brushed her two pigs before a showing. It is her second year showing her pigs, and she said she is better prepared to make an impression. Caldeira said she has always loved pigs.
When asked what advice she would give to kids who would like to raise pigs, she said working hard is the key to caring for pigs.
"Don't be scared, just do it," Caldeira said. "Don't care about anyone else. Just care about your pig and you."
Following the animal showing, dozens of kids from all age groups showcased their self-created outfits during the Talbot County 4-H Fashion Show.
The 4-H program is a local club teaching kids new skills, such as sewing, photography and more. Each kid had a moment to shine as dozens of parents took photos and cheered for their stylish outfits.
Brown, a former home economics teacher, said she was so proud of all the work that the young contestant did for this year's show. For her, as host of the fashion show, she is impressed by the 27 outfits being modeled in the show and the work of the volunteers who make the event possible.
"It's just a culmination of hundreds of people working together and everybody doing their part in order to come up with this little event," Brown said. "We are not a big state fair. We don't have squeaky rides and all that. We're not big enough, but we have people in the community that just come out and enjoy, socialize, marvel at what the kids are doing."

 Eastern Shore business owners are encouraged to participate in a free, first-of-its-kind artificial intelligence online training series for local businesses this fall.The two-part online program takes place Oct. 27–28 from 6 to 8 p.m. via Zoom and marks the first time the economic development departments of Dorchester, Caroline, Talbot and Worcester counties, along with the Mid-Shore Regional Council, have partnered on a training initiative of this kind.

title: Watermen oppose striped bass cuts, urge status quo at Chesapeake College forum
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Watermen oppose striped bass cuts, urge status quo at Chesapeake College forum

 September 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 1084
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS — Eastern Shore watermen packed Chesapeake College on Monday and overwhelmingly opposed draft striped bass rules that would trim total removals by 12 percent in 2026 and could add more closures.The public hearing — organized by the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission and the Maryland Department of Natural Resources — drew more than 100 people, including county commissioners, council members and state delegates. By a show of hands, virtually every attendee opposed any change to current rules.
At issue is Draft Addendum III, the Fisheries Commission's proposal to support rebuilding the East Coast striped bass stock by 2029. The action seeks to reduce fishery removals by 12 percent beginning in 2026. For the commercial sector, the draft proposes a quota cut; for the recreational sector, it considers season closures and/or size-limit changes.
It also contemplates requirements for commercial tagging programs, a coastwide definition of total length for size-limit compliance, and changes to Maryland's recreational baseline season to simplify rules, improve enforcement and better align fishing access with release mortality and stakeholder input.
The Commission intends to take final action no later than October, with most measures implemented in 2026.
"Tonight is a way for the members on the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission to hear your concerns," said Mike Luisi, an associate director with the Maryland Department of Natural Resources' Fishing and Boating Services and a member of the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission. He later added: "The plan is to get the striped bass healthier so we can [return] to additional quotas in light of having a healthier population. That's the truth. It is to provide for a better stock so we can provide more quota back to the commercial industry and [lighten] restrictions on the recreational industry. For those who say we do not take the watermen's advice, we do a spring spawning stock assessment where watermen take us out on their routine."
Emilie Franke, a fishery management plan coordinator for the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission, walked the audience through the options, including a potential allowance for catch-and-release during part of the spring — a period that has been closed in recent years to protect spawning fish. That drew a sharp reaction.
"Catch-and-release will be on spawning grounds," said Brian Hardman, president of the Maryland Charter Boat Association. "How could you push this through knowing this information?"
Franke said striped bass–specific research about catch-and-release effects on spawning — such as impacts on egg production or pre-spawn behavior — is limited. "The research is inconclusive," she said, noting the technical committee is working to incorporate environmental factors into models where appropriate.
Speakers repeatedly pressed the agencies on data and modeling. Hardman questioned the federal Marine Recreational Information Program estimates. "The MRIP data that they use is off by about 40 percent," he said. "Maybe the numbers you are trying to hit are so artificially high we will never get there."
Delmarva Fisheries Association President Rob Newberry cited a Maryland study from the late 1990s to argue release mortality is higher than assumed. "There's 200 years of data you people have flagrantly not paid attention to," he said, urging the state and the Fisheries Commission to complete socioeconomic and pollution analyses before tightening rules. "Start using good science — it's there."
Robert T. Brown, president of the Maryland Watermen's Association, said the draft's rebuilding target is unrealistic. "You all are wrong that they put the target so high," Brown said. "You can only go so far until it is out of reach. You can't maintain it. When it comes to it, we've got so many rockfish out there now. The big fish are there, the small fish [are] coming back."
Elected officials echoed the industry's frustration. "Send this back, rework it," said State Sen. Johnny Mautz. "The reality of how this plays out is it is overburdening our local economy. Last year's impact from two fish to one fish was catastrophic."
Dorchester County Council member Mike Detmer said the draft has eroded trust. "I am deeply concerned about the 12 percent cut," he said. "What I hear is a lack of confidence in the board. The watermen are the most concerned to have a robust fishery. We have to protect this magical resource."
Wicomico County Council member James Winn urged the agencies to look beyond fishermen for causes. "Are we the issue?" he asked. "Could it be a menhaden fleet up in Virginia catching more than just menhaden? Have you done studies on other industries affecting the fish? Maybe we should be restricting what they're doing — not what we're doing."
Talbot Watermen's Association President Jeff Harrison said stricter rules have hollowed out traditional working communities. "When I ran charter there were about 40 [charter boats] on Tilghman," he said. "Right now there are three. It's hard to call it a fishing village anymore."
Del. Jay Jacobs called spring catch-and-release "the wrong direction," arguing it contradicts prior steps to protect broodstock. "It's an unscientific position to take without knowing the damage it's caused," he said. "We're here to maintain a historic livelihood."
Several speakers described the proposal as a choice between the status quo and more closures, with some options allowing spring catch-and-release. Many said they prefer no change. "Why haven't you considered giving us 12 percent back instead of taking?" asked waterman Dan Dierker. "Start talking to people who pay the most to fish, who have the most to lose. Stop listening to the wrong people like the CCA (Coastal Conservation Association).
Veteran Kent County waterman Don Pierce said cumulative quota cuts are pushing families out of the business. "I've been doing this for 60-plus years," he said. "You come in for one day, trying to run this industry. … Had a 12,000-pound quota when this all started. When you're done with this one, I'll have seven. Take a 50 percent cut in your salary, see how long you sit there."
Luisi said the Maryland baseline season concept grew out of feedback from many quarters — including watermen — and that nothing has been finalized for 2026. "We heard that it would be in Maryland's best interest to try to drive the economy," he said. "These changes weren't meant to harm anyone. They were meant to try to offset different times of the year."
What's next: The Fisheries Commission is scheduled to consider Draft Addendum III later this fall in Annapolis, with final action expected no later than October 2025 and implementation in 2026. Commercial tagging requirements, if adopted, could take longer to roll out. Maryland's DNR said it would carry comments from Monday's forum to the board.

title: Trump’s return has these conservative Latinos excited
author: ROBERT STEWART Capital News Service
content:
Trump’s return has these conservative Latinos excited

 November 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ROBERT STEWART Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 817
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ROCKVILLE — Juan Leo Salazar is on a mission to awaken a dormant political power in Maryland — the state's conservative-leaning Latinos.He has compiled a list of 28,000 names he believes he can galvanize for conservative causes. He says his organization of Maryland Latino Republicans has roughly 300 paying members.
He and many of his conservative friends had been working and keeping their heads down, he said. Now they're not afraid of sharing their views, he said, despite possible criticism and even retaliation.
"Now that Trump is in," Salazar said, "nobody's afraid."
Exit poll data on Latino voters had some analysts' heads spinning. Nationwide, 46% of this group voted for Donald Trump in the general election.
But that turnout for Trump was not surprising for some Latino Republicans like Salazar. He and others had watched the ways people in their networks were responding to the Biden-Harris administration and saw the writing on the wall.
Salazar, who came to the area in the late 60s, has many thoughts on how Trump will benefit folks in Maryland.
To start, he praised Trump's promise to cut taxes on tips and overtime as a win for the working-class Latino community.
"Now with the tips, no tax on tips. That is wonderful," he said, "you should see how the Latino community, Hispanics, are so happy about (that)."
He also thinks the Republican victory can help improve cultural issues conservatives care about at the state level.
Connected with Latino Republicans across six counties in Maryland through his organization, Salazar has a good sense of how politically transformative the issue of parental input into school curricula is. He believes it unifies many minority immigrant groups in the state. This, he said, could change the state's political map.
"If those (other) minority groups can get organized … with chapters in different counties," he said, "I'm sure we can turn this state at least orange."
But to strengthen the Republican hand in a state overwhelmingly run by Democrats, you need friends.
Alirio Martinez is one of Salazar's friends in that mission.
Martinez, 50, lives in Easton with his wife Ann and their six cats. Outside of his entrepreneurial work — the two have an online business — Martinez enjoys connecting with fellow partisans.
The two men met this October outside of an early-voting polling precinct in eastern Montgomery County. Martinez was in the area and wanted to see if his buddy was canvassing. Salazar happened to have a table set up there, where he was doing outreach to the Latino community.
Martinez said there are a number of reasons why he's hopeful that Trump's return to Washington could help Latinos in the state.
"I tell people it's about what's going on, they're hurting people's pockets big time," Martinez said. "They're seeing the price of the eggs, the milk … the gas."
Martinez, who went as a Republican delegate to the Republican National Convention in 2016, said he can remember the time under Trump when his favorite sandwich cost him $5 and when gas prices were more affordable. Things changed under Biden, he believes. "Everything," he said, "started going up."
International politics also plays a role. The two presidential candidates took different stances on the president of El Salvador, Nayib Bukele. Where Trump embraced the so-called "world's coolest dictator," Harris expressed concerns about a decline in the country's democratic institutions.
Martinez said that many Salvadorans, who comprise the largest foreign-born population in Maryland, were disgruntled with what they perceived as Harris attacking a national hero. He said Bukele has done an amazing job of fighting crime in El Salvador.
Then, there's the elephant in the room.
Prior to the elections, immigrant rights groups warned that Trump's return to power would spell devastation for immigrant communities. But both Martinez and Salazar pointed to a greater number of deportations under President Obama than under Trump, in Trump's defense.
"When he won in 2016, they were saying the same thing, exactly," Martinez said.
He also said people should remember that Trump extended Temporary Protected Status to Salvadorans in 2019. Martinez, who perceives Democrats as more lenient towards illegal immigration, believes Harris was worse for immigrants in the state. Trump extended Temporary Protected Status after revoking it in 2018.
"There are bad and good people," Martinez said.
He added that many Latinos in the state support tougher immigration. The vast majority who come to the U.S., he believes, are good and hardworking people. It's the small percentage of undocumented individuals doing bad things in the country, he said, that makes Americans perceive all Latinos as criminals.
Salazar believes Trump would not undergo mass indiscriminate deportations.
"He's not going to do this," said Salazar, "because if that happens, we will be here to say, 'Hey, that's not right.'"
Both men plan on attending Trump's upcoming inauguration on Jan. 20. They both hope to meet the administration and lobby for what they believe is important for Latinos in the state, and they are embracing optimism.
"For the Latino community," said Salazar, "there are a lot of good things that are happening."

title: Juvenile identified in Cambridge shooting

Juvenile identified in Cambridge shooting

 September 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 CAMBRIDGE — The juvenile who allegedly shot his step-father in the face on Friday has been identified by Cambridge Police.According to a press release from the Cambridge Police Department, Jaheem Mortaz Brown, 15, of Cambridge was arrested without incident Friday. Police said they were made aware of the shooting by Brown's mother, who drove to the police department and reported that her son had shot her husband in the face.
Brown was arrested the Tuesday before at Cambridge-South Dorchester High School for allegedly assaulting the school safety officer, but he was released the same day to the custody of his step-father according to Dorchester County Sheriff Jimmy Phillips.
{p class="p1"}"He was one of the people involved in this melee at Cambridge-South Dorchester High School last week," Phillips said.
According to the press release from the Cambridge Police Department, a witness, who was sitting in a vehicle on Skinners Court, alleges Brown struck her vehicle before his step-father exited the residence. Brown allegedly brandished a firearm and shot the step-father in the face before fleeing on foot to High Street.
Upon arriving at the scene, officers found Brown exiting the family's residence, where he was arrested. They also found one spent shell casing, but police did not recover the weapon, the press release said.
Police said officers and detectives were flagged down near the Park Lane and Camper Street area, where a man was hunched over and bleeding from his mouth. The 34-year-old man was identified as Brown's step-father.
He suffered a gunshot wound to the right cheek, and Dorchester County EMS transported him to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Cambridge. He was then flown to Shock Trauma by Maryland State Police Aviation. The severity of his injuries has not been disclosed.
Due to current Maryland Juvenile Reform Laws, Brown was not able to be questioned following the incident, police said. The reason for the crime and the whereabouts of the gun are still unknown, they said.
Brown has been turned over to the Dorchester County Department of Corrections without bond and is being tried as an adult. He is facing nine charges: attempted murder in the first and second degree, assault in the first and second degree, reckless endangerment, handgun on person, loaded handgun on person, firearm use in a felony violent crime and the possession of a firearm for a minor.

title: Dangerous minds - Israel-Hamas war, Musk comments, police surveillance spark new social media fights
author: Mike Sunnucks; Apg National Enterprise Editor
content:
Dangerous minds - Israel-Hamas war, Musk comments, police surveillance spark new social media fights

 November 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks; Apg National Enterprise Editor | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 1895

 Read News Document

 The Holy Land war between Israel and Hamas is birthing increased police and government surveillance of social media, prompting calls for more Americans to report "hate crimes" and proposals to require all social media accounts to have public name verifications amid concerns about increases in antisemitism and terrorism threats.There are also pushes to deport some anti-war, pro-Palestinian foreign college students deemed supportive of U.S. designated terror groups and expel and ban Palestinian refugees from entering the country.The efforts are born out of security concerns stemming from U.S. support for Israel's war against Hamas in Gaza after the Oct. 7 terror attacks. But they are also sparking concerns about stunting or intimating dissent, privacy and other free speech protections.There is also a new social media battle over Twitter/X owner Elon Musk's support for a social media post that talked about anti-white sentiments among "Jewish communities." A number of major media and technology advertisers, who also compete with social media platforms and some of Musk's technology ventures, have paused advertising on X. That includes Disney (which owns ABC and ESPN), Apple, Paramount Global (which owns CBS and Comedy, IBM, Comcast/NBC Universal (which owns NBC and MSNBC) and Warner Bros/Discovery (which owns CNN).Musk said he agreed with a post from a Twitter who said "Jewish communities have been pushing the exact kind of dialectical hatred against whites that they claim to want people to stop using against them." "You said the actual truth," Musk said in a reply Nov. 15, latter adding that his concurrence was geared toward progressive activist groups and the Anti-Defamation League.The Biden administration condemned Musk's statement Friday. "We condemn this abhorrent promotion of antisemitic and racist hate in the strongest terms," the U.S. administration said in statement drawing parallels to the beliefs of the Robert Bowers, who faces the death penalty after the Tree of Life Synagogue shooting in Pittsburgh left 11 congregants dead.The ADL on Nov. 16 also criticized Musk. "it is indisputably dangerous to use one's influence to validate and promote antisemitic theories, said ADL CEO Jonathan Greenblalt, who on Friday then praised Musk for his condemnation of pro-Palestinian and pro-Hamas phrases 'from the river to the sea' and 'decolonization.' Musk said Saturday some of the critics are dangerously using the episode to squelch free speech and that. he plans on suing progressive activists he claims inaccurately showed neo-Nazi and antisemitic posts next to Twitter/X advertisers' promotions."I am sticking to my principles. As for any fake advocacy groups who seek to suppress free speech, they should remember that karma is real," Musk said on his social media platform.EXPELLING FOREIGN COLLEGE STUDENTSThere is a GOP push to expel foreign college students deemed to be supporting Hamas, Hezbollah and other groups on the U.S. government's list of terrorist groups.A group of 21 GOP attorneys general - including Ashley Moody of Florida and Austin Knudsen of Montana - want the federal government to "vigorously renew vetting of foreign students' and deport those deemed to have endorsed or provided "material support to foreign terrorist organizations." "It is possible that renewed vetting of foreign students already admitted to the United States may reveal activity that renders them ineligible to hold a student visa and liable to deportation," Knudsen, Moody and their cohorts wrote in a letter Nov. 8 to U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken and the U.S.Department of Education.Free speech and civil liberties advocates say the reactions to anti-Israel war protests (some of which have seen antisemitic rhetoric) can bleed into censorship as well as quieting and punishing voices of dissent."Free speech means protecting speech you don't like. Sometimes it even means protecting speech you find abhorrent and hateful," said U.S. Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Kentucky, after voting against censure measure aimed at U.S. Rep. Rashida Tlaib, D-Michigan, over her anti-Israel rhetoric and use of a pro-Hamas slogan.BANNING PALESTINIAN REFUGEESA group of congressional Republicans - including U.S. Reps. Andy Thomas, who represents the Eastern Shore, along with U.S. Reps. Ryan Zinke of Montana and Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia and U.S. Sen. Steve Daines of Montana, are also leading efforts to keep Palestinian refugees from the war out of the U.S. Zinke, Harris and Greene also wants to kick out Palestinians who entered the country on or after Oct. 1 in the aftermath of the Hamas' Oct. 7 terror attacks inside Israel that sparked the war in Gaza.They say said he does not trust the Biden administration or Palestinian authorities to adequately screen potential refugees.Critics say the proposal is xenophobic.Similar sentiments related to refugees and college students have been echoed by 2024 GOP presidential candidates such as former president Donald Trump and Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis, who has suspended pro-Palestinian students' groups in his home state deemed extremist and favored restrictions on public library and school curricula content deemed inappropriate or offensive.While conservatives press universities, who have sometimes aggressively banned right-wing voices from their campuses, to condemn and crackdown on pro-Palestinian student protesters, the American Civil Liberties Union wants them to uphold free speech principles."It is precisely in times of heightened crisis and fear that university leaders must remain steadfast in their commitment to free speech, open debate, and peaceful dissent on campus.These principles are the bedrock of academic freedom at all universities," the ACLU said in a statement."The First Amendment protects all people who live in this country, whether they're here as citizens, foreign nationals, or visitors," the civil liberties group said.ENCOURAGING MORE HATE CRIME REPORTINGDaines and a bipartisan senators including U.S. Sen. Chris Van Hollen, D-Maryland, have also recently written to FBI Director Christopher Wray and the U.S. Department of Homeland Security asking for more investigative and enforcement resources to be dedicated to addressing antisemitism.The Anti-Defamation League reports a 300% increase in anti-Jewish threats, vandalism and violence since the start of the war, which has seen more than 1,400 Israelis and more than 11,000 Gazans killed.In a separate letter, U.S. Sen Jon Tester, D-Montana, also said FBI and DHS efforts should also be focused on white supremacists echoing past and current Biden administration efforts to go after alt-right groups.The Biden White House, which has put a focus on going after right-wing groups since taking office in 2021, has also launched a new task force to go after "Islamophobia" during the war.On Tuesday, the FBI said it added Oregon to a nationwide effort aimed at encouraging getting more Americans to report "hate incidents' ' with billboards posted in Eugene, Medford and Corvallis as well as digital signs at Portland International Airport.Similar hate crime billboards have been put up across the country, including last month in North Carolina, along with ads on public transit systems, social media platforms and local media outlets.Last month, the U.S. Department of Justice and FBI released new data showing there was a 7.3% increase in reported hate crimes in 2022 (11,634 cases versus 10,840) in 2021.There were more than 6,500 racially motivated incidents - 52% of them aimed at Blacks - and more than 2,000 cases related to religion - with 55% targeting Jews, according to DOJ.SOCIAL MEDIA SURVEILLANCE, FORCED VERIFICATIONSA state law in Montana backed by Knudsen and GOP Gov.Greg Gianforte banning Chinese-owned social media app TikTok is also one of the central fronts in efforts to restrict social media platforms and content.Montana lawmakers worry about TikTok's data security and ties to the Chinese government.The ban is being mirrored in other states.The Montana prohibition is being challenged by TikTok and free speech advocates in court.But there are also other efforts to increase government regulations and scrutiny and law enforcement surveillance of social media.New York Gov. Kathy Hochul said Nov. 13 that state police have ramped up social media surveillance and will reach out more to individuals and groups posting hate speech online."We're very focused on the data we're collecting from surveillance efforts. What's being said on social media platforms.And we have launched an effort to be able to counter some of the negativity. and reach out to people when we see hate speech being spoken about on online platforms," Hochul said. "Our media analysis, our social media analysis unit, has ramped up its monitoring of sites to catch incitement to violence; direct threats to others." The New York governor said the rise in extremist and violent threats after the start of the war in the Middle East "poses a clear and present danger." But the idea of more aggressive police surveillance of social media posts raises some concerns.Gerard Kassar, chairman of the New York Conservative Party, said police social media monitoring is potentially "chilling to the core"."Law enforcement authorities can and should monitor legitimate terrorism suspects online, but spying on everyday citizens is unconstitutional and wrong," Kassar said.Republican presidential candidate and former South Carolina governor and U.S. ambassador Nikki Haley wants to require all social media accounts be verified by name thus eliminating anonymous online speech on major platforms."Every person on social media should be verified by their name," said Haley, who is increasingly being promoted as an establishment and neoconservative 2024 alternative to former president Donald Trump."First of all, it's a national security threat. When you do that, all of a sudden people have to stand by what they say. And it gets rid of the Russian bots, the Iranian bots and the Chinese bots. And then you're going to get some civility when people know their name is next to what they say, and they know their pastor and their family members are going to see it," Haley told Fox News.Haley also backs a TikTok ban pointing to the recent viral traffic of a letter criticizing Israel and the U.S. from Osama Bin Laden.Harris told Fox News Nov. 16 that Congress could soon take some actions related to TikTok and the issue will come down to speech versus national security, citing the platform's Chinese ownership.The verification push sparked a backlash from free speech advocates, particularly on the right who have already been upset over social media bans and content restrictions over coronavirus vaccines and challenges to the 2020 election results.They say it will eliminate anonymous dissent and speech."Nikki Haley is 'openly' pushing for the government to use private tech companies to censor speech. This is a flagrant violation of the Constitution and straight out of the Democrats' playbook.Any politician who thinks it's OK for the government to use the private sector as its censorship bureau shouldn't be allowed anywhere near the White House," said Vivek Ramaswamy, who has frequently sparred with Haley over TikTok and other issues.

Hearn Building project moves toward construction with pivot

 July 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News

 CAMBRIDGE — Green Street Housing is adapting its design plans for the Hearn Building project on Race Street following concerns from Cambridge Planning and Zoning commissioners over ground-floor residential units.After a June 4 Planning and Zoning Commission meeting where Green Street — an affordable housing developer — presented its concept site plan for review, Cambridge City Attorney Patrick Thomas determined that placing apartment units on the ground floor of the the Hearn Building does not comply with the city's Unified Development Code.
"So we will be adapting our plans accordingly to prepare for resubmission to the planning commission," Green Street Director of Development Chase Powell said in an interview.
Green Street hopes to have an updated concept site plan for the commission to review in time for the commission's August meeting, Powell said.
At the June 4 meeting, Powell presented his company's plans for 505 and 509 Race Street — a roughly 50,000-square-foot mixed-use development that would include 44 residential units and 4,000 square feet of commercial, office or retail space fronting Race Street.
Powell said Green Street is financing the project using funding through the Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development's Low Income Housing Tax Credit Program and the department's loan resources.
"And with that comes a high commitment to designed quality and energy-efficiency," he said at the meeting.
Currently, there are two buildings on the land that Green Street plans to develop. Powell said they plan to raze 505 Race Street and build a new building in its footprint. For the Hearn Building at 509 Race Street, he said Green Street essentially plans to build a building within it.
"The Hearn Building is a shell, more or less, with a roof," he said. "So what we are proposing is what I would say, just a phenomenal feat of engineering to put a structure within a structure."
During the meeting, Commission Vice Chair William Craig brought up Green Street's plan to put apartment units on the ground level, behind commercial space. He cited a section in the city's Unified Development Code that states residential uses should be located on the upper floors of buildings in the "core" subdistrict, which the property is in.
Craig also pointed to the permitted uses table, which does not permit commercial apartments on the ground floor of a building located in the core subdistrict.
"That's what the ordinance says," he said. "And so I don't know how you're going to make it comply with that with this residential on the first floor."
Thomas said he hadn't looked into this before the meeting, but agreed with Craig's interpretation of the code.
NEXT STEPS
In an interview, Powell said since the city's determination that there cannot be residential units on the ground floor of the property, Green Street's architect is in the process of reconfiguring the plans to retain as many units as possible.
Although Powell suspects they will not be able to keep all 44 units in the property plans, he thinks the project will still be financially viable.
Cambridge City Planner Holly Baldwin said Green Street will need to to come back to the Planning and Zoning Commission again with the project's preliminary site plan. Once the commission has approved the plan, Green Street will have to submit its final construction plans for review and approval by city engineering and the city's zoning official, Baldwin said.
Powell said Green Street has had to do a lot of work to help people understand Green Street's intentions with this project.
In October, Cambridge Commissioner Brian Roche sent a letter to Maryland Secretary of Housing and Community Development Jake Day requesting a revision to the Hearn Building project plans. Roche said the current plan would further concentrate poverty in an area without an excess of available jobs, would go against Cambridge's Neighborhood Revitalization Plan and its Comprehensive Plan goals and would be an "excessive" cost to taxpayers, among other things. Roche also brought up a concern for management issues down the line.
At the meeting on June 4, Powell said TM Associates Management, which manages Cambridge apartment New Horizons, will be managing the Hearn Building apartments once the project is complete. He said there shouldn't be concerns about poor management because Green Street is a local developer.
"So we're very driven to make sure that everything's being maintained and it's orderly," he said. "Because it's in my backyard, too."

title: Talbot's advanced life support pioneers reflect on program's 40-year mark
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot's advanced life support pioneers reflect on program's 40-year mark

 August 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 722
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — Pioneers in Talbot County's advanced life support services gathered this week to reminisce on the 40-year anniversary of their revolutionary effort to improve emergency response on the Mid-Shore.Five Easton firefighters began volunteering to man a new advanced life support, or ALS, program on Aug. 13, 1985. They had just one vehicle from the fire department. They sacrificed time at home and kept up constant communication to ensure someone was ready to respond to a cardiac emergency at any given moment.
The "first five," as they're often called, were Wayne Dyott, Kevin Knussman, Marc Stockley, Ray Taylor and the late Gary Jones.
Wednesday afternoon inside the Harrison's Harbour Lights restaurant in St. Michaels, the four men shared laughs and memories of the effort they spearheaded four decades ago to the day.
"It was quite a haul," Stockley recalled. "And unfortunately, in the past five years, I've been able to use this (ALS) system several times. And seeing the changes. It's been interesting to see the advancements. The care level is always there."
They were joined by others integral to the early success and soon-to-come expansion of paramedic services in Talbot County: Margie Callahan, then-nurse coordinator at Easton Memorial Hospital, and Buddy Harrison IV, former County Council president and the first director of Talbot County Advanced Life Support.
They all took time to reflect on Jones' integral role in the effort.
Jones, former director of cardiovascular services at the Easton hospital, died in 2021. Dyott said Jones joined the fire company in the 1980s knowing the ALS program was about to kick off.
"Ultimately, he was a good bridge between hospital staff, them accepting us and bringing the whole program together," Stockley said.
'SKEPTICISM AT FIRST'
Jones and others worked to show people the importance of pre-hospital cardiac care and why countywide ALS services were needed.
A half-decade ago, response times for heart emergencies could sometimes be 20 to 30 minutes. First responders typically reported to the fire station, then traveled to the location of the emergency.
Taylor said it was hard at first for fire companies to even accept EMTs back in the 1970s. The five men, certified as cardiac rescue technicians, aimed to change that.
"We kept hearing the same thing: 'you're not doctors, you don't need to play doctor on the ambulance,'" Taylor said.
Fire department and hospital leaders eventually warmed up to the ALS program, Taylor said. It didn't come without questions from the community, Stockley noted.
"I think there was skepticism at first, but I think it came around eventually when they started seeing positive results," he said.
On Wednesday, Taylor recalled what may have been the first of those positive outcomes. In 1985, he and Dyott rode in the ALS vehicle to the scene of an overturned truck and a man lying down. Taylor successfully defibrillated the man, and that began to turn heads in the right direction.
"It's a good feeling," Taylor recalled.
IMPACT FELT TODAY
Since 1985, the modest five-person, volunteer venture in Easton has transformed to a countywide staple. The Talbot County Department of Emergency Services operates six ALS units and one "chase vehicle" for rapid response. Over 50 paramedics and EMTs staff the units, some full-time and others volunteers.
The hard work of the original five was done with the hope of having a comprehensive system like the one that exists today, Dyott said.
"That's what we started. That was our goal, our ambition," he said.
Tina Kintop, Talbot's EMS division chief, said the division's current success and bandwidth wouldn't be possible without those pioneers. Crews responded to around 6,800 calls last year, she noted.
"We are better prepared and educated more than ever in the life-saving business," Kintop wrote. "Thank you to the visionaries 40 years ago and to those advancing ahead today."
Callahan similarly credits the first five for persevering through the doubts and paramedic funding struggles in 1985 and the years after.
"They were a part of seeing this all come to fruition," she said.
Over the last 40 years, it has always been about saving lives, said Talbot County's original ALS leaders. Knussman said all the vehicle swaps and early morning phone calls were well worth it.
"I think all of us would agree that the people on the street today are better trained, better educated, better equipped and better organized," Knussman said. "That's something that all four of us, and Gary if he were here, that's something to be proud of."

title: Easton's new fire chief has plans for equipment, recruitment

 EASTON — J.R. Dobson grew up around the fire house, always knowing he wanted to be a firefighter.In his teenage years, Dobson joined the Trappe Volunteer Fire Company as a junior cadet, and by 16 he began riding the fire trucks. He fondly recalls the "everybody knew everybody" aspect of the tight-knit community.
Dobson eventually moved to Easton, beginning his journey with the Easton Volunteer Fire Department in 2003. Over time, he's served in a number of roles, including most recently, assistant chief.
Now he's taking on the department's top role for the first time. Dobson was elected the department's chief in December.
With a wife and two daughters, timing was everything for Dobson when considering the commitment to assume a role as demanding as Easton fire chief. The timing is right, he said, and he's looking forward to leading and making a difference.
"There's a lot of tradition here," Dobson said. "It's certainly the biggest department in the county. It's got probably the most going on out of all the departments in the county. I think just being here, seeing how this department operates versus a small department. It's a business. And we're all here for free, none of us get paid."
Dobson officially began as chief this month. Sonny Jones just wrapped up his third two-year term leading the department.
Dobson, who volunteers at the fire department as all the firefighters do, is a patrol and operations commander at the Talbot County Sheriff's Office. He believes his experience leading around 35 deputies across multiple divisions will translate to his duties in the fire house.
"I think that I bring a lot of management skills, leadership skills," Dobson said. "Just from my experience there, I think it helps you here."
Thus far, Dobson says the support he's received has been "overwhelming."
Past fire chiefs have reached out, and he hopes to pick up one thing from each of them to set himself up for success. For instance, Jones' ability as an incident commander is something Dobson admires.
"If there were ever a bad day anybody was having, he's who you would want there," Dobson said of Jones. "Just the way he kind of rolls through an incident scene. He's been there and done that kind of thing."
Similarly, Jones — who is remaining involved with the department — spoke highly of Dobson.
"I've known J.R. the entire time that I've been a member of the Easton fire department," Jones said. "J.R. is a first-rate guy. He's a terrific leader. He has many, many qualities which will bode well for him as the chief of the department."
Some of the ongoing projects the new fire chief has his eye on include purchasing a utility vehicle to use for Rails to Trails and woods fires, buying a new engine and updating box alarm assignments. He also wants to implement some new standard operating procedures.
Dobson said he hopes to nail down a handful of tasks for the year and keep circling back to see what progress is being made. At the top of his list is recruitment and retention of volunteers.
"I think it all starts with recruiting. I think it all starts with retention," Dobson said. "Those are things that we've done well in the past, although the last year or so we haven't gotten as many members as we would like. And sometimes we'll get members in and they don't realize the commitment."
While acknowledging the town's consistent support of the department over the years, Dobson believes Easton Fire can do better in attracting more volunteers amid struggles statewide and nationwide to fill volunteer fire departments.
"We got to get people in here," Dobson said. "We've got to get these trucks out. And I think that the way the town's growing, if we don't grow with it, then we're failing ourselves."
