title: Tunis Mills bridge replacement project moves forward
author: Konner Metz
content:
Tunis Mills bridge replacement project moves forward

 January 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 629
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TUNIS MILLS — A beloved bridge in the Tunis Mills community is moving toward reconstruction after months of resident input into the bridge's redesign.In recent years, the 345-foot-long Leeds Creeks Bridge and its wood planks have deteriorated. County engineers consider the bridge structurally deficient, necessitating a replacement.
Tuesday, the Talbot County Council agreed to move forward with the bridge replacement project. County Engineer Ray Clarke recommended the county work toward finalizing rights-of-way acquisitions and necessary permits so construction can be pursued later this year.
As proposed, the replacement would include a wooden deck and a timber wearing surface. The structures below the bridge supporting it, known as piles, would consist of concrete and steel materials.
Clarke told council members that in order to use federal funding for the project, the bridge replacement project cannot use timber piles per the State Highway Administration. He added that trying to build an all-timber replacement will cause significant delays and costs.
"The big disadvantage we have is that if we don't get the federal aid, we're probably going to need to request the council for additional funding for the project, local funding," Clarke said. " … This could be a $3 or $4 million ask."
The project costs around $6.5 million, with $1.5 million coming from the county. The rest is federally funded.
Advocates of a 100% wooden replacement have been in dialogue with the county, including at an August public meeting. Susan McDermott and John Tabori, two of those advocates, have lived in Tunis Mills next to the bridge for four years.
McDermott says the original proposal to rebuild the bridge many years ago "was just unacceptable to the community." The county's recent proposal matches more of what she and some other neighbors had hoped for.
"We're very pleased that the council has shown as much flexibility toward community views as it has," McDermott said.
Residents like McDermott previously expressed concerns that an asphalt wearing surface would encourage speeding across the bridge. The county's plans now include a timber wearing surface. Clarke said that change will amount to around a $250,000 increase.
The other main change based on community feedback is a reduction in the height of the safety railing from 42 to 36 inches.
McDermott, who leads a small group of neighbors called the Tunis Mills All-Timber Bridge Alliance, hopes to find answers to whether an exception can be made for the requirement that piles not be timber.
She adds that the bridge is an integral part of the community.
"I think the town feels that the wooden bridge of Tunis Mills — one of the last wooden-deck bridges in the county — is very much part of the community," McDermott said. "It's not just a bridge that occasional traffic goes across. We've got a lot of walkers in this neighborhood, a lot of kids and people just use that bridge as a foot path."
After a video of the bridge was shown during the meeting, Talbot County Council Member Lynn Mielke said it seems the replacement "needs to be done sooner rather than later."
Talbot County Council Vice President Pete Lesher thanked Clarke and his team for their efforts to advance the replacement project.
"I appreciate the homework that you've done to investigate the alternatives as requested and appreciate that we really can't sacrifice the federal aid," Lesher said. "The economics of this project dictate that we absolutely need to go with the recommended steel concrete pilings and concrete cap."
Lesher motioned to approve the project as presented, and the rest of the council unanimously agreed. Lesher added that he hopes the federal funding for the project comes through, referencing President Donald Trump's temporary pause on federal grants and loans announced earlier this week and rescinded Wednesday.
"And we'll just hope that any suspension of federal grant aid for transportation projects is very short-lived," Lesher said Tuesday.

title: Maryland House and Garden tour lets visitors explore Talbot County properties
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Maryland House and Garden tour lets visitors explore Talbot County properties

 May 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 660
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Standing in the foyer of Canterbury Manor in Easton, one's eyes might dart straight out the window to the luscious green grounds that look out onto Trippe Creek.Or their eyes might be drawn to the estate's light and airy living room, which boasts a Steinway Piano from the 1920s, English furniture, and French and Dutch paintings. But no matter where the eye goes first, it's undeniable that it won't take long to feel drawn into the 1906 colonial revival style home.
For Easton resident Summer Parrish, it was the design of the kitchen — complete with French copper pots hanging above a big kitchen island — and the large but cozy-feeling butler's pantry.
"Oh my gosh," she said, talking about various parts of the house. "The flower arrangements that are in (the) sun porch and on the kitchen table are the most beautiful I've every seen in my entire life."
Canterbury Manor was the second home Parrish and her family members, including her sister and mother, toured on the Saturday of Mother's Day weekend. The Talbot County tour is part of the Maryland House and Garden Pilgrimage, which was started in 1937. Proceeds go toward the preservation and restoration of historically significant properties in the state.
Parrish's mother, Hope Leuchter, said comparing the first home they visited — a 1928 two-and-a-half story central brick mansion called Ellenborough — to Canterbury Manor is like comparing apples and oranges.
"The first one has the most magnificent trees," Leuchter said. "And if you're crazy for trees and their botanical names and love their lore, that would have been it. Here (at Canterbury Manor), the artistry, the effectiveness of colors and choices. The home is beyond words beautiful."
Every two years, the pilgrimage brings Marylanders from all over the state to ooh and aah at historic architecture, grand gardens and fragrant floral arrangements in Talbot County. Most of the flowers in the arrangements are from the gardens of Talbot County Garden Club members.
The money raised from the Talbot County tour "by and large" stays in the county, Talbot tour co-chair Kim Eckert said. This year, the Talbot County Garden Club, which organizes the tour, chose to put proceeds toward Scotts United Methodist Church and St. Paul's Episcopal Church, both in Trappe.
"We wanted to focus on houses in Trappe, and we thought the best thing to do was to put the money back into Trappe," Eckert said.
The funds raised from the tour will go toward fully fixing and preserving both of the more than 250-year-old churches. Eckert said Lane Engineering and McHale Landscape Design both donated or discounted services to help make this possible. She said the Garden Club will even have some money left over to put toward other projects, such as the Talbot Historical Society gardens.
Along with Canterbury Manor and Ellenborough, tour-goers also had the opportunity to visit Easton's 219 S. Hanson St. and Trappe's Chloras Point Farm, Ferry Farm House, Trappe Landing Farm and Lloyds Landing.
"You get a really neat collection of Talbot County's homes, from the grand estates to the regular, beautiful farm homes," said Jack Thompson, executive director of the Maryland House and Garden Pilgrimage.
At Lloyds Landing, an 18th century house on the Choptank River in Trappe, Sherwood resident Kevin Carnahan took in the history of the property. The house, erected between 1720 and 1730, is one of the only eight remaining structures from that era in the county.
"They all have a lot of history," Carnahan said about the four homes he had visited so far. "But this one in particular."
Montgomery County resident Lynn Konefal talked about the pieces of history in the house, like the old family photos hanging on the walls.
And even though it's one of the oldest structures in the county, Lloyds Landing was built with air conditioning and heat in mind, Eckert said.
"Based on how the roof is pitched and how it's located to the Choptank," she said. "It's mind-boggling to me that they designed all that in 1729."

title: Defending North Bayside champion Queen Anne’s County among teams trying to fill graduation holes in an attempt for another deep playoff
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Defending North Bayside champion Queen Anne’s County among teams trying to fill graduation holes in an attempt for another deep playoff

 September 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 1620
 Words 

 Read News Document

 North Bayside boys soccer coaches have been busy this preseason — and during the early weeks of the regular season — mending holes in their lineups.Defending division champion Queen Anne's County High, which went 13-3-1 and reached the Class 2A state semifinals a year ago, graduated eight, including six starters.
"The guys that we lost were huge parts," Lions head coach Wade Hosler said.
North Caroline head coach John Austin can sympathize after graduating seven, including 2023 North Bayside Player of the Year Logan Harned.
"I feel as a conference we lost a lot of really good players," Austin said. "Last year's conference was very, very senior heavy."
A handful of those graduates are now playing in the collegiate ranks, with North Caroline's Harned at Neumann (Pa.) University and goalie Gavin O'Brien at Frostburg State, while Queen Anne's has Billy Schindler at Washington College.
The Class 1A ranks also felt graduation's sting. North Dorchester lost 10, while Cambridge-South Dorchester first-year head coach Josh Dohoney is trying to patch holes created by almost half of dozen losses.
In addition to the Vikings, Easton welcomes former standout Avery Brice as its new head coach, while Kent County begins the Dennis Hickman era.
Queen Anne's shared the conference title with James M. Bennett in 2021, but the last North team to win the Bayside championship outright was Kent Island in 2016, when the Bucs topped Stephen Decatur in penalty kicks. The Bucs and Lions look to be on another collision course to decide the North when they meet in Stevensville on Oct. 18, though North Caroline and Easton figure to also be atop the division ranks.
The South's dominance of the conference crown could be extended this year, as Bennett, which lost to eventual Class 3A state champion South River in last year's postseason, returns the bulk of its team from a season ago.
Here's a look at this year's North Bayside teams.
CAMBRIDGE-SD
Head Coach: Josh Dohoney.
Who's Where: Goalie: Nate Huber (Sr.); Backs: Osvaldo Hernandez (Jr.); Evan Kozak (Sr.); Colton Phillips (So.); Gibby Robinson (So.); Midfield: Lucas Harper (So.); Gavin Weber (So.); Ryan Harris (Sr.); Forwards: Will Banks (Jr.); Wyatt Abbott (So.); Marcos Hernandez (Fr.).
Outlook: After one year as an assistant, Dohoney begins his first head coaching job in soccer knowing he'll need to be patient.
"We're very young. Very much a rebuilding squad," said Dohoney, who played at Delmar, Del.
The Vikings graduated more than half a dozen from last year, including center midfielder Randall Johnson. The midfield looks technically sound, but with five sophomores and one freshman starting, Dohoney hopes this will be a season of growth.
COL. RICHARDSON
Head Coach: Dillon Shaheen.
Who's Where: Goalie: Cohen Carels (Sr.); Backs: Cameron Todd (Sr.); Jacklin Novembre (Jr.); Jackson Jean Jr. (Jr.); Caleb Rouser (So.); Midfield: John Beaven (So.); Jack Walls (Jr.); Preston Rickwood (Sr.); Ludver Vasquez (Jr.); Aydan Downie (Sr.); Forwards: Morgan Demir (Sr.); Angel Castro-Rios (Sr.); Skyler Endzel (Fr.); Brody Omohundro (Fr.).
Outlook: Shaheen begins his third year as head coach with his most experienced team he's had. That has translated into victories over Pocomoke and North Dorchester for starters.
"It's been pretty good so far," said Shaheen, who lost three seniors from last year. "Obviously we have a lot of seniors and juniors, and most have been playing at the varsity level for three or four years. I'm pretty confident in our squad this year."
EASTON
Head Coach: Avery Brice.
Who's Where: Goalie: Sam Hutchison (Jr.); Backs: Mario Medina (Sr.); Felix Valentine (Jr.); Brody Byrnes (Sr.); Kai Ferraris (Jr.); Landon Chaney (Sr.); Midfield: Clay Nagle (Sr.); Luke Stanco (Jr.); CJ Chaconas (Sr.); Blake Royer (So.); Ale Monroy (So.); Dominic Stanco (Sr.); Otto Perez-Arreaga (Fr.); Logan Sundt (Jr.); Liam Edgell (Sr.); Forwards: Kyle Ensminger (Jr.); Rodi Fresco Rubio (Jr.).
Outlook: Brice was a center midfielder on Easton's last two teams to win Bayside titles (2013, '14) and helped the Warriors reach the 2A state final in '14 before continuing his playing career at Wesley (Del.) College.
Now, he steps into his first head coaching job.
"Things are shaping up nicely," Brice said. "Could things be better? Yes. That's kind of one thing that we just hope to do every day in the season; just be better than the day before."
While the Warriors have been receptive to their new coach's ideas and style, Brice stressed they must strive for consistency.
"The mindset is you can be really good, but every game you've got to bring it," Brice said.
KENT COUNTY
Head Coach: Dennis Hickman.
Who's Where: Goalie: Leyder Cruz (Sr.); Backs: Noah Iacona (Jr.); Jayden Miller (So.); Stewart Hickman (Jr.); Bryce Jacobs (So.); Midfield: Nick Stead (Sr.); Colbyn Lopez (Jr.); Ethan Clark (Sr.); Forwards: Gabe Parr (So.); Dylan Peralta (Fr.); Sebastian Cousineau (So.).
Outlook: A 1993 graduate of Kent County, Hickman, who played soccer, baseball and wrestled for the Trojans, takes over as head coach after spending the last two years as an assistant.
In an attempt to build a program, Hickman has already achieved one goal in fielding a junior varsity for the first time since 2019.
"We think by having a jayvee, getting them out there on practice, getting them those reps and having some game-time situations and play, that we're only going to be able to build on that moving forward," Hickman said. "It's just the best thing for the program."
That coupled with a varsity roster that includes nine juniors and nine sophomores, could bode well for the future.
As for this year's team, there isn't a lot of experience, though Stewart Hickman has plenty of travel ball experience, as has recruited players over the summer to come out for the team.
KENT ISLAND
Head Coach: Lin Outten.
Who's Where: Goalie: Quinn Burns (Fr.); Backs: Davis Miller (Sr.); Noah Scopp (Sr.); Gavin Neboshynsky (Sr.); Mark Rees (Sr.); Spencer Chappell (Jr.); Elijah James (So.); Midfield: Simon Vujinovic (Sr.); Brendan Thomas (Jr.); Cooper Liebel (So.); Landon Pecor (Jr.); Forwards: AJ Miller (Jr.); Eric Hoffman (Sr.); Ethan Schriver (Sr.); Robert Simkins (Jr.).
Outlook: The Bucs have a lot of experience moving from the midfield into the attack, but are not as experienced in the back. Though seniors Davis Miller, Scopp and Rees return, Outten hopes shifting Neboshynsky and Chappell from midfield to the back bolsters his defense.
AJ Miller netted 10 goals a year ago, and Outten thinks that number will go up, especially with the return of Hoffman, who missed the bulk of last year with an early season injury.
"But really what makes the engine go is the three guys in the middle — Thomas, Vujinovic and Liebel," Outten said.
NORTH CAROLINE
Head Coach: John Austin.
Who's Where: Goalie: Mason Shilling (Jr.); Backs: Lewis Higgs (Jr.); Brayden Boarts (Sr.); Jimmy Cohoon (Jr.); Midfield: Ayden Russell (Jr.); Tyler Gutierrez (Jr.); Omar Marroquin (Sr.); Jonnathan Luna Feliciano (Jr.); Diego Castro (So.); Landyn Harned (So.); Kyle Reed (Jr.); Forwards: Heath Frantum (Jr.); Issac Bautista (Jr.); Luke Raga (So.).
Outlook: The Bulldogs graduated seven from a year ago, including Harned, O'Brien, and also lost leading scorer Kevin Godinez.
Austin thinks his team will be more defensive-minded this season. The defense is led by Shilling, who Austin thinks has college potential. Shilling and company figure to be tested early, as the Bulldogs open with defending conference champion James M. Bennett, Class 2A state semifinalist Queen Anne's, and perennial conference heavyweight Stephen Decatur.
"We have a lot of holes to fill," Austin said. "I think we are where we need to be right now. But the goal is can we just keep getting better as the year goes on, and then when October rolls around, play our best soccer?"
NORTH DORCHESTER
Head Coach: Gabe Guzman.
Who's Where: Goalie: Jayden Coleman (Jr.); Backs: Chris Sanchez (Jr.); Tahjere Pritchett (Jr.); Alex Fonseca-Gonzalez (So.); Martin Chirino Fernandez (Jr.); Midfield: Christian Chase (Jr.); Peyton Bleyer (So.); Daniel Mejia (Sr.); Kegan Henry (Jr.); Forwards: Volcy Nerat (Fr.); Dagoberto Chirino Fernandez.
Outlook: The Eagles graduated 10, including seven starters. Among Guzman's top priorities is getting his freshman to buy into his system and get acclimated to the high school varsity format.
"We're working on trust," Guzman said.
QUEEN ANNE'S
Head Coach: Wade Hosler.
Who's Where: Goalie: Ethan Keppler (Sr.); Backs: Christian Coppage (Sr.); Conner Cheezum (Sr.); Hayden Albright (Sr.); Brody Nordvik (Jr.); Midfield: James Rath (Jr.); Gage Jordan (Sr.); Nathan Kostka (Jr.); Mason Albright (Sr.); Boden Blodgett (So.); Josiah Hegarty (So.); Forwards: Ryan Lee (Sr.).
Outlook: "The preseason seemed awfully short this year, and our chemistry wasn't quite where I'd like it this time of year," Hosler said. "But I think it's coming, so I'm optimistic that we can do good things. We've had good moments and we've had mistakes. But I like the direction we're heading in."
Hosler has also liked his team's 3-0-1 start, which included Monday's 3-0 shutout of North Caroline.
Despite its big graduation losses, the Lions do have a solid core of returners. Outside backs Coppage and Cheezum return along with Keppler in goal. Jordan is back in the midfield while Lee returns at striker.
"We have some big pieces, but we still have some big holes to fill," said Hosler, who graduation losses included Schindler, center back William Nagle and leading scorer Nick Esper. "If we can have some guys step up I think we'll be OK."
ST. MICHAELS
Head Coach: Pat Hambleton.
Who's Where: Goalie: Will Sherwood (Sr.); Backs: Tyler Murphy (Jr.); Jack Brennan (Sr.); Sherwin Mendez (Sr.); Brennan Dean (Jr.); Midfield: Ethan Royer (Jr.); Gavin Bieber (Fr.); Johnny Mautz (Jr.); Abel Delgaudio (So.); Forwards: Connor Wheeler (Jr.); Miles Fox (Jr.); Haven Haddaway (Sr.).
Outlook: Having Sherwood — first-team all-North Bayside goalie the past two years — and an experienced returning defensive unit should make the Saints plenty tough.
While that provides Hambleton comfort, he also liked what he has seen on the offensive end.
"Finally creative," Hambleton said of his attack. "We're going to be an enjoyment to watch. Still have an older group to support our creative offensive style. I have players to make it a pretty game finally. And they get it."

 November 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Columns 
 
 342
 Words

 On Nov. 22, 1963, John F. Kennedy, the 35th president of the United States, was shot to death during a motorcade in Dallas; Texas Gov. John B. Connally, riding in the same car as Kennedy, was seriously wounded. Suspected gunman Lee Harvey Oswald was arrested. Vice President Lyndon B. Johnson was sworn in as president.Also on this date:
In 1718, English pirate Edward Teach — better known as "Blackbeard" — was killed during a battle off what is now North Carolina.
In 1935, a flying boat, the China Clipper, took off from Alameda, California, carrying more than 100,000 pieces of mail on the first trans-Pacific airmail flight.
In 1986, 20-year-old Mike Tyson became the youngest heavyweight boxing champion in history, stopping WBC titleholder Trevor Berbick in the second round of their championship bout in Las Vegas.
In 1990, British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, having failed to win reelection to the Conservative Party leadership on the first ballot, announced she would resign.
In 2005, Angela Merkel took office as Germany's first female chancellor.
In 2010, a panicked crush at a festival in the Cambodian capital of Phnom Penh left some 350 dead and hundreds injured in what the prime minister called the country's biggest tragedy since the 1970s reign of terror by the Khmer Rouge.
In 2017, Ratko Mladić, the Bosnian Serb general whose forces carried out the worst massacre in Europe since World War II, was convicted of genocide and other crimes by the United Nations' Yugoslav war crimes tribunal and sentenced to life behind bars.

title: Mayor Megan Cook brings down duck gavel, officially opening 53rd Waterfowl Festival
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Mayor Megan Cook brings down duck gavel, officially opening 53rd Waterfowl Festival

 November 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 324
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The 53rd annual Waterfowl Festival officially began Thursday evening at the Tidewater Inn, where Megan Cook, mayor of Easton, was welcomed onstage to officially open the festival with the banging of the duck gavel.This three-day festival welcomes thousands of waterfowl enthusiasts to Talbot County each year to appreciate local wildlife, art, heritage, food and community.
Throughout the Thursday evening ceremony, citations were given to organizers of the festival, longtime volunteers were honored for their service and a featured artist unveiled new work.
The ceremony began with opening remarks by Eric Milhollan, president of the executive board for the Waterfowl Festival. He welcomed all attendees, recognizing them for joining the festival and supporting conservation efforts.
In his speech, Milhollan shared his long history with the festival. Beginning with volunteering with his father and later becoming involved with his own family as an adult, Milhollan shared his pride for the countless families who have long-standing traditions of volunteering for the festival.
"I'm proud to have my oldest son cheering for the second year. He's joined by his two brothers and sister, all coming home from college to help for the weekend at the festival that's been part of my life and my family's life," Milhollan said. "I believe in the crowd and see that many who have similar stories in passing the tradition of the festival to their families. This is what allows us to celebrate 53 years."
Throughout the evening, several people were honored, including a memoriam for Kim Perry Whiteley and Hall of Fame presentations for Blenda Armistead, Ron Flohr and Butch Townsend. A waterfowl statue was unveiled by this year's Waterfowl Festival Featured Artist Ronnie Wells.
As Cook held the opening gavel in her hand, she looked to the leaders of the Waterfowl Festival, and they all smiled.
"Are we ready? All right, we're ready. Let's go," Cook said before banging the duck-shaped gavel against the podium and officially opening the Waterfowl Festival's 53rd year of celebration.

title: Biden in a bind: Left-wing, anti-war pressure challenges reelection, long-standing support for Israel
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Newspapers
content:
Biden in a bind: Left-wing, anti-war pressure challenges reelection, long-standing support for Israel

 March 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Newspapers | Section: World 
 
 1075
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The U.S. military started air dropping aid into Gaza Saturday as U.S. President Joe Biden faces pressure from many Democrats who want Israel to agree to a ceasefire in its war against Hamas after the Oct. 7 terror attacks.Anti-war and pro-Palestinian pressure from the left challenges Biden's long-standing support for Israel as he faces a tight reelection race against former president Donald Trump.
Biden has also received more financial support from pro-Israel groups and advocates than any other U.S. politician over the last four decades, according to the Center for Responsive Politics which looked at campaign donations since 1990.
U.S. MILITARY DROPPING AID IN GAZA
According to the Associated Press, U.S. military C-130 cargo planes on Saturday dropped food in pallets over Gaza, three U.S. officials said, two days after more than 100 Palestinians who had surged to pull goods off an aid convoy were killed during a chaotic encounter with Israeli troops.
Three planes from Air Forces Central dropped 66 bundles containing about 38,000 meals into Gaza at 8:30 a.m. EST, according to two of the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity before a public announcement, the AP reported.
Biden said Friday the U.S. would start air dropping aid into the Hamas-controlled Palestinian area where more than 30,000 people have died since the start of the war. Another 7,800 people are missing with a good number of those presumed dead within the rubble of the Holy Land war.
More than 1,400 Israelis have died since the war started in October. Israeli officials say they have killed 10,000 Hamas and other Islamic militant fighters in the war.
Earlier in the week before the Michigan presidential primary, Biden played up the possibility of a ceasefire in Gaza. Yesterday and today, Biden also talked up a potential 6-week ceasefire that could start before the Muslim holiday of Ramadan (which begins March 10).
But Hamas continues to hold Israeli hostages taken In the Oct. 7 attacks and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu vows to continue the war to dismantle the Islamic militant group.
"This week a Harvard CAPS-Harris poll was published; it determined that 82% of the American public supports Israel. That is to say - more than 4 out 5 U.S. citizens support us and not Hamas. This broad support gives us redoubled energy to continue the campaign until total victory," Netanyahu said in a statement.
BIDEN'S LONG SUPPORT FOR ISRAEL
Biden has been a steadfast supporter of Israel during this 51-year tenure in U.S. politics, while serving in the U.S. as vice president in the Obama administration and now as U.S. president.
Biden has declared himself "a Zionist" supporting the Jewish state of Israel on multiple occasions including in December at Hanukkah celebration at the White House.
Since 1990, Biden has received close to $10 million in donations from pro-Israel groups and advocates according to the Center for Responsive Politics. That's the most of any U.S. politician.
But Public opinion polls show wide swaths of Democrats, especially younger and Muslim voters, support a ceasefire and oppose Netanyahu's war after the Oct. 7 attacks.
That showed up in the Michigan primary where 13.2% of Democrats voted uncommitted and self-help guru Marianne Williamson, who was not actively campaigning, got 3% of the vote.
Michigan is a key battleground in the general election.
Trump received 758,892 votes in the GOP primary versus Nikki Haley compared to 623,415 for Biden who isn't facing substantial opposition.
PRESSURE FROM THE LEFT
Left-wing advocates — including U.S. Sens. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., and Bernie Sanders, I-Vermont — have stepped up their pushes against Israel's war in Gaza and want to put more strings on U.S. military aid to Israel — which totals more than $3 billion annually.
"Netanyahu and his right-wing government have created a catastrophe in Gaza. Today Israeli troops opened fire on Palestinians desperate for aid. The U.S. must push for a cease-fire, hostage releases, & condition military support on pursuing a two-state solution for a lasting peace," Warren said Feb. 29.
Sanders is also pushing against U.S. support for Netanyahu's government and Israel's war effort against Hamas.
The U.S. government designates the Islamic group as a terrorist organization.
"Children are starving in Gaza. Instead of opening up the borders and allowing humanitarian aid to come in, Israeli soldiers are shooting people who are desperately trying to get food off of trucks. This must stop. The U.S. cannot continue funding the Netanyahu war machine," Sanders said Feb. 29.
That has pushed Biden and his presidential campaign – which is in 50/50 race with Trump — to press for a ceasefire and launch the airdrops.
"We're trying to work out a deal between Israel and Hamas (with) the hostages being returned and (an) immediate ceasefire in Gaza for at least the next six weeks," Biden said.
CLOSED BORDERS
The humanitarian situation in Gaza is magnified by Egypt and Jordan refusing to allow Palestinian refugees from their war zones into their countries, the lack of international pressure, including from other Muslim countries and Europe, on Hamas to release Israeli hostages and Palestinian militants also wanting to keep civilians in Gaza as shields against Israel Defense Forces and over worries about Israel taking over the area after the war.
International aid groups — many of which are critical of Israel and U.S. support for the war with some taking pro-Palestinian stances in the Middle East conflict— have said the U.S. aid is more about optics than alleviating suffering from war.
"Oxfam does not support U.S. airdrops to Gaza, which would mostly serve to relieve the guilty consciences of senior U.S. officials whose policies are contributing to the ongoing atrocities and risk of famine in Gaza," said Scott Paul, associate director for Oxfam America. "While Palestinians in Gaza have been pushed to the absolute brink, dropping a paltry, symbolic amount of aid into Gaza with no plan for its safe distribution would not help and be deeply degrading to Palestinians."
Aid groups have criticized Israel for not allowing more aid via trucks amid concerns from the IDF that those supplies have and will continue to be taken by Hamas.
IDF officials said the Thursday event where Gazans were killed during a chaotic mob scene involving an aid convoy only involved Israeli soldiers firing warning shots to try to disperse the mob.
"This morning humanitarian aid trucks entered northern Gaza, residents surrounded the trucks and looted the supplies being delivered. As a result of the pushing, trampling and being run over by the trucks, dozens of Gazans were killed and injured," an IDF spokesman said Thursday.
Palestinians contend the IDF shot at the Gazans resulting in the stampede.

 Former president Donald Trump has been charged like mobster and drug kingpin in Georgia, like an anarchist and foreign spy in Florida and like a post-Civil War Ku Klux Klan member in Washington D.C. as he faces now a quartet of criminal charges in the run-up to 2024 election.Trump was indicted by a Fulton County, Georgia grand jury along with 2024 campaign cohorts and attorneys - including Rudy Giuliani, Jenna Ellis and White House Chief of Staff Mark Meadows - over attempts to reverse President Joe Biden's 11,779-vote win in the Peach State.Part of that indictment includes racketeering charges conventionally used against organized crime syndicates and criminal gangs."The indictment alleges that rather than abide by Georgia's legal process for election challenges, the defendants engaged in a criminal racketeering enterprise to overturn Georgia's presidential election result," Fulton County District Attorney Fani Willis, a Democrat, said during a late-night news conference Monday, Aug. 14, announcing the indictment of the former president and leading 2024 GOP White House candidate.The indictment includes RICO (Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations), making false statements and other election meddling charges. The criminal charges to making false statements, like some of other federal allegations against Trump, will face First Amendment free speech counterarguments.Across the U.S., RICO cases have commonly been used against organized crime syndicates and criminal gangs including John Gotti's Gambino Crime Family, the Hells Angels, Latin Kings and the Cowboy Mafia, which used shrimp boats to smuggle illegal marijuana in the late 1970. There have been RICO charges used in some corporate and other corruption cases including 2022 indictments of some current and former soccer officials associated with FIFA and CONCACAF.In Georgia, RICO convictions could potentially bring prison terms of 5 to 20 years.According to the Associated Press, the Trump indictment includes criminal charges related to "attempting to persuade Georgia lawmakers to ignore the will of voters and appoint a new slate of electoral college electors favorable to Trump." "In one particularly brazen episode, it also outlines a plot involving one of his lawyers to access voting machines in a rural Georgia county and steal data from a voting machine company," the AP writes.Like with his federal indictments and charges in New York of filing false business claims to cover up alleged hush money paid to porn star Stormy Daniels and Playboy model, Karen McDougal, Trump lambasted the charges as politically motivated falsehoods aimed to undermining his 2024 White House bid."Can you believe it? This failed District Attorney from Atlanta, Fani Willis, where murders and other violent crime soars daily to new record highs, is charging me with 2020 Presidential Election Interference. No, Fani, the only Election Interference was done by those that Rigged and Stole the Election," Trump said in a statement on social media platform Truth Social. "Those are the ones you should be going after, not the innocent people that are fighting for Election Integrity!" Ellis and Guiliani, who served as Trump campaign lawyers, say they are being charged criminally for providing legal advice. "The Democrats and the Fulton County DA are criminalizing the practice of law," Ellis said in a social media statement.U.S. Justice Department Special Prosecutor Jack Smith has invoked federal grand juries in Florida and D.C. to indict Trump via the 1917 Espionage Act over his alleged misappropriation of classified documents and a post-Civil War law aimed at violent harassment by the Ku Klux Klan over the Jan. 6 Capitol riot and efforts to derail Congress' certification of Biden as the 2020 election winner.The Espionage Act has been previously used against Julian Assange, Edward Snowden, Julius and Ethen Rosenbereg and early 20th Century anarchist writer Emma Goldman.All told, Trump, 77, could potentially be jailed for the rest of his life if convicted and sentenced aggressively by state and federal judges.Tung Yin, a law professor at Lewis & Clark Law School in Portland, Oregon, said jury selections will be very important in the cases against Trump and prospective jurors may hide their love, disdain or other views toward the former Republican president."That person might give very bland answers during jury selection," XXX said. "It would be very hard to ferratt someone like this out. you get one person out of 12 you have a hung jury." The timing of the trials could run into and potentially after the 2024 U.S. presidential campaign elections.Yin sees the classified documents case where Trump is accused of improperly taking classified materials from the White House to his Florida estate as the stronger of the federal prosecutions.If convicted, Trump, the leading opposition candidate currently to President Biden, could potentially be jailed.For example, Jan. 6th charges in D.C. (which Biden won over Trump 92% to 5%) could result in Trump going to a federal prison for between 57 to 71 months, according to an estimate from Yin. That's between just under four and almost six years.Politically, as expected, Trump-aligned Republicans criticized the Georgia indictment while Democrats and progressives hailed the effort to convict and potentially imprison the bombastic populist former president.

Fulton County District Attorney Fani Willis speaks in the Fulton County Government Center during a news conference, Monday, Aug. 14, 2023, in Atlanta. Donald Trump and several allies have been indicted in Georgia over efforts to overturn his 2020 election loss in the state.

Preston man pleads guilty to attempted murder - CRIME

 DENTON - A Preston man pleaded guilty Monday to attempted murder in connection to the February 2022 stabbing of a young woman.After waiving his right to a jury trial two weeks ago, Mark William Thompkins, 25, pleaded guilty to attempted second-degree murder during a hearing in Caroline County Circuit Court.The plea reached Monday comes over a year and a half after the stabbing of a then 25-year-old woman near Holly Park Drive and Gilpin Point Road in Preston shortly before 3 p.m. on Feb. 17, 2022.According to Caroline County State's Attorney Sloane Franklin, trash collection workers near the scene first saw the woman sitting in the driver's seat of her vehicle with a man, later identified as Thompkins, seated behind her. Thompkins began striking the woman with his fists, then brandished a knife to stab her neck.The woman ran from her vehicle and collapsed in the front yard of a nearby house. Thompkins cradled her while holding the knife to his own throat, Franklin said.A witness attempted to help the victim but Thompkins threatened them, pointing the knife at them and yelling for them to get back.Multiple law enforcement agencies, including the Caroline County Sheriff's Office, Maryland State Police and Maryland Natural Resources Police, responded to the stabbing.Franklin said Thompkins punctured his own neck with a knife while running to the woods, evading officers.After 15 minutes and the use of multiple non-lethal methods, including a taser, to diffuse the situation, a state trooper was able to knock the knife out of Thompkins' hand to detain him, police said.Both Thompkins and the woman were flown to the University of Maryland Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore for treatment of their injuries.Following his arrest, a judge found Thompkins incompetent to stand trial in April 2022.He was committed to the Maryland Department of Health until August of this year, then transferred back to a local detention center upon being found competent, according to court filings.In court Monday, Franklin said he will recommend a 30-year sentence with all but 15 years of active incarceration suspended, followed by five years of supervised probation and special mental health conditions.State sentencing guidelines recommend five to 10 years, said Jesse Hicks, Thompkins' attorney. The plea is not binding, meaning a judge has the ability to impose a higher or lower sentence than what is recommended.Sentencing will be deferred until Feb. 1, 2024.

title: Dorchester Burial Sites Preservation Board gets another chance
author: Maggie Trovato

Dorchester Burial Sites Preservation Board gets another chance

 January 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 717

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A board designed to help preserve grave sites in Dorchester County has one year to prove it is able to accomplish its mission or it will face dissolution.After holding a public hearing about repealing a chapter of the county code regarding burial sites preservation, the Dorchester County Council agreed Jan. 21 to keep the chapter — which includes the Burial Sites Preservation Board established within it — for a test period.
"A one-year test from today to see what you can accomplish and see if it is a worthy board to have within this county," Council Member Ricky Travers said before making the motion.
Throughout the public hearing and following discussion, council members brought up concerns of past problems with the board's participation and its ability to work cohesively. Council President Lenny Pfeffer said that in the one-year test period, the board would need to prove it can fill its seats and provide a quorum at its meetings.
Travers said board members would need to work together, not against each other as has been the case in the past.
"As passionate as people might be about grave sites, ... we cannot have this controversy," Travers said. "So whomever comes on that board needs to be willing and ready to work side-by-side."
County Planning and Zoning Director Susan Webb said the Maryland Historical Trust is the state's enforcing entity regarding burial sites preservation.
"And we were basically duplicating the effort," she said. "While this may be a good board for a nonprofit, being under the county's umbrella, I don't think it's working out."
Dorothy Samonisky, the chair of the Burial Sites Preservation Board, said the Maryland Historical Trust only gives guidance and does not "act as an arm of the law" like the county can.
"So right now, this burial site preservation is the only thing that gives you as county members anything to stand on if there is an incident with a grave site."
Pfeffer clarified that the board is an advisory group to the council.
Samonisky said people have been buried in Dorchester County since 1669, and many of those burial sites are on private property. She said the policy in county code gives the county the authority to "act upon destruction of those cemeteries."
Ashley Samonisky, who also spoke during public comment, said the board can guide council actions and help with outreach and education. She said there needs to be something in the code that addresses what happens if a person "maliciously destroy(s) a property or (tries) to hide the fact that it was there," in order to build a beach house, for example.
"There needs to be fines," she said. "There needs to be penalties up to and including the cost of restoring it to the pre-demolition stage. These are just a few ideas that this body can help with."
Dorothy Samonisky acknowledged that there were "internal conflicts" between several board members at one point. She said she also was out due to two major surgeries in 2024.
"We had met up through '23 and had things on the agenda and topics to discuss," she said.
Council Vice President Mike Detmer, who ultimately voted in favor of the board having a one-year test period, said he thinks the board has value, but would function better if not affiliated with the county.
"It being a law and having to be constituted a certain way and done a certain way is holding an effort to preserve burial sites back," he said, later adding, "I think it could be more flexible and more dynamic as a stand-alone."
Detmer said as long as he is on the council, if someone comes to the council with "a salient point" about something in the county, it will get attention. That doesn't require a board, he said.
Before the council unanimously agreed to give the board a test period, Travers said the board had previously gone through an "extremely adversary" time that got to the point where some board members felt unsafe coming to the meetings. He said the county practically had to act as a referee.
"And that's not what we need on our boards," he said.
Pfeffer warned the this can't happen again.
"The last board that was assembled ... had brought things to this chamber," he said. "Had brought thoughts of slander. Had brought disagreements. I will not allow that to happen during these meetings."

title: Deepening Divides - Democrats Split Over 'Anti-Zionism Is Antisemitism' Measure; Poll Shows U.S. Racial, Generational Differences Over Israel-Hamas War
content:
Deepening Divides - Democrats Split Over 'Anti-Zionism Is Antisemitism' Measure; Poll Shows U.S. Racial, Generational Differences Over Israel-Hamas War

 December 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 954
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The U.S. House of Representatives approved a measure Wednesday declaring that "anti-Zionism is antisemitism" prompting a split among Democrats.A majority of House Democrats did not vote for the measure as a public opinion poll from Gallup shows substantial divides among Americans over the Israel-Hamas war in Gaza by age, race and political persuasion.
Whites, older voters and Republicans tend to back Israel in its war against Hamas after the Oct. 7 terror attacks while younger Americans, people of color and Democrats disapprove of Israel's air strikes and ground invasion of Gaza aimed at the Islamic militant group, according to a poll released Nov. 30 by Gallup.
The congressional measure condemning antisemitism passed with support from 216 Republicans and 95 Democrats. The resolution's most controversial component was plank equating anti-Zionism with antisemitism.
Zionism is a movement and belief system that supports the Jewish state of Israel in the Middle East.
"Zionism is the movement for the self-determination and statehood for the Jewish people in their ancestral homeland, the land of Israel," according to the Anti-Defamation League.
Thirteen Democrats voted against the measure and 105 Dems voted 'present' or did not vote neither supporting nor opposing the resolution.
One Republican - U.S.
Rep. Thomas Massie of Kentucky - voted against the anti-Zionism/antisemitism measure. Another four GOP lawmakers did not vote.
"Anti-Zionism isn't antisemitism," Massie said in a social media statement pointing to congressional remarks by U.S. Rep. Jerrold Nadler, D-New York, that some Orthodox and other Jews are not in agreement with modern Zionist constructs.
Nadler, the House's most senior Jewish members, said some Orthodox Jews believe only the Messiah can establish a new state of Israel and the measure can label progressive Jews and others critical of controversial judicial reforms in Israel as antisemitic.
Nadler and U.S. House Majority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, D-New York, were among those voting present on antisemitism measure.
The 13 Democratic no votes came from progressives who have been critical of Israel's war in Gaza against Hamas and U.S. support for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu after the Islamic militant group's Oct. 7 attacks.
Opponents of the measure - which referenced rises antisemitic vandalism and violence - included U.S. Reps. Jamaal Bowman and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York, Rashida Tlaib of Michigan, Ilhan Omar of Minnesota and Pramila Jayapal of Washington "We must be steadfast and clear in condemning antisemitism. The extreme GOP resolution on the floor today had no Democratic cosponsors and inappropriately said all anti-Zionism is antisemitism. Muddying the waters about what antisemitism is, is completely wrong and unhelpful," said Jayapal who had to clarify recent comments about whether she condemned Hamas' rapes and violence against women and girls in the Oct. 7.
GOP SUPPORTS MEASURE U.S. Rep. Andy Harris, a Republican representing the Eastern Shore, voted for the antisemitism measure along with Maryland Democratic U.S. Reps.
Steny Hoyer, David Trone, Dutch Ruppersberger and Kweisi Mfume. Maryland Democratic U.S. Rep. Jamie Raskin and John Sarbanes voted present.
House Republicans overwhelmingly backed the resolution which labels some pro-Palestinian slogans as antisemitic.
"More Jews were murdered on October 7th than on any other single day since the Holocaust.
Let that sink in. We have even seen members of this very body repeat blatantly antisemitic rhetoric and spread lies about Israel and her right to exist. Let me be absolutely clear: such hate has no place in the halls of Congress nor our national discourse. It is our fundamental responsibility as leaders and Members of Congress to condemn and fight these horrific acts of hate and discrimination against the Jewish community," said U.S. Rep. David Kustoff, R-Tennessee, one of the main sponsors of the resolution.
GOP backers of the measure point to a rise in antisemitic incidents and pro-Hamas and pro-Palestinian rhetoric that calls for or insinuates the destruction of Israel. They also point to the 106 no or present that did not support the measure - 105 of them from Democrat.
"The world has seen a drastic rise of antisemitism since October 7th that is deeply disheartening and extremely concerning," said U.S. Max Miller, R-Ohio. "Elected leaders must have the courage to condemn and fight all forms of domestic and global antisemitism.
While I am glad this resolution passed the House today, I am disappointed that 106 of my colleagues failed to take this opportunity to condemn antisemitism forcefully." AMERICA DIVIDED The Gallup poll released Nov. 30 shows significant splits over the Holy Land war by race, political party and gender.
The polls shows 71% of Republicans back Israel's war against Hamas in Gaza versus support from 36% of Democrats.

Charles humane society celebrates 50 years

 September 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ilana Williams iwilliams@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 547
 Words 

 Read News Document

 While many things have changed over the last half century, once constant has been the care provided to animals by the Humane Society of Charles County.The nonprofit organization is hosting its Golden Paws Gala on Oct. 10 to celebrate 50 years of taking care of sick, injured and homeless animals.
The event is from 6 p.m. to 10 p.m. at the Waldorf Jaycees at 3090 Crain Highway. Tickets are $75 per person.
Local humane societies are not directly attached to the National Humane Society, making the Humane Society of Charles County 100% reliant on local donations, grants and fundraising, Rayanne Benya, president of the board of directors for the Humane Society of Charles County, said.
In 1975, the humane society did not have a building. Instead, people who found an injured animal had to take them home, Anne Gardiner, founder of the Humane Society of Charles County, said. In 1981, the St. Charles County Association of Realtors gave the humane society the land for a shelter and it opened in 1983.
"It was tough getting started," Gardiner said. "One time I had [animals] in all three bathrooms and we were wondering what we were going to do."
The humane society has three sections: the kennel, which houses animals ranging from dogs and cats to guinea pigs, rabbits, lizards, turtles and snakes; the humane education program, which teaches students about animals and environmental science; and the clinic.
"Fifty years later, we're still here," Benya said. "We're here because we're supported by the residents of the county … and I think that's something to celebrate."
The gala will have a silent auction with dog baskets, Gardiner said. Other baskets will have household items. Wine and alcohol will be raffled, and there will also be gift cards for restaurants and businesses.
Live music will be performed by the "Original" Moonlighters and there will be a lipsologist — a person who "reads" lip prints — and a cash bar. Food is being donated by the Waldorf Jaycees.
"It's just for a great cause," Benya said. "We adopt out anywhere from one to 2,000 animals a year and all those animals need medical care."
Under the shelter's care, the humane society often has about 150 animals, an amount that can go up to 250 animals during the summer, Benya said.
Throughout the year, the shelter has around 200 volunteers who help with adoption events, laundry and being around the animals. They also want to build an animal medical facility for emergencies and a larger surgery wing.
"When [people] come here and they volunteer, they see the connection … between humans and animals," Benya said.
The humane society is holding its annual photo contest until Sept. 27, Benya said. People can send a cute photo of their pet that can be featured in a calendar.
On Sept. 20, they will have an adoption event at the humane society, Benya said.
The nonprofit also has a program called Freedom Friends year round that offers discounts to veterans to adopt animals for animals that have been in the shelter for six months or longer.
"It's important that we receive the funding … so we can continue to be here for the county," Benya said. "If we disappear, that's going to be devastating for the animal population.
For more information about the Oct. 10 gala or to purchase tickets, go to humanesocietycc.org.

title: 'He made Delaware famous': Native son George Thorogood honored for rock, blues chops
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
'He made Delaware famous': Native son George Thorogood honored for rock, blues chops

 June 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 1114
 Words 

 Read News Document

 George Thorogood, whose humble beginnings playing at the University of Delaware and at Newark bars led him to worldwide fame as one of rock 'n' roll's icons, returned to Newark last month for a celebration of his decades-long career.The celebration marked the 50th anniversary of Thorogood's first show, held on a small bandstand at UD's Lane Hall dormitory.
UD presented Thorogood with its highest non-academic honor, the Medal of Distinction, which is given to people who have made significant cultural, humanitarian, scientific or intellectual contributions to society or in their profession. Thorogood is the first entertainer to receive the award.
"We celebrate a rock 'n' roll and blues legend whose music has echoed for the last five decades," said Bill Lafferty, vice chair of the UD Board of Trustees. "A native Delawarean and former semi-pro baseball player, George Thorogood isn't just a musician. He's a storyteller whose guitar speaks the language of freedom and grit and maybe a little bit of rebellion, too."
After the formal presentation at the Green Mansion Bar on Main Street, officials unveiled a plaque honoring Thorogood near the site of the former Stone Balloon, where he played many shows. The sign designates the alley between the Washington House and Main Street Plaza as "Thorogood Alley."
"Thank you for what you've done for Newark, putting us on the rock 'n' roll map, and what you've done concurrently for the University of Delaware," Mayor Jerry Clifton said. "We can't say thank you enough for the contributions that you have made."
Thorogood accepted the honors with self-deprecating humor.
"It really proves something I always knew, and that is Delaware always had questionable taste," Thorogood quipped.
He added that he and bandmates Jeff Simon and Bill Blough were surprised to be invited to such a prestigious event.
"Jeff and Bill and I are taken aback because of all the places we weren't invited to, and all the places we were invited to leave," he joked. "So this is more than an honor, it's a shock."
Rock 'n' roll history
A native of Wilmington, Thorogood spent his early 20s traveling the country as an acoustic street musician. When he returned home for his sister's wedding in December 1973, Simon booked the Lane Hall gig without telling him. The two had grown up playing music together informally but had never played an official show.
Thorogood bought an electric guitar at a pawn shop, and the rest was history.
"We had the place rockin'," Thorogood recalled in a biography posted on his website. "We must have played 'One Bourbon' three times. It may have been a bit unpolished and primitive, but we were connecting with the audience in a major way. From that very first show, Jeff and I knew we were onto something."
After that show, George Thorogood and the Delaware Destroyers began playing gigs at Newark venues like the Stone Balloon, Deer Park Tavern and the Rathskeller, the UD-run beer hall that is now a study room in the Trabant University Center. They then expanded their reach regionally and nationally.
The band's major recording debut came in 1977 with the release of a self-titled album.
Thorogood's popularity increased in the 1980s, when the band opened for the Rolling Stones, appeared on Saturday Night Live and devised an aggressive touring schedule that included performances in all 50 states within 50 days.
His single "Bad to the Bone," which remains his most well-known song, debuted in 1982. Other hits include "I Drink Alone" and "One Bourbon, One Scotch and One Beer."
In the '80s, he owned a house on West Chestnut Hill Road in Newark.
In 1983, while at the height of his popularity, he returned to Lane Hall to perform a surprise concert in front of 500 people to mark the band's 10th anniversary.
Thorogood and the Destroyers are now in the midst of a tour celebrating their 50th anniversary, which was delayed by a year due to Thorogood's health issues. One day after the ceremony in Newark, they are scheduled to perform at the Freeman Arts Pavilion in Selbyville.
Thorogood's contribution to Newark didn't stop at music. In the late 1970s, he built a baseball field at the corner of Casho Mill Road and Barksdale Road because the city was lacking space to play the sport. A few years later, he sold the field to the city, which renamed it Leroy Hill Park. The field is now used by Newark American Little League and Newark Charter School.
'He did a lot of good for the city'
Melissa Forsythe, owner of Rainbow Records, came to Friday's event with several of Thorogood's albums for him to autograph. The rocker's music continues to sell well at Rainbow, she said.
His impact goes even farther than that, she added.
"He's given people the reality check that it's possible to be from Delaware and do something cool," she said.
Demitri Theodoropoulos remembers being 11 or 12 years old, playing baseball on the field Thorogood built.
"Every once in a while, he would show up and almost coach us," Theodoropoulos said, adding that he didn't realize at the time who he was. "We had no idea; he was just this guy who showed up."
As the owner of Wonderland Records, Theodoropoulos certainly knows who Thorogood is now.
"That blues-rock crossover, that's kind of where he is," he said. "He's not full-on blues, and he's not pop rock. He's one of the very few crossover musicians. A lot of people learned to play guitar to his albums."
Dave Mackenzie, the longtime engineer at the campus radio station WVUD, said Thorogood played several on-air shows to help the station when it was in its early years. He also remembered working sound for one of Thorogood's Deer Park shows in 1978.
"It was New Year's Eve, downstairs in the back room," Mackenzie said. "It was loud, and the train came through every now and then. It was a fun night."
Bill Stevenson, who ran the legendary Stone Balloon, recalled that when Thorogood was starting out as a solo musician, he wasn't old enough to get into the music venue.
"He used to sit out in front on the wall, play his guitar with the guitar case open and make as much as the musicians made," Stevenson said.
Within a few years, though, Thorogood became a mainstay at the Balloon, playing some 50 shows there.
"He made Delaware famous," Stevenson said. "Everyone in the world knows who George Thorogood is. He did a lot of good for the city."
The fact that Thorogood was a regular at the Balloon helped Stevenson book other prominent acts.
"He brought a lot of credibility to the town," Stevenson said. "We had Bruce Springsteen, Metallica. I couldn't have done it without him being from here. I would keep telling everyone back in the '70s and '80s, 'Well, George plays here all the time.'"

title: National Museum of Asian Art presents 'Park Chan-kyong: Gathering'
content:
National Museum of Asian Art presents 'Park Chan-kyong: Gathering'

 August 17, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 931
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Seoul-based artist Park Chankyong has gained international recognition for his use of photography and film to examine the complex history of modern Korea."Park Chan-kyong: Gathering" will be the first solo presentation of his work in a major U.S. museum.The exhibition will feature a range of works that highlight Park's masterful use of the photographic medium to explore the enduring traces of tradition, history and disaster in contemporary society. It will be on view at the Smithsonian's National Museum of Asian Art Oct. 7 through Oct. 13, 2024.This will be the inaugural exhibition in the National Museum of Asian Art's modern and contemporary galleries, opening as the museum celebrates its centennial year. The galleries will become a space dedicated to engaging visitors in the myriad formats and media employed by artists to examine Asian society from the late-20th century to today, in context with Asian art dating from antiquity to the present that is on view throughout the museum.Park's multi-channel video, "Citizen's Forest," will anchor this exhibition of five recent works. A panoramic video presented in the format of a monumental landscape scroll painting, "Citizen's Forest" draws on the poetry of Kim Su-yeong (1921-68), Minjung painting and folk culture to reflect on major tragedies in South Korea's history from the late 19th century to the present. In "Belated Bosal" and "Fukushima: Autoradiography," inverted images and the natural landscape convey the inescapable sense of ecological disaster.Another installment in Park's study of the history of North and South Koreas, a series of still and moving image portraits titled "Child Soldier" reimagines the presence of a lonely North Korean soldier.In-gallery public programs with the artist and guest speakers will accompany the exhibition, including a screening of a short film by Park and an artist-led discussion Oct. 22 (details below).The exhibition is an important opportunity to introduce visitors to a major figure in contemporary Asian art and engage them in multisensorial experiences and insights into modern and contemporary Korea.Park studied fine arts at Seoul National University and earned a Master of Fine Arts at the California Institute of the Arts. Weaving together art historical and literary references, along with folk traditions and current events, he creates visually powerful works grounded in the enduring impact of rapid socioeconomic development and the Cold War on South Korean politics and society."As the National Museum of Asian Art enters its next 100 years at the dawn of what is fast becoming the Asian century, we are even more committed to telling complex stories about objects from a variety of perspectives," said the museum's director Chase F. Robinson. "We are also dedicated to engaging new audiences with Asian arts, cultures and societies and using our platform to address present-day issues.The rich dialogue and learning engendered by contemporary exhibitions like Park Chan-kyong's enable us to reach these goals." "I have followed Park Chan-kyong's work for years and am grateful to him for collaborating with us on this exciting project," said Carol Huh, associate curator of contemporary Asian art. "The opportunity to learn more about his use of the photographic medium and powerfully nuanced insights into Korean society today is an ideal way to usher in the next landmark chapter in the museum's groundbreaking contemporary Asian art program.As the museum embarks on its second century, this exhibition deepens our mission to examine evolving perspectives on the histories and cultures of Asia." Following "Park Chan-kyong: Gathering," the museum's new modern and contemporary galleries will feature an exhibition of works by contemporary artist Munem Wasif (Bangladesh), opening in late 2024. Both exhibitions will treat the artists' practices and relevant artistic and social context in greater depth, offering alternative viewpoints on their respective homelands.PROGRAMIn conjunction with "Gathering," Park will come to the National Museum of Asian Art to screen his short film Night Fishing and to discuss his work on Sunday, Oct. 22, at 2 p.m. in the Meyer Auditorium Shot entirely on an iPhone, this surreal short was co-directed by Park and his brother, Park Chanwook, and won the Golden Bear for Best Short Film at the 61st Berlin International Film Festival.In it, a fisherman feels a tug on his line, and much to his surprise, pulls a woman (K-pop star Lee Junghyun) out of the water. She comes alive and is revealed to be a shaman priestess who performs a ritual in honor of a drowned man. Like "Citizen's Forest," a video work on view in the exhibition, Night Fishing was inspired by Park's fascination with Korean shamanism.(Dir.: PARKING CHANCE [Park Chan-wook and Park Chankyong], Korea, Korea, 2011, 33 min., DCP, Korean with English subtitles) ABOUT THE NATIONAL MUSEUM OF ASIAN ARTThe Smithsonian's National Museum of Asian Art is committed to preserving, exhibiting, researching and interpreting art in ways that deepen our collective understanding of Asia and the world. Home to more than 46,000 objects, the museum stewards one of North America's largest and most comprehensive collections of Asian art, with works dating from antiquity to the present from China, Japan, Korea, South Asia, Southeast Asia and the Islamic world. Its rich holdings bring the arts of Asia into direct dialogue with an important collection of 19th-and early 20th-century American works, providing an essential platform for creative collaboration and cultural exchange between the United States, Asia and the Middle East.Its galleries, laboratories, archives and library are located on the National Mall in Washington, D.C. The museum is free and open to the public 364 days a year (closed Dec. 25). For more information, visit www.asia.si.edu.

title: Local lightning rods: Social media, national divisions changing local politics
author: Mike Sunnucks APG National enterprise editor
content:
Local lightning rods: Social media, national divisions changing local politics

 March 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks APG National enterprise editor | Section: News 
 
 449
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Megan Cook, Russ Nelson and Ann Groves Lloyd are mayors of small towns in Maryland, Montana and Wisconsin.Nelson has been the mayor of Belgrade, Montana, for 20 years.
Karen Rose has been with Sarasota County Schools in Florida for more than three decades serving as a special education teacher, middle school principal and since 2020 on the local school board.
Over their tenures, the quartet and local officials across the country have seen the exponential growth of social media and its impacts on civil discourse, as well as the increasing intersections between divisive national politics and what's happening at the community level.
School board, city council and county commission meetings have all become venues for fights over controversial curriculums and books, COVID rules, drag shows at public libraries and national issues with advocates from the left and right looking for local debates on immigration, abortion and Israel's war in Gaza.
Rose said public comments at school board meetings can be very political and very partisan. "It's very organized," Rose said.
Social media, with its expansive reach, along with online meetings allow more residents and businesses to engage with and keep tabs on local governments and schools. That can also help bring more transparency to city halls, local law enforcement and school districts.
"The more information that we share with the public about what's happening in town, the better. We also have a live feed for all of our council, board and commission meetings. If residents aren't able to make it, they can always watch the recordings from our website," said Cook, mayor of Easton.
But social media also magnifies broader contemporary distrust of the media, government, politicians and other institutions. It can also bring rumor mills and coarse discourse.
"From a city perspective, we just wish people would pick up the phone and call us. We are constantly fighting the rumor mill," said Groves Lloyd, mayor of Lodi, Wisconsin (a small town near Madison).
Groves Lloyd identifies herself as a "progressive feminist" and "small town mayor" on her X/Twitter account where she is no fan of former president Donald Trump. But the Wisconsin mayor said she's pulled back on her progressive posts, especially on Facebook, because of the atmosphere of social media.
In Montana, Nelson, the mayor of Belgrade (which has a population approaching 13,000 people), worries all the political tensions at the local level discourages candidates for office and shortens tenures for staff and officeholders. He avoids social media altogether.
"I'm not on Facebook. I'm not on social media," said Nelson. "You can call me, or if you need me, you can text me. That's my technology."
For a more expansive look at the issue check out our story online and in our national e-edition on Monday, March 11.

title: Excellent customer service
content:
Excellent customer service

 My wife and I were born and raised in Baltimore. We are in our mid 70s and since our childhood we have always vacationed on the Eastern Shore. Twenty years ago we relocated to Northeast, Tennessee, but still annually come back to the Eastern Shore to get our "seafood and steamed crab fix." However, I am writing to you not about your delicious food but about the kindness shown to us by Brent Spurry, owner of the Spurry Tire Company.Our story: We had just finished four glorious days in St. Michaels and while gassing up the car for the 450-mile return trip home, I noticed the valence (or mud guard) located under my front bumper was hanging down. Concerned that it would completely break away while on the highway, I began looking for a repair shop. It was Saturday, and I learned many repair shops were closed. In desperation I asked a kindly person tending our hotel's lawn for help. He directed me to the Spurry Tire Company on Elliot Road. He said be sure to ask for the owner, Brent Spurry.After a 20-minute ride including through picturesque downtown Easton, I arrived at the Spurry Tire Company. It was a larger business than I anticipated with six bays (all full) and maybe a dozen employees (all very busy). The waiting room was also full of customers which I thought didn't bode well for an out-of-state vehicle with a hanging mud-guard being repaired anytime soon.I reluctantly asked to see Brent Spurry and to my surprise he appeared within a minute. I related my story, and he said his bays were full but when one became available someone would take a look. I walked outside to ponder my next move (should I risk the trip home).Just then I heard a pleasant voice say "We are putting your car in an open bay.Ten minutes later same voice says "all fixed you're good to go." Surprised and grateful I asked, "What do I owe you?"[[---]] see the office was the reply. I return to the waiting room (it was even more crowded)."Hello, I'm Mr. Townsend, you folks were kind to fix my car, what do I owe you?" Nothing was the reply from the counter clerk. I said obviously this is a busy place but can I see Mr. Spurry?Within minutes Brent Spurry appeared. I thanked him and politely insisted that I pay him for the work.He smiled and said, "No charge" [[---]] even though I'm from out-of-state and he will likely never see me again [[---]] He said, "No charge." In a flash he returned to the shop. I turned to leave and said to the crowded waiting room that they were fortunate to have a Spurry Tire Company in their city.A lady remarked for all to hear "we know." I wrote this letter because I wanted others to know about Brent Spurry and his kindness and business practices.He is a perfect example of practicing excellent customer service even to someone from out-of-state.JERRY AND PEGGY TOWNSENDNortheast, Tennessee

 ST. MICHAELS - The Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum will celebrate the Bay's favorite bivalve at OysterFest on Saturday, Oct. 28, from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.CBMM's OysterFest features oysters served a variety of ways, along with other local fare, craft beer, and spirits, plus live music on two stages, an oyster stew competition, a full schedule of demonstrations and presentations, children's activities, and more.Guests can savor Chesapeake Bay oysters, with both raw and cooked options available, from the Talbot Watermen Association and other local oyster farms.There will also be a variety of Chesapeake delicacies and other food offerings via local vendors available for purchase, plus a beverage selection that includes specialty cocktails and an array of local craft beer options.For OysterFest, guests will enter campus through CBMM's new Welcome Center, getting a first look at the new building overlooking Fogg's Cove and the chance to shop in the new Museum Store inside. (Please note that the exhibition spaces within the Welcome Center are not yet open to the public.)Purchase your tickets in advance now for this rain-or-shine event and learn more at cbmm.org/oysterfest.The always-popular oyster stew competition invites guests to sample offerings from various local restaurants and then vote for their favorite to decide which chefs will claim the coveted title.There will be live music on both sides of campus all day long, with stages on both the Tolchester Beach Bandstand and Fogg's Landing. Swamp Donkey Newgrass will be playing the historic bandstand, bringing its unique "newgrass" sound with a combination of genre-spanning original songs and covers to OysterFest for the fifth time.Guests can head to Van Lennep Auditorium throughout the day to hear from a variety of guest speakers sponsored by the Upper Shore Regional Folklife Center through the Maryland Traditions Program of the Maryland State Arts Council. The offerings include a series of panels related to CBMM's special exhibition The Changing Chesapeake and a history presentation from Dr. Clara Small.The American Chesapeake Club will be on hand to discuss Maryland's official dog, the Chesapeake Bay retriever, and showcase its retrieving ability, while the 100 Hundred Shores Project will offer the opportunity for guests to dye their own shirts using water from the Miles River.There's also an oyster slurp-off contest to add to the friendly competition, plus a wide range of Chesapeake-themed children's activities, including games, model boat building, and story time.Guests can get in the festive spirit by purchasing OysterFest gear in the new Museum Store, showcasing this year's featured historic oyster tin from CBMM's collection. The one-gallon tin, packed in the 1940s by W.E. Rigging & Co., out of Crisfield, Md., is emblazoned on shirts and stickers, as well as the commemorative mugs that will be used for the oyster stew competition.This year, OysterFest is generously sponsored by M&T Bank with support from Eastern Shore Tents & Events, Kelly Distributors, and What's Up Media.OysterFest admission is $7 for museum member adults and active and retired members of the military (with ID); $19 for non-member adults; $16 for seniors (ages 65 and up) and college students (with ID); $7 for non-member children ages 6-17; and free for member children 6-17, and all children 5 and under. For safety reasons, non-service dogs need to be kept home during museum festivals, including OysterFest.

 President Donald Trump targeted Maryland Gov. Wes Moore (D) in a Truth Social post on Aug. 24, saying he may reconsider federal dollars for rebuilding the Francis Scott Key Bridge and could "send in the troops" to Baltimore.Over 2,000 National Guard troops are deployed in Washington, D.C., with Trump alluding to other potential deployments around the country, including Baltimore.
On Aug. 21, Moore wrote a letter to Trump, inviting him to Maryland to see the progress on crime that the state has made.
"There is no higher priority for me, as the governor of my state, than the safety of my people. This is an issue of both professional and personal significance. I grew up in and around communities left behind by people in power, who sought to weaponize the pain of their constituents through hollow talking points that never changed the reality on the ground," Moore wrote in the letter.
Moore cited recent crime statistics around the state, saying that he is deeply encouraged by the progress he has seen.
"Homicides in Maryland are down statewide by 20% since my inauguration two and a half years ago. In the first six months of 2025, the Baltimore Police Department continued to see double-digit reductions in gun violence, including a 22% decrease in homicides and a 19% decrease in non-fatal shootings from the year before," Moore wrote. "If there's anything Maryland has proven over the last two years, it's that we can achieve performance without being performative."
At the end of the letter, Moore invited Trump to attend a public safety walk in September on a date of the president's choosing.
"Governor Wes Moore of Maryland has asked, in a rather nasty and provocative tone, that I 'walk the streets of Maryland' with him," Trump wrote in a post on Truth Social on Aug. 24. "I assume he is talking about out-of-control, crime-ridden, Baltimore?"
Trump furthered that he "would much prefer that [Moore] clean up this crime disaster" before he comes to the area for a walk.
"Wes Moore's record on Crime is a very bad one, unless he fudges his figures on crime like many of the other 'Blue States' are doing. But if Wes Moore needs help, like Gavin Newscum [sic] did in [Los Angeles], I will send in the 'troops,' which is being done in nearby D.C., and quickly clean up the crime," Trump wrote.
Trump finished, saying that he gave "Moore a lot of money to fix his demolished bridge."
"I will now have to rethink that decision?" Trump said.
Moore responded to Trump's post on Truth Social, saying, "President Bone Spurs will do anything to get out of walking — even if that means spouting off more lies about the progress we're making on public safety in Maryland."
In an MSNBC interview following the exchange, Moore emphasized that federal bridge funding was authorized by Congress and President Joe Biden, not Trump.
"The 100% cost share that is now being done between the state of Maryland and the federal government was not authorized by Donald Trump," Moore said. "It was authorized by Congress, and it was authorized by President Biden.
"Once again, the president's showing this is not about policy. This is not about supporting your people. This is not about what it is going to do to port workers and small businesses. This is an ideology, and it's a deeply dangerous ideology. Frankly, again, [the funding] he's talking about pulling that he did not give us in the first place."

title: Time for DeSantis to rock and roll with Trump - COMMENTARY
content:
Time for DeSantis to rock and roll with Trump - COMMENTARY

 August 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A6 | Section: Opinions 
 
 564
