title: A map geek’s quest to clean the nation, 1 watershed at a time
author: Alisha Camacho Capital News Service
content:
A map geek’s quest to clean the nation, 1 watershed at a time

 December 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Alisha Camacho Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 1411
 Words 

 Read News Document

 By 11 a.m., Jon Merryman had collected 45 tires, 38 bags of trash, packs of shingles, a mattress, a playpen and remnants of an accident swept under a guardrail near College Park, Maryland.Merryman, 62, was frustrated and restless. The Nov. 6 election hadn't gone his way. A veteran and a man of action, he turned to a lifelong passion to cope: picking up trash.
Over the following days, he cleaned up roadsides in 22 counties spanning Virginia and West Virginia.
"I call it channeling my anger," Merryman said, tone dropping.
Physical work helps him maintain his emotional and mental health. When he returned home to Catonsville, Merryman felt more rejuvenated and ready to face what came next. For him, cleaning up litter is a way to reclaim control, one piece of trash at a time, in a world that can feel overwhelming.
"I want people to feel like one person can make a difference," he said.
Merryman traces his passion for protecting the environment to campaigns from his childhood. Campaigns like "Smokey the Bear." "Woodsy the Owl." The 1970s commercial "Keep America Beautiful: The Crying Indian."
While controversial today, the "Keep America Beautiful" ad had a simple message for 7-year-old Merryman: "People start pollution. People can stop it." Inspired, he planned a post-Halloween mission to clean up wrappers and litter. With a full bucket, Merryman marched down to a storm drain, thinking that's where the trash should go.
"Thank God an adult was there," he said. The passerby explained how storm drains lead to rivers. He didn't know it yet, but Merryman would dedicate much of his adult life to rectifying this mistake.
The makings of a soldierMerryman's cousins, conservationists on Maryland's Eastern Shore, took him under their wings and ignited a passion for studying the environment. They invited him on bird banding and counting trips. Merryman remembers the sky filling with "rivers of birds" for 15 minutes at a time. Clicker in hand, he counted birds until his hand grew weary.
"You're witnessing the miracles of being on earth when you see stuff like that," Merryman said.
His cousins later dissuaded him from becoming a marine biologist.
"They got me geared up for this life of studying animals, then said, 'Oh, you don't want to do that. It's a life of chasing grants.'"
Merryman entered the University of Delaware as a biology major. Switched to geology. Jumped to civil engineering. His GPA plummeted. He pivoted to part-time status while working for the university. Eventually, he found his footing in geography while programming educational software. Also minored in photography.
His first summer out of college, Merryman worked as a volunteer ranger at the Grand Canyon, giving talks, leading groups and picking up trash in front of the visitor center. "Funny thing is, that's what I love to do now: pick up trash."
The staff liked him and encouraged him to apply for a seasonal park ranger job, but then Congress slashed funding, so the job didn't exist.
Merryman took on seasonal jobs. While working in the Everglades, he saw a billboard promoting the army's college fund.
It offered $20K for two years of service.
"Great option," he thought. He enlisted in the army and spent six years in the National Guard.
'My wife puts up with a lot'When Merryman returned to civilian life, he worked in instructional technology. "As it turns out, there's a lot of commonality between arranging the elements of a map and arranging the elements on a computer screen," he said.
But his passion for the environment remained. One day, while working at Lockheed Martin, Merryman came across a trash-strewn creek and park. He spent five years turning it into a sustainable habitat.
His hobby of picking up trash also found its way home. "My driveway was full, I mean seriously, full of scrap metal," he said. He sold the metal from cleanups to fund his kids' robotics team. "The things we do," Merryman chuckled.
Through it all, he said, it took a lot of patience from his wife, Kirsten. "The spouses that put up with it are angels, too. They are. My wife puts up with a lot."
Turns out, so do his kids.
Litter everywhere in the middle of nowhere
A common conundrum Merryman encounters is people acknowledging a problem but not taking responsibility. "Someone else is doing the littering. It's those people," they think.
Merryman became determined to show that littering is everyone's problem. During a road trip with his son to Los Angeles, an idea emerged, and they cleaned up trash in one county per state, adding two counties for Texas.
When they arrived "in the middle of nowhere" in Turkey, Texas, Merryman found "litter everywhere." He wanted people to realize that we are all responsible for this pile of trash because of all the things we buy and the resources we use.
To illustrate the extent of trash pollution, he started placing green dots on a map of counties he'd clean up.
"I'm a map geek," Merryman said. He had been tracking all the counties he visited for years, a hobby shared by fellow geographers. Now, he aims to pick up trash in every county for as long as possible.
Recently, he picked his daughter up from school in Ithaca, New York. As they left Ithaca and crossed over into the Chesapeake Bay watershed, an idea "dawned on me," he said.
He'd picked up trash in counties between Ithaca and Baltimore, having done this drive many times. "I put those on the map," Merryman said when he realized he was nearly halfway done. "I bet I could do them all" in the watershed.
He now focuses on watersheds rather than state lines. Water carries pollution across borders, so "state boundaries don't matter as much as the watershed," he said.
On Dec. 1, 2024, Merryman reached his goal. He picked up trash in all 206 counties in the Chesapeake Bay watershed. Bringing his total count to 524. One-sixth of all counties in the United States.
Sharkey d'SharkOn February 2, 2022, at 2:22 p.m., Merryman retired — a moment he carefully planned. "I walked out the door," said Merryman. "I just thought it was funny."
A few months later, Merryman found his retirement buddy, Sharkey d' Shark, on the side of the road. The abandoned toy-turned-sidekick became a playful way to engage others in cleanups.
Sharkey has a social media presence. "It's a lot easier to have a back-and-forth conversation with Sharkey," Merryman said, "as opposed to writing posts and getting crickets in response."
Merryman hopes Sharkey can help educate and inspire younger generations to partake in cleanups. For now, "about 90% of Sharky's fans are middle-aged women," he laughed.
Nature is innocentWhen not traveling to pick up trash, Merryman volunteers with Lights Out Baltimore, searching for dead or injured birds hit by windows due to disorienting artificial lights.
"Nature, as far as I'm concerned, is all innocent," Merryman said. Migrating birds navigate at night using the moon and stars, but lights lead them to windows. "There's a reason it's happening. It's not because the bird's stupid," he said. The birds can't see the glass.
Not long ago, Merryman found an old Facebook post when he first joined the group and held a bird for the first time in decades. Now, he's active in several Facebook groups where he educates others about window strikes. Sharing photos of the dead birds tends to upset people, especially those who have already seen them.
On the one hand, Merryman speaks to newcomers who aren't aware of this issue and spreads awareness "over and over and over again." On the other hand, some people complain and don't want to see the photos.
"I'm sorry if it makes you feel squeamish," Merryman said, his tone serious. He paused. "Actually, I'm not. I'm not sorry," he said with a wry laugh. "I hope that it will make you care about it."
It is a difficult line to walk — getting people to care without turning them away. "I'm just not good at drawing that line personally," he admitted.
But he is good at showing up and doing the dirty work. "I'm happy to be the grunt, the foot soldier."
Merryman has a plan for the rest of his retirement. He is going to pick up trash in every county in the United States. Until he physically can't anymore. Then he hopes to write a book.
So far, he's crossed off Arizona, Vermont, New Hampshire, Maryland, Virginia, Delaware, and New Jersey while nearing the finish line in Pennsylvania and Virginia.
Maybe he won't reach his goal. "But I'm gonna die trying." And maybe the world will be a little cleaner, with a few more birds in it.

title: TODAY IN HISTORY/May 29
author: Staff Writer
content:
TODAY IN HISTORY/May 29

 May 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Columns 
 
 527
 Words

 On May 29, 1988, President Ronald Reagan and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev opened their historic summit in Moscow.On this date:
In 1765, Patrick Henry denounced the Stamp Act before Virginia's House of Burgesses.
In 1790, Rhode Island became the 13th original colony to ratify the United States Constitution.
In 1848, Wisconsin became the 30th state of the union.
In 1914, the Canadian ocean liner RMS Empress of Ireland sank in the St. Lawrence River in eastern Quebec after colliding with the Norwegian cargo ship SS Storstad; of the 1,477 people on board the Empress of Ireland, 1,012 died. (The Storstad sustained only minor damage.)
In 1953, Mount Everest was conquered as Edmund Hillary of New Zealand and Tensing Norgay of Nepal became the first climbers to reach the summit.
In 1977, Janet Guthrie became the first woman to race in the Indianapolis 500, finishing in 29th place (the winner was A.J. Foyt).
In 1985, 39 people were killed at the European Cup Final in Brussels, Belgium, when rioting broke out and a wall separating British and Italian soccer fans collapsed.
In 2009, a judge in Los Angeles sentenced music producer Phil Spector to 19 years to life in prison for the murder of actor Lana Clarkson. (Spector remained in prison until his death in January 2021.)
In 2012, Doc Watson, the Grammy-award winning folk musician whose lightning-fast style of flatpicking influenced guitarists around the world, died in North Carolina at age 89.
In 2014, Starbucks closed thousands of stores for part of the day to hold training sessions for employees on unconscious bias, in response to the arrests of two Black men at one of its Philadelphia stores for sitting in the Starbucks without ordering anything.
In 2015, the Obama administration formally removed Cuba from the U.S. terrorism blacklist.
In 2017, Manuel Noriega, a onetime U.S. ally who was ousted as Panama's dictator by an American invasion in 1989, died at age 83.
In 2018, ABC canceled the reboot of "Roseanne," after star Roseanne Barr's tweet that referred to former Obama adviser Valerie Jarrett as a product of the Muslim Brotherhood and the "Planet of the Apes."
In 2019, in his first public remarks on the Russia investigation, special counsel Robert Mueller said charging President Donald Trump with a crime was "not an option" because of federal rules, but he emphasized that the investigation did not exonerate the president.
In 2020, fired Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin was arrested and charged with third-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter in the death of George Floyd. (He would be convicted in April 2021 on those charges as well as second-degree unintentional murder.)
In 2021, actor Gavin MacLeod, best known for his roles on "The Mary Tyler Moore Show" and "The Love Boat," died at age 90, and Grammy-winning singer B.J. Thomas, who hit the charts with songs including "Hooked on a Feeling" and "Raindrops Keep Fallin' On My Head," died at 78.
In 2022, President Joe Biden sought to comfort a city grieving the killings of 19 elementary school pupils and two teachers at the hands of a lone gunman in Uvalde, Texas. Faced with chants of "do something" as he departed a church service to meet privately with the families, Biden responded: "We will."

 The Spiralis Gallery and The Zebra Gallery are presenting a new exhibit "Flower Power."The exhibition runs through May 31.
The Spiralis Gallery and The Zebra Gallery are both located at 5 N. Harrison Street in Easton.
"The exhibit will explore the myriad ways that floral motifs make their way into art. The show celebrates the intricate and extraordinary magic flowers bring to a piece of artwork," according to an announcement.
The Spiralis Gallery is owned by Gail Patterson and features Contemporary Afro Caribbean art. The Zebra Gallery is owned by Susan Schauer John, an award-winning local fiber artist.
"Joy, sorrow, birth, death, serenity and exuberance — all of these emotions and human experiences are marked with flowers," said Gail Patterson.
Featured artists in the Zebra Gallery will include Howard Lapp, Ingrid Matuszewski, Charlotte Harron, Susan Fay Schauer John, Sheryl Southwick, Carol Newmeyer, Cindy Winnick, and Elizabeth Casquerio. Featured artists in the Spiralis Gallery will include Tejiri Esewhaye, Hezekiah Obidare, Lee Mason York, Zsudayka Nzinga, Ernesto Beckford, Gerard, and Fares Micue.
"Artists have long used flowers to express these subtleties, and this show will examine the connection," said Schauer John.

title: Common ground: Citizens Connect launches with focus on saving Eastern Neck
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Common ground: Citizens Connect launches with focus on saving Eastern Neck

 August 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 768
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Inspired by Washington College's class "Bridging the Divide," Chestertown residents Joan Caivano and Eileen Kessler formed Citizens Connect, a forum designed to find common ground among people who disagree politically.Kessler said Citizens Connect's mission during the administration of President Donald Trump is to bring attention to the impact of federal policies and budget cuts on local interests.
Caivano said since Trump was elected, there are many areas of concern — including immigration, health care and education — that the group seeks to discuss in a nonpartisan way.
The group's first public meeting focused on Eastern Neck Island, a major tourist attraction in Kent County and the Upper Shore.
The discussion, "Eastern Neck: Can it Survive Federal Budget Cuts," was held Aug. 18 at the Unitarian Universalist Church in Chestertown, where Caivano and Kessler are members.
"The survival of Eastern Neck Island is in jeopardy," Kessler told an audience of about 80.
Guest speakers included Friends of Eastern Neck President Bill Burton and Vice President Bonnie Ford. They described the work of their nonprofit organization, which has about 300 members and 50 volunteers. The group assists the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, which maintains the refuge and whose work could be threatened by budget cuts.
Burton, who has worked in environmental sciences for 44 years, said the group has been instrumental in projects such as repairing the slate roof of the 1930 lodge and replacing windows, a $55,000 expense. They also staff the visitor center, tend the butterfly garden and help with repairs wherever needed.
But those services could be threatened, he said.
Ford said the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service is part of the U.S. Department of the Interior, so cuts to the department affect the refuge.
Ford added that over many years, there have been cuts regardless of which party controlled the White House.
In Maryland, Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge, located 12 miles south of Cambridge, operates the Chesapeake Marshlands complex of four refuges, one of which is Eastern Neck Island.
The Blackwater staff has diminished over time.
"In 2007, there were 23 employees. Currently there are 11," Ford said. "And Eastern Neck currently has no on-site staff but relies on those from Blackwater."
Ford said although the problem seemed bipartisan, Elon Musk's email across federal agencies concerning voluntary retirement and mandatory buyouts led to further staff reductions.
"Some at the beginning of the year took the retirement offer and Blackwater staff dropped from 14 to 11," she said.
Additionally, an executive order signed Feb. 25 requires department heads to submit a reduction in force plan. The speakers said this has decreased morale among U.S. Fish and Wildlife personnel.
The reduction in force plan has not been made public, but Friends of Eastern Neck want to be proactive. Their goal is to avoid further losses and keep staffing at current levels.
Burton said the staff is essential.
"Staff are not just there to mow the lawn," he said. "They are specialists and biologists employing scientific techniques to maximize the refuge's potential. They do controlled burns. They raise and lower levels in ponds. They grow habitats for wildlife and much more."
Without their services, the refuge would close, Burton said. Friends of Eastern Neck said it is a place they cannot lose, drawing 70,000 visitors annually.
Ford urged attendees to join a letter-writing campaign to local, state and federal lawmakers. More information is available on the Friends of Eastern Neck website, friendsofeasternneck.org.
"Don't just assume because of politics they will not seek to protect the refuge. Seeing people care about this has been a very humbling experience for me," she said.
She said there is common ground between hunters, anglers, environmentalists and politicians on the need to "maintain a refuge … as a refuge."
Public comment produced more ideas.
One person suggested involving the public school system by having children draw pictures of the refuge to influence lawmakers. Another suggested mobilizing people to raise awareness about climate change. Someone else recommended enlisting business bureaus.
Ducks Unlimited and other outdoor organizations have strong lobbying influence, said one woman active in politics.
She noted that U.S. Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.), who serves on the appropriations committee, and U.S. Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md. 1st) are particularly involved in this issue.
People exited the meeting energized and united over the local issue, which pleased the organizers. Afterward, membership in Citizens Connect increased, Burton said.
"I think Burton and Ford did a beautiful job speaking across the political spectrum and to the community," Kessler said.
The next Citizens Connect meeting will be Sept. 15 at the Kent Cultural Alliance. The topic will be how to talk with people from different backgrounds and political views. Anthony Flaccavento, founding director of the Rural-Urban Bridge Initiative, will be the guest speaker.

title: Talbot keeps it simple on way to championship
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Talbot keeps it simple on way to championship

 July 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 426
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Talbot manager Rich White's approach was fundamentally simple."Just play baseball," White told his Talbot team heading into the District 6 Senior League championship June 26. "We laid the groundwork with the practices and they knew what the expectations were. Just play baseball the way they know how, and don't do too much."
Talbot followed those instructions while riding the solid one-two pitching punch of Nathan Merchant and Couper Barletta on the way to a 5-2 title-clinching victory over Dorchester at Hog Neck.
Talbot was scheduled to play Brunswick on Saturday in the first round of the state tournament in Berlin.
"It's a fantastic group of kids," said White, whose team won the best-of-three series 2-1. "We're pulling them from three different high schools (Easton, St. Michaels, Saints Peter and Paul). But they jelled well. They've been accepting of, I don't want to say a diminished role. Let's say they were a shortstop at their school, but we're asking them to play left field. And everyone has bought into the team concept. Everyone has contributed."
Talbot won the series opener 13-3 in Hurlock on June 24. Dorchester knotted the series at one-all the following night with a 14-7 win, setting up the decisive Game 3.
Dorchester took a 1-0 lead in the top of the first inning of the title game on Jackson Nehring's RBI single.
But Talbot responded with a four-run rally in the bottom of the first for a lead it never surrendered.
Buel Jensen knocked in the tying run with a fielder's choice. Jace Elliott and Finley Carter each worked back-to-back bases-loaded walks to make it 3-1. Brody McDaniel, Talbot's No. 9 hitter, then laid down a two-out RBI bunt single to give Talbot a three-run lead after one complete.
Merchant got the starting nod on the mound for Talbot and yielded two unearned runs and two hits over four innings, striking out two and walking three. Barletta came on in relief to seal the victory.
"It was very effective," White said of his team's pitching combination. "Both guys. Different styles. Merchant gets a lot of weak contact, and then Barletta comes in and he's more of a strikeout, power pitcher.
McDaniel finished 2 for 3 with a pair of RBIs, and Elliott also drove in two runs. Talbot finished with 10 walks, with Ben White and Carter each drawing two. Jensen added two stolen bases.
Nehring, Dorchester's clean-up hitter, finished 2 for 3. Dorchester totaled seven stolen bases, led by Ryan Robinson, who had three.
Carson Weber started on the mound for Dorchester, allowing four runs but no hits in 2/3 of an inning.

title: Public weighs in on emergency food processing residual bill
author: Tom McCall
content:
Public weighs in on emergency food processing residual bill

 August 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 561
 Words 

 Read News Document

 An earlier version of this story contained incorrect information about the status of the bill. The commissioners did not vote on the bill Tuesday.DENTON — The Caroline County Commissioners held a public hearing on a controversial bill concerning the permitting of food processing residuals Aug. 6.
If the bill is passed after the commissioners' third hearing on Aug. 20, storing these residuals in Caroline County would require a permit. The bill also allows for inspection and civil or criminal penalties if a storage site is found to be in violation.
"This is not banning storage of food processing residuals," Commissioner Larry Porter said. "If someone feels strongly about using it as a soil amendment and wants to store it, they can come in and apply once these regulations are set."
The bill requires the use of closed-top storage tanks for food processing residuals, going a step further than state regulations passed during this year's General Assembly. House Bill 991, which took effect July 1, created a state permitting process under the Maryland Department of Agriculture for the use, storing and hauling of the residuals.
Caroline County's bill is the latest development in what has been months of packed public hearings and extended moratoriums on residual storage tanks. For county commissioners, the main hurdle has been cracking down on a few "bad actors" that store the residuals irresponsibly.
The bill garnered mixed reviews from Caroline County residents, environmental experts and representatives of the poultry industry at prior public hearings. Several took to the podium Aug. 6 to voice their opposition or support of the legislation.
Mike Woodward, the owner of a Ridgely farm right next to an open-top residual storage facility, voiced support for the bill.
"I am 400 yards from the tank itself... We have a lot of issues with flies. The odor is atrocious at times," Woodward said. "We had a vet come out. We were having trouble with our horses. Their eyes were watering and runny and nasty. We couldn't figure out what was going on with them. The vet checked them out and the flies were laying larvae inside their eyes."
Brad Sears, a Ridgely commissioner, said, "I come before you on behalf of the Town of Ridgely in support of the emergency legislative bill. I offer this testimony to advocate for the men, women and children, who live, work and attend school and play within the town limits. We have concern because of improper storage of FPR (food processing residuals) poses well documented threats to human life, health and wellbeing."
He said open-top containers do nothing to limit "odors, the exposure to vectors, the airborne bacteria and viruses."
Holly Porter, executive director of the Delmarva Chicken Association, has been a vocal opponent of the county's bill in prior public hearings. She spoke again in opposition of the legislation on Tuesday.
"I really and truly would like the commissioners to consider some way of grandfathering in the farmers who are utilizing and storing food processing residuals for years without the complaints we have had in the past," she said. "If we do not do that, we are impacting other farmers who are becoming collateral damage because of one unfortunately bad actor."
Responding to Holly Porter's comments, Larry Porter said, "Grandfathering in, unfortunately would have to include grandfathering in what Miss. Porter referred to as the 'bad actor.' ... you can't enforce laws on some people and not all people."

title: Local musician shares latest album, 'Impermanence'
author: ADRIAN COTTON Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Local musician shares latest album, 'Impermanence'

 September 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ADRIAN COTTON Special to the Star Democrat | Section: News 
 
 366
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — In mid-August, local singer/songwriter Ashton Mooday and her band, Gerry Werner, Jeremy Blouch and Connor Stoehr, held a concert at the Chestertown Volunteer Fire Company to celebrate the release of her newest album, "Impermanence."This is Mooday's fourth album, and many of her family and friends came out to support her achievement.
With gold and green lighting, balloons scattered throughout the room and refreshments, Mooday took listeners on a journey through the creative processes that made up her new musical creation.
The audience was captivated the entire night as Mooday and company treated the audience to a total of 24 songs which included all 15 tracks from the Impermanence album and nine bonus songs from some of her previous albums.
The album covers three stages of a relationship: the joy of being in love; the pain of breaking up; and the triumph of overcoming heartbreak.
Mooday and her band were a delight to watch because of their "realness." You could tell these people weren't just co-workers/bandmates but a family who enjoyed being around each other.
Two special guests joined Mooday's band, the audience told they traveled two and a half hours to be a part of the show — AJ "A-Juice" Mason who appeared on the song "My Person" and OfficialMacMan who appeared on the song, "Sike." Both could be seen bopping their heads, smiling with pride at their friend's performance.
When asked how she felt about the show, Mooday said, "The concert was phenomenal from my perspective. I couldn't have asked for a better band to back me up or a better crowd to share the experience with. I am lucky to have so much support with my family, friends and this community."
The audience felt lucky to hear her perform.
These past few months have kept her on her toes.
Currently, she runs her music school, Mooday's Music, LLC, located at 151 Dixon Drive Suite 4 in Chestertown.
She's also preparing for a mission's trip to Costa Rica with her fellow church members at Hope Fellowship.
Learn more about Mooday's Music LLC by visiting her website, moodaysmusicllc.org, and be sure to check out all of her work, which includes albums, singles and EPs that date all the way back to 2017 on Spotify.

title: TODAY IN HISTORY/May 38

content:
TODAY IN HISTORY/May 38

 May 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Columns 
 
 373
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On May 28, 1830, President Andrew Jackson signed the Indian Removal Act, which forced nearly 50,000 Native Americans to relocate to designated territories west of the Mississippi River.Also on this date:
In 1863, the 54th Massachusetts Volunteer Infantry Regiment, made up of free Black men, left Boston to fight for the Union in the Civil War.
In 1892, the Sierra Club was founded in San Francisco by naturalist John Muir.
In 1918, American troops fought their first major battle during World War I as they launched an offensive against the German-held French village of Cantigny; the Americans succeeded in capturing the village.
In 1959, the U.S. Army launched Able, a rhesus monkey, and Baker, a squirrel monkey, aboard a Jupiter missile for a suborbital flight which both primates survived.
In 1972, burglars working on behalf of the Nixon White House broke into the Democratic National Committee headquarters in the Watergate Hotel in Washington, D.C., installing surveillance devices on telephones and taking photos of DNC documents.
In 1977, 165 people were killed when fire raced through the Beverly Hills Supper Club in Southgate, Kentucky.
In 1987, to the embarrassment of Soviet officials, Mathias Rust, a teenage West German amateur pilot, landed a private plane near Moscow's Red Square without authorization. (Rust was held by the Soviets until he was pardoned and freed the following year.)
In 2013, calling it perhaps the biggest money-laundering scheme in U.S. history, federal prosecutors charged seven people with running what amounted to an online, underworld bank, saying that Liberty Reserve handled $6 billion for drug dealers, child pornographers, identity thieves and other criminals around the globe.
In 2021, officials announced that the remains of more than 200 children, some as young as 3 years old, had been found buried on the site of what was once Canada's largest indigenous residential school, in Kamloops, British Columbia.

title: 4,000 gallons of sewage overflows into Windmill Branch
author: Contributed
content:
4,000 gallons of sewage overflows into Windmill Branch

 October 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 233
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - A gravity sewer line along South Washington Street in Easton discharged 4,425 gallons of untreated wastewater into Windmill Branch, headwaters of the Tred Avon River, on Wednesday, Easton Utilities reported.The cause of the backup was due to the sewer line being clogged with a combination of grease, rags and "flushable" wipes. Easton Utilities immediately reported these overflows to state and local health authorities and promptly treated the areas affected with lime to disinfect the surfaces around the points of discharge.Easton Utilities strongly urges the public and food service establishments to be mindful of what they release to the sewer lines.Only human waste and toilet paper should be flushed - disinfecting and "flushable" wipes and other items should be properly disposed of in the trash, not the toilet.These wipes and other items do not break down in sewer or septic systems and can damage the internal plumbing in homes as well.In addition, everyone should keep fats oil, and grease out of drains to prevent blockages or backups."Easton Utilities remains committed to the safe, sanitary removal of wastewater while minimizing the impact to our environment," said Doug Abbott, Easton Utilities' engineering, water and wastewater department manager.No customers were impacted by this event. While the Talbot County Health Department has confirmed there is minimal impact on public health, regulation requires a press release be distributed to notify the general public.

title: The Wailers, Southside Johnny highlight upcoming shows at Avalon Theatre
author: Mike Sunnucks
content:
The Wailers, Southside Johnny highlight upcoming shows at Avalon Theatre

 May 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1410
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Avalon Theatre in downtown Easton has an upcoming slate of shows that includes reggae stalwarts The Wailers, New Jersey rockers Southside Johnny & The Asbury Jukes and other performances. The music and performing arts venue is located at 40 E. Dover Street in Easton. Here's a rundown of upcoming shows with performance descriptions from the Avalon.For ticket prices and more show and venue information at the Avalon and its Stoltz Listening Room online check out avalonfoundation.org.
The Met: Live in HD Madama Butterfly
Saturday, May 11th
Doors: 12:30pm / Show: 1:00pm
Avalon Theatre
Extraordinary soprano Asmik Grigorian tackles the demanding role of Cio-Cio-San, the loyal geisha at the heart of Puccini's devastating tragedy. Tenor Jonathan Tetelman stars as the callous American naval officer Pinkerton, whose betrayal destroys her. Mezzo-soprano Elizabeth DeShong reprises the role of the steadfast maid Suzuki, and baritone Lucas Meachem is the American consul Sharpless. Acclaimed maestro Xian Zhang takes the podium on May 11 to conduct Anthony Minghella's vivid production. This live cinema transmission is part of the Met's award-winning Live in HD series, bringing opera to movie theaters across the globe.
Dar Williams with Guest Heather Maloney
Saturday, May 11
Doors: 7:30 a.m.; Show: 8 p.m.
Avalon Theatre
Dar Williams' lyrics contain bouquets of optimism, delivered on melodies alternating between beguiling lightness and understated gravity.
Always in the right place at the right time for the success she's had over a 25+year career, Dar rose out of the vibrant mid-90's Boston scene, inspired by the eclectic influences of alt-rockers, Berklee jazz musicians, slam poets, and folk artists like Patty Griffith, Melissa Ferrick, the Throwing Muses, Vance Gilbert, and Jonatha Brooke.
Through all the ups and downs, however, it's always been about staying true to herself. "Good and bad things happen, and it's not necessarily a reward or indictment. I've just got to meet it," she observes. "Like, I'm bringing my whole life to this moment; it will surprise me, challenge me, show me where I was wrong, even make a fool out of me, but my job is to show up and not take adversity personally. Real happiness doesn't have to feel like Snoopy dancing with Woodstock; it can just be knowing you have the resilience to meet whatever comes to you. I will call that a good life."
Dar will be joined by special guest Heather Maloney, a Massachusetts-based singer songwriter whose voice is her "not-so-secret weapon" (Boston Globe) and whose "lyrics cut to the chase" (Huffington Post).
Minor Gold
Wednesday, May 15
Doors: 6:30 p.m.; Doors: 7 p.m.
Stoltz Listening Room
Minor Gold are ARIA-nominated artists Tracy McNeil and Dan Parsons. Canadian and Australian, respectively, this Trans-Pacific duo echo '70s cosmic Americana with an easy charm and potent honesty.
The strength of the songwriting and the indeterminate perfection of how these two artists' voices lock in together hit right where the emotions live inside us. With dynamics ranging from the intense restraint of campfire intimacy through to open-throttle abandon, Minor Gold delight and enthrall as they weave masterful harmonies and deft guitar playing around unforgettable, stripped-back performances.
Since releasing their critically acclaimed self-titled debut album in August 2023, the duo have been on the road—recently returning from a 30-date North American album tour with supports for The Teskey Brothers and an official showcase at AmericanaFEST in Nashville, as well as the 2024 Folk Alliance International in Kansas City. https://www.minorgoldmusic.com/
Julian Brezon
Friday, May 17, 2024
Doors: 6:30 p.m.; Show: 7 p.m.
Stoltz Listening Room
New York-based Easton native Julian Brezon returns to the Stoltz with a stellar quartet presenting jazz standards and original compositions. As a saxophonist, composer, and educator, Julian brings a fresh ear to the world of modern creative music. His compositions strike a delicate balance of harmonic adventurousness and familiar listenability while his takes on standards blend a love of tradition with an ear for experimentation.
Julian recently earned his Master of Music degree in jazz performance at the City College of New York in Harlem. He has studied with jazz greats Gary Thomas, Steve Wilson, Jason Rigby, and Vincent Herring. https://www.julianbrezon.com/
Boy Band Review
Saturday, May 25
Doors: 6:30 p.m.; Show: 7 p.m.
Avalon Theatre, 40 E. Dover Street, Easton, MD
Boy Band Review is THE best boy band tribute show in the country! They have played numerous high-profile events, private engagements, a Las Vegas residency at Planet Hollywood Casino, performed with Chris Kirkpatrick of NSYNC joining the band for multiple shows, and selling out countless venues across the country to capacity crowds.
Having captured the hearts of fans with their #boyband shows that transport audience members back in time to the days of frosted tips and hunky front-men professing their undying love. The #boyband shows are an incredible throwback experience reliving your best years with a full band, choreography, and harmonies.
They are playing to capacity crowds nationwide…so don't let this opportunity to see them perform in the Avalon go "bye bye bye"!
https://boybandreview.com/
Carpool — Cars Tribute Band
Saturday, June 1
Doors: 7:30 p.m.; Show: 8 p.m.
Avalon Theatre
Carpool is a tribute band that recreates the sound, feel, look and vibe that made the Cars world famous. The band is comprised of five of the best and hardest working full-time musicians in the Atlanta area. Their performances meticulously capture the sleek, synth-heavy, steady-beat and driving-guitar sound that made the one-and-only Cars so awesome.
A Carpool show helps you "shake it up it" and takes you right back to when the Cars were (and continue to be) the soundtrack of our lives, reminding us all of why the Cars hold a very special place in our hearts and minds. https://carpooltributeband.com/
Mutlu
Thursday, June 6
Doors: 7:30 p.m.; Show: 8 p.m.
Stoltz Listening Room
A Philadelphia musician who proudly carries a torch for the city's soul legacy, Mutlu (pronounced moot'-lu) makes a connection with every audience. Coming up in the Philly scene, he played around town and in area clubs before landing his first tour opening for Joe Jackson. Since then he's toured across the U.S. and Europe with his musical brother, Amos Lee, who discovered Mutlu's music just as both of their careers were taking off.
In addition, he's found an advocate with Daryl Hall & John Oates, who invited Mutlu to support a national theater tour. http://www.mutlusounds.com
Southside Johnny & The Asbury Jukes
Friday, June 7, 2024
Doors: 7:30 p.m
Avalon Theatre, 40 E. Dover Street, Easton, MD
Southside Johnny and the Asbury Jukes emerged from the New Jersey shore scene in 1974, and though they carried over a significant influence (and some key personnel) from Bruce Springsteen & the E Street Band, the Jukes evolved as more of an R&B horn band in the Memphis Stax Records tradition.
Organized by singer John Lyon, guitarist/songwriter Steve Van Zandt (who decamped for the E Street Band in 1975, but continued to produce, manage, and write songs for the Jukes) and Richie Rosenberg, the band is well known for high-energy shows and no-holds-barred songs, including "I Don't Wanna Go Home," "Havin' a Party," "The Fever," "Talk to Me," "Trapped Again," and "This Time It's For Real."
Still tinged with the exuberant rhythm and blues feel that is the Jukes' trademark, and loaded with the driving sound of the legendary Jukes horn section, Southside Johnny and the Asbury Jukes continue to expound their signature Jersey Shore sound – all for the sheer joy of it. https://www.southsidejohnny.com/
The Brothers Comatose
Thursday, June 20

title: Make your groceries last longer
content:
Make your groceries last longer

 September 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 12 | Section: News

 A recent column on the proper storage for fresh fruits and vegetables generated a lot of great reader feedback - plus dozens of new tips and tricks to make all grocery items last longer. I love this stuff so much, I must admit to being slightly compulsive - gathering, testing and assessing techniques. Here are a few of my new favorites: BERRIESAre you familiar with that sick feeling that comes when you notice that the berries you bought yesterday are already showing signs of mold and turning brown? Here's the remedy: As soon as you bring them into the kitchen, prepare a mixture of one part vinegar (white or apple cider) and 10 parts water. Give the berries a bath in the mixture.Swirl them around a bit and then gently drain, rinse and place in the refrigerator.Don't worry. The solution is so weak, you will not taste the vinegar. This treatment should give your strawberries an additional two weeks of useful life and raspberries a week or more. Vinegar retards the growth of bacteria that causes berries to spoil so quickly.POTATOESTo keep potatoes from growing big ugly sprouts before you have time to use them up, store them with a couple of apples. For some reason, that really works to halt the sprouting.ALUMINUM FOILLet me just say that I'm a believer! It drives me crazy that I do not know why this works, but it certainly does: Wrap celery, broccoli and lettuce in a single layer of aluminum foil before storing in the refrigerator. Celery will stay crisp and fresh for up to a month stored this way. It's simply amazing.MUSHROOMSStore mushrooms in a paper bag. Now the air can circulate and the mushrooms will remain dry and lovely for weeks.Mary Hunt is the founder of EverydayCheapskate.com, a frugal living blog, and the author of the book "Debt-Proof Living."

title: Gluten-Free Bakery Girl rises to the challenge
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Gluten-Free Bakery Girl rises to the challenge

 March 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Business 
 
 628
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — It began as a challenge for an already established cook.Tricia King, owner of Gluten-Free Bakery Girl, said that during her time as a personal chef, she had a client with rheumatoid arthritis who needed to avoid gluten in her diet. King undertook the task of creating tasty gluten-free recipes.
Now, about 20 years later, she is the owner of Gluten-Free Bakery Girl, an entirely gluten-free bakery on the Eastern Shore.
King centers the health and well-being of her customers in everything she does, and that includes making sure all her baked goods are not only safe but also a delight to eat.
The passion for tasty food has been a long love of King's. She has been cooking almost all her life, and even when she wasn't cooking, she was studying and watching other cooks like Julia Child and her mother. She said that cooking just came naturally to her.
"When you have a passion for it, it's easy to do it," King said. "I've loved food my whole life."
After studying interior design, she decided to open a personal chef business in Salt Lake City, Utah, called Purple Pomegranate. For two years, she traveled from house to house every day, doing the shopping and cooking for two weeks and then repeating the same cycle with different clients.
Then, she had the opportunity to be a sous chef in a hotel in Scotland.
It was there that she dove into baking. When she came back to the States, she trained under pastry chef Matt Ratliff in the Perry Cabin.
The work was intense, King said. Daily, the kitchen would produce 40 souffles, bake bread and cookies, and make wedding cakes.
In the back of her mind, she still yearned to open her dream bakery. So, she began using the back kitchen to try different gluten-free desserts.
Before she made the leap to establish her bakery, she shared her dream with one of her friends, and he said, "Oh, it's never going to work. A gluten-free bakery?" She smiles, recollecting the memory and how he has since taken back his words.
Gluten-Free Bakery Girl has been in business in St. Michaels for 12 years and will be opening in a bigger location in Easton. Its products can be found throughout Maryland, Delaware, D.C., Massachusetts, New York and other states nationwide.
King said the vast majority of her customers have celiac disease, an immune reaction to eating gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley and rye. Due to this, it is of the utmost importance that there is no cross-contamination in her kitchen.
She operates in a 100% certified gluten-free facility and kitchen.
All products are individually wrapped to prevent any potential cross-contamination from other foods during shipping and sale, and all employees are only allowed to bring gluten-free food to work.
"People don't understand that you can't just bake in a kitchen and then wipe it down and then bake gluten-free," King said. "Twenty parts per million, which is a crumb of bread, is enough to make someone who has celiac disease sick."
More than anything, King wants to help people with celiac disease lead a more accessible and safer day-to-day life. King said her customers with celiac disease often feel that they need to miss out on treats for their health, but having the opportunity to provide people the chance to indulge in a baked good makes all the effort she puts in her bakery worth it.
King urges young girls thinking of starting a bakery or any business to have faith in themselves and allow themselves to grow outside their comfort zones.
"We women are the hardest on ourselves," King said. "We beat ourselves up the most. It puts blocks in front of us, but we have to know we can make it through. So, keep going. You have to keep going."

title: More information on Dorchester charter amendments
author: STEPHEN RIDEOUT
content:
More information on Dorchester charter amendments

 October 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEPHEN RIDEOUT | Section: Columns 
 
 618
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last time I wrote about the first three proposed Charter Amendments that are on the ballot in Dorchester County this November. Two of the next three are similar and one has more background information required to help you understand the reason for it.Question D seeks to clarify certain of the responsibilities of the county manager including the day-to-day operation of county government and establishing procedures for certain vacancies. This requires some explanation.
When the Dorchester Citizens for Better Government began to look at the day-to-day management of county government, we found a couple of things. Every employee was an "at will" employee, and anyone could be terminated upon a vote of three members of the council for whatever reasons they might have, no matter how long the person had worked for the county.
We also found that at times some of the council members were telling the staff what to do and how to do it. The county manager position went for months without any effort by the council to find a replacement.
The Charter Commission did significant work on this proposed amendment to help ensure that there was a more timely transition when a county manager left or was terminated, allowed for the appointment of an assistant county manager subject to funding, allowed for studies to be done when appropriate, established a time limitation for searches for a replacement of the county manager, and most importantly established that the county manager is responsible for the day-to-day operations of county government and that the council is to deal with the administrative and departmental services through the county manager and not through direct orders to staff members.
Adding the above language to the existing language that "all departments, agencies, and offices of the Government shall be subject to the direction, supervision, and control of the County Manager under the authority of the Council…" ensures that the employees work with and under the authority of the county manager and that he or she is subject to the direction and authority of the County Council.
Of all of the proposed amendments, the passage of this one will help to ensure a more efficient and effective working environment that will benefit the entire county and its residents.
With Question E, the proposed change removes the requirement that the director of finance be a resident of Dorchester County. As this is a particularly important job in county government and finding the best person can be a challenge and restricting the council in where the finance director can live simply limits their ability to find the most qualified person. What is true about where the county manager lives is also true for the finance director.
The current County Council has informally addressed the final Question F. When the Dorchester Citizens for Better Government saw what challenges people faced with attending the council meetings in person, we urged that the meetings go on the internet so that people could watch government at work and be able to communicate about the meetings without having to be there in person. The prior council rejected these requests at first and finally agreed to them. Having the meetings on Town Hall Streams benefited everyone.
The language of this Charter Amendment simply puts it in the law that the current and all future councils shall ensure the transparency of the county government by having the ability of the public to attend meetings in person or virtually and have a clear understanding of their right to access to public records.
The vote in November for all of these questions should all be "yes" so that the running of county government is more transparent and more efficient and effective for the benefit of all of the citizens of Dorchester County.

title: Rardin scores five goals in return as top-seeded Sabres grind way past Falcons for spot in MIAA B Conference championship
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Rardin scores five goals in return as top-seeded Sabres grind way past Falcons for spot in MIAA B Conference championship

 May 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 881
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — It was the No. 1 seed.It had won 11 of its last 12 games, and had already twice beaten its opponent.
But none of that matter to Saints Peter and Paul High boys head lacrosse coach Todd Wolters after the first half of Tuesday's Maryland Interscholastic Athletic Association B Conference semifinal.
After mustering just one first-quarter goal and carrying a four-goal cushion into halftime, Wolters made clear to his team he wasn't happy.
"Coach pulled us over at halftime and told us that this could be the end of our season," sophomore face-off man Grant Messick said. "'We could be done here.' But none of us want that. I think he kind of brought that out of us, just saying we could be going to Navy this Friday to win a championship that hasn't been done in a decade."
The Sabres responded, outscoring No. 4 Gerstell Academy by three goals in a decisive third quarter, catapulting them to a 13-8 victory on a dreary Tuesday afternoon.
Sts. Peter & Paul (15-4) advances to Friday's MIAA B Conference championship game where it will meet second-seed and two-time defending champion Archbishop Curley (11-7) at Navy-Marine Corps Memorial Stadium at 5 p.m. The Sabres defeated Curley twice during the regular season.
"They were taking a team lightly, like they've already won," said Wolters, whose team won 7-6 at Gerstell on April 12, then routed the Falcons 16-3 on their home turf April 30. "And they've done that before. We just lose focus."
In his first game back from injury, JJ Rardin (five goals) gave the Sabres a 1-0 lead with 2:22 left in the first quarter, when he scored off an assist from Andrew Steinhardt.
Gerstell (6-10) tied the score on Bronson Peters' goal less than 2 minutes into the second quarter. Rardin gained possession out in front of the net and fired his second goal just under the crossbar to make it 2-1 just 18 seconds later. But the Falcons came right back with Ryan Ellis beating Sabres goalie Hank Wolters (11 saves) to make it 2-all.
Davis Kimminau whipped a shot in from the right side, and less than two minutes later, set up Vincent Dyer's goal to nudge Sts. Peter & Paul to a 4-2 lead. But Peters (four goals) scored at the midway point of the second quarter to make it a one-goal game again.
"They came out and they didn't want their season to end," Messick said of Gerstell. "They came out with nothing to lose. We're the one seed. They come out and they beat us, then it's a huge upset. And if they don't it's not what they were expected to do. So I think they had that mentality while we came out thinking, 'Well, we smoked them before. We're going to roll them this time.' But they didn't. They came out and they fought really hard."
The Sabres scored the last three goals of the half, as Liam Durnbaugh, Noah Zimmerman and Rardin each tallied to make it 7-3 at the break.
"Our guys were in it," Gerstell head coach Ryan Drenner said. "We stayed in the fight the entire game. That was the biggest difference. We were here a couple weeks ago April 30. Very lopsided. We try to learn a lesson from every game regardless of the outcome of the game. And so for that one it was we had to come up with a better plan of how to travel down here and be ready to go from the jump. So we changed how we warm up just to be a little bit more alert from the start. I thought our guys did that today and we played four quarters of a great lacrosse game."
Gerstell cut its deficit to 7-4 just 19 seconds into the third quarter on a goal by Peters. Zimmerman scored for the Sabres, but Matthew Schols answered for the Falcons.
Sts. Peter & Paul took control the remainder of the quarter, getting one goal each from Steinhardt (four assists) and Kimminau, and two more from Rardin for a 12-5 lead heading into the fourth quarter.
"We know how good we are," Wolters said. "The third quarter we go and we really just started opening it up. And then in the fourth quarter we thought it was done."
The Sabres extended their lead to 13-5 before Gerstell scored the game's final three goals.
"We weren't hustling," Wolters said of certain stretches. "We'd come down and throw it away and then they would go down and score on unsettled situations. They had eight goals and I know five to six were unsettled and we can't have that.
"It's a win. We'll take it," Wolters said. "You can't win a championship unless you're in the championship. And we're in the championship."

title: War in the Holy Land - More Dems pressure Biden to publicly freeze $6B in Iranian assets; potential wider conflict confront Israel, Gaza

War in the Holy Land - More Dems pressure Biden to publicly freeze $6B in Iranian assets; potential wider conflict confront Israel, Gaza

 More U.S. senators, including Democrats, are joining the push to get the Biden administration to refreeze $6 billion in Iranian assets released as part of a September prisoner swamp after Hamas' attacks, including killing civilians, inside Israel.The effort comes as urban warfare in Gaza and worries of a wider conflict in the Middle East confront Israel as it strikes back at Hamas in the Palestinian territory.On the Iranian asset front, the Biden administration continues to be pushed to refreeze the $6 billion in Iranian assets after the Hamas killings, which included women and children. Tehran is a prime backer of Hamas, Hezbollah and other anti-Israel militants.Last week, Democratic U.S. Sens. Jon Tester on Montana and Joe Manchin of West Virginia joined the chorus of Republicans pressing Biden to refreeze the Iranian money after the bloodshed.U.S. Sens. Steve Daines of Montana, Marsha Blackburn of Tennessee and Marco Rubio of Florida are part of that GOP push.On Friday, Tester and Manchin were joined by 12 other senators (5 Republicans, 6 Democrats and one independent) in a letter to U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken in asking the White House to publicly freeze the Iranian money."We write to you in light of Hamas' violent and horrific terrorist attacks on Israel on October 7 which killed over a thousand innocent civilians, including American citizens. Given Iran's history of supporting acts of terrorism through Hamas, the United States must do everything in its power in the wake of this brutal attack to ensure that Iran is not in a position to continue funding Hamas' terrorist activities in Israel and throughout the Middle East," the senators wrote."While we understand that there are reports of an agreement with Qatar to freeze $6 billion in Iranian assets, we urge you to make this decision official U.S. policy and continue your efforts to limit Iran's ability to provide support to Hamas." Senators that are part of the push include Republicans Dan Sullivan of Alaska, Todd Young of Indiana and Joni Ernst of Iowa, Democrats Sherrod Brown of Ohio as well as Jacky Rosen and Catherine Cortez Masto (both of Nevada) and Independent Kyrsten Sinema of Arizona.A quiet deal?The Biden administration has stopped short of confirming reports that the U.S. and Qatar have reached a quiet deal to sequester the Iranian money. Blinken and White House national security spokesman John Kirby have resisted confirming the Qatar reports or publicly committing to refreezing the assets.Instead, they have stressed that Iran has not touched any of the $6 billion and that money is overseen by the U.S. and is supposed to only be used for humanitarian aid inside Iran.U.S. Sen. Tom Cotton, R-Arkansas, said the quiet deal relate to the Iranian money could be temporary and he wants Congress to move to make the refreezing permanent.Daines backs that effort."We have witnessed horrific attacks on the Israeli people by the Iranian-backed terrorist group Hamas. The United States needs to lead by example and sanction this dangerous regime," Daines said.Kirby stressed Friday other U.S. sanctions related to Iran and its help for militant and terrorist groups.Israel at war The White House national security spokesman also said there were no plans to put U.S combat troops in Israel as the Israel Defense Forces prepare for an expected invasion of Gaza where Hamas is based and more than 2.1 million people live in area roughly the same size as Philadelphia and Detroit.There have been more than 1,200 Israelis killed in the Hamas terror attacks.Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu posted pictures on Twitter/X showing "babies murdered and burned" in the Saturday, Oct. 7 carnage.The Palestinian Health Authority reports more than 1,500 deaths in Gaza with continued IDF shelling and missile strikes since the Hamas attacks.Israel has also told residents of Gaza to evacuate to certain years with a ground invasion expected. The IDF made some incursions into Gaza Friday.The U.S. has moved an aircraft carrier group into the Mediterranean Sea as well as more fighter jets into the region as deterrence for Iran and other anti-Israeli actors involving themselves in the Hamas fight.U.S. Secretary of State Lloyd Austin visited Israel Friday after Blinken's stop there Thursday in shows of support for Israel after the Hamas killings."We're rapidly moving to provide IDF (with) resources to include ammunition and interceptors to resupply (the) Iron Dome.These critical assets will help ensure Israel has what it needs to defend its cities and citizens," Austin said in a social media post.Netanyahu and Israeli officials say they are ready to go neighborhood-by-neighborhood to root out and crush Hamas."We will obliterate Hamas, we will triumph. It might take time, but we will end this war stronger than ever. 'May the Almighty cause the enemies who rise up against us to be struck down before them,'" Netanyahu said Friday.The fate of Gaza An Israeli ground offensive will create urban warfare fighting potentially a kin to fights in Iraq, Somalia and Chechnya with plenty of peril of the Gaza's 2.1 million civilian population.The United Nations Relief and Works Agency said Israel's siege of Gaza has cut off food, water and power to Gaza with potential catastrophic consequences."It has become a matter of life and death. It is a must; fuel needs to be delivered now into Gaza to make water available for 2 million people," said Philippe Lazzarini, UNRWA Commissioner-General.No humanitarian supplies have been allowed into Gaza for a week now, the UN group said.The UN group said with power cut off Palestinians have been forced to use water from wells, increasing the risk of waterborne diseases."We need to truck fuel into Gaza now. Fuel is the only way for people to have safe drinking water. If not, people will start dying of severe dehydration, among them young children, the elderly and women. Water is now the last remaining lifeline.I appeal for the siege on humanitarian assistance to be lifted now," said Lazzarini.On the left, some progressives and critics of Israel are worried about civilian deaths in Gaza where 47% of the population are children."I am calling for immediate de-escalation and ceasefire to save countless civilian lives, no matter their faith or ethnicity. Our government must lead with compassion for all civilians. I believe in my heart that the majority of Americans want the killing and violence to stop. War crimes cannot be answered with war crimes," said U.S. Rep. Rashida Tlaib, D-Michigan."Millions of people in Gaza-half of them children-have been given an impossible 24 hour evacuation order, but they have nowhere to go. They have been cut off from electricity, food, and water for days.Hospitals are running out of electricity to keep babies and the injured alive. The collective punishment of Palestinian civilians is a war crime, the confirmed use of white phosphorus bombs in Gaza is a war crime, yet there are no statements demanding these violations stop from the American political establishment." Pope Francis has called for a new mindset in the Middle East and holy land for Christians, Jews and Muslims."Terrorism and extremism do not help to reach a solution to the conflict between Israelis and Palestinians, but fuel hatred, violence, revenge, and only cause each to other suffer. The Middle East need a peace built on dialogue and the courage of fraternity," the Roman Catholic leader said.Thats a difficult sell with Israel's mourning the loss of life, including children, at the hands of Hamas and Palestinian militants hoping for a wider, regional conflict.U.S. support for Israel President Joe Biden has voiced steadfast support for Israel in the Gaza war but has also stressed the need to abide by the "laws of war." Many Republicans have said they back Israel's offensive in Gaza."Israel has every right to use every force need to repel what just happened to them," said U.S. Rep. Chip Roy, R-Texas.U.S. Rep. Andy Harris, a Republican representing the Eastern Shore, endorsed Roy's statement on social media and GOP presidential candidates such as former U.S. UN Ambassador and South Carolina Gov. Nikki Haley and Florida Gov.Ron DeSantis also support the IDF's and Netanyahu's promises to crush and obliterate Hamas."Hamas showed no restraint when it slaughtered innocent Israelis. Hamas is evil and must be eradicated.We must stand with Israel-not just when it is hit, but also when it hits back," Haley said.

author: CARL HAMILTON cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Former Cecil County deputy gets one year in misconduct case

 January 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: CARL HAMILTON cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 1088
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CECIL COUNTY — A former Cecil County Sheriff's Office deputy who took and sent sexually explicit photos and videos of himself and two women, including one picture that he took of his genitals — while on duty, in uniform and inside agency headquarters — received a one-year jail term on Wednesday, according to the Maryland Office of the State Prosecutor.Visiting Retired Kent County Circuit Court Judge Paul M. Bowman imposed a five-year sentence on the defendant — Elkton resident Kyle Logan Thomas, 28 — for misconduct in office and then suspended four years of the penalty, prosecutors said. Bowman also imposed a suspended one-year sentence on Thomas for visual surveillance with prurient intent, prosecutors added.
In addition, the judge ordered Thomas to serve three years of supervised probation after completing his one-year jail term, prosecutors reported.
"The defendant's conduct is best described as depraved, sadistic, and vicious," Bowman reportedly remarked from the bench while sentencing Thomas.
The sentence imposed by Bowman matched a recommendation made by Assistant State Prosecutor Abigail E. Ticse, who handled the criminal case with Deputy State Prosecutor Sarah R. David.
After Wednesday's sentencing, Maryland State Prosecutor Charlton T. Howard III said, "I am proud of our office's efforts to build a strong case against a law enforcement officer who was sworn to protect and serve, not to abuse and traumatize, the residents of Cecil County. We appreciate the Court's sentence and believe that it demonstrates to the residents of Cecil County and the entire State of Maryland that real consequences await people who commit crimes such as these, especially by those that hold positions of public trust."
Thomas had pleaded guilty to those two charges in October, as part of a plea deal in which prosecutors agreed to dismiss nine related charges against him, according to court records and Cecil Whig archives.
In August, two months earlier, Thomas was charged with misconduct in office, witness retaliation, visual surveillance with prurient intent, revenge porn, and distribution of obscene material. Thomas was not arrested, but rather was served charging papers.
Thomas had worked as a sworn Cecil County deputy for approximately two and a half years — from February 2021 until July 18, 2023 when the agency "separated Deputy Kyle Thomas from employment" amid an internal investigation into the allegations made against him, according to Capt. Michael Holmes, a CCSO spokesman. Thomas had been on suspension, per protocol, during his last nine months with the sheriff's office after the agency received a citizen complaint on Oct. 28, 2022 regarding his purported off-duty and on-duty misconduct, he noted.
As part of an overview in the charging document, prosecutors explained, "Thomas, who was married, frequently utilized Snapchat to communicate and exchange photos and videos with other users because the communications or other exchanges typically disappear."
Thomas had a romantic relationship with a woman, who ended that relationship in August 2021, prosecutors reported.
"Throughout their relationship, Thomas shared photographs and videos with Victim I, primarily via Snapchat, depicting Thomas engaged in sexual acts," according to prosecutors.
At approximately 12:20 p.m. on June 16, 2021 — while on duty amid a shift that went from 7:45 a.m. to 7 p.m. that day — Thomas shared a video with VICTIM I using the "My Eyes Only" album on Snapchat and the image "depicted Thomas in his CCSO uniform, in the CCSO building, holding, touching his exposed penis," prosecutors reported.
The woman attempted to end her relationship with Thomas several times and, in response, according to court records, Thomas "made verbal threats" to her.
In August 2021, VICTIM I attempted to cease all contact with Thomas, prosecutors reported. After an interaction between VICTIM 1 and Thomas in October 2022, VICTIM I and others made complaints about Thomas to the CCSO, which spurred the internal investigation that resulted in agency officials suspending Thomas, according to prosecutors.
In late October 2022, Thomas learned that CCSO was investigating him and that VICTIM I had been interviewed by agency investigators and that "a copy of the video that he shared with VICTIM I on Snapchat had been provided to the CCSO," according to prosecutors.
In response, Thomas contacted VICTIM I several times at her place of employment — a doctor's office — on two days in November 2022 and requested to make a complaint against her, prompting her to obtain a final peace order against him, prosecutors said.
Prosecutors reported that Thomas went to a Cecil County District Court commissioner and requested that VICTIM 1 be charged with sharing the "video of Thomas in his uniform exposing his penis to her husband and Thomas' employer, the CCSO." VICTIM I had provided that video to CCSO in October 2022 while making her formal complaint against Thomas.
The Cecil County State's Attorney's Office, however, dismissed the charges that Thomas had filed against VICTIM I, prosecutors reported. The MOSP criminal information filed against Thomas accused Thomas of taking retaliatory action against VICTIM I.
Prosecutors reported that Thomas became "engaged in a sexual relationship" with a second woman in 2019 and that she ended their relationship in May, some four years later.
They further reported that, throughout their relationship, Thomas took videos and photos of himself and the woman engaged in sexual acts and that he took those images without her consent.
The woman tried to end their relationship several times and, in response, Thomas sent videos of himself and the woman engaged in sexual acts to her, prosecutors said. Thomas also threatened to send videos of the woman engaged in sexual acts to other individuals or post the videos online, prosecutors added.
In July 2022, VICTIM 2 told Thomas to delete the photos and videos that he had on his phone, according to prosecutors. But Thomas told VICTIM 2 that he couldn't because he was anxious to post them on social media someday "maybe when you get pregnant or married," prosecutors reported.
From April 2022 through January, Thomas sent dozens of videos of himself and VICTIM 2 engaged in sexual acts to other Snapchat users without VICTIM 2's consent or knowledge, according to prosecutors. Thomas asked random Snapchat users to watch the videos, prosecutors said. Thomas also paid several Snapchat users to watch the videos," prosecutors added.
When the Cecil County Sheriff's Office suspended Thomas on Oct. 28, 2022, agency officials served him a non-contact order forbidding Thomas from interacting with several specified people involved in the administrative investigation, including the second woman, prosecutors reported. Thomas refused to sign the non-contact order, according to prosecutors.
Thomas contacted the second woman "in person, through text messages and on social media applications, including Snapchat" from Nov. 12, 2022 through May 4, 2023, prosecutors reported.

title: U.S. labor secretary visits Cambridge oyster hatchery on workforce tour
author: Lily Tierney
content:
U.S. labor secretary visits Cambridge oyster hatchery on workforce tour

 September 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 663
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — U.S. Secretary of Labor Lori Chavez-DeRemer came to Cambridge to tour Horn Point Oyster Hatchery as her Maryland stop on the Secretary's "American at Work" listening tour. She chose the hatchery to preview one of Maryland's "most important" industries.Maryland was Chaves-DeRemer's 36th stop on her U.S. tour that focuses on workforce investments.
For Manager of the UMCES Horn Point Laboratory Stephanie Alexander, the goals of the visit were to foster dialogue.
"She (the secretary) was very engaged in the tour. She grasped what we were doing, and I think she really understood that we were kind of here for the trifecta of the oyster, the commercial fishery, the private aquaculture sector, as well as the restoration sector," Alexander said.
Chavez-DeRemer chose the Horn Point Oyster Hatchery in Cambridge because aquaculture is "an important industry here in the state of Maryland." She said the tour made her think not only of the science that goes into the oysters but the future of the industry.
"I asked a question in there: had they thought about 3D printing oyster shells? Now, why would I ask that question? I was in Japan for the World Fair just a few months ago, and they were 3D printing coral and reintroducing that back into the ocean and would reintegrate and grow new coral. So it's those kinds of questions that I think about. How can we best fortify the industry?" Chaves-DeRemer said following the tour.
She said her goal is to complete the remaining 14 states by the first week of December in hopes to provide timely, actionable feedback to President Donald Trump within the first year of both of their terms.
Chavez-DeRemer said feedback from the tour will shape workforce programs and federal grant decisions. She said the Labor Department's focus on jobs and training reflects the administration's priorities of accountability, innovation and community strength.
Chaves-DeRemer emphasized the "Make America Skilled Again" grants, which are intended to flow to state and local partners and fund targeted workforce needs, including apprenticeships. The hatchery had one apprentice last cycle and aims for two more next year.
Alexander said she personally funded the apprenticeship in the previous year and that it was nice to hear of other potential funding opportunities.
"My ideal apprentice would be somebody who has ties to the oyster industry, who is looking to do things different than what has historically been done. I think that would be amazing to foster connections, not only between the industry and our community, but the environment," Alexander said.
When asked about how to stimulate the workforce amid federal budget cuts, Chaves-DeRemer said the department is focused on preventing waste, fraud and abuse, aligning with Trump's budget with economic goals, which were central to his campaign and the early months of his current term.
She said this is done through inter-agency collaboration via memorandum of understandings.
The federal administration says it is cutting waste by modernizing operations such as using technology like AI, streamlining compliance programs, and upgrading systems to prevent fraud and inefficiency.
"Two out of every three new jobs is created by a small business owner," Chaves-DeRemer said. "So right here in Maryland, this industry is important. It's important to the ancillary jobs that it will affect. So the more we grow this economy, the better off and more prosperity we'll have."
Alexander hopes there will be future collaboration with the Department of Labor to build a highly skilled workforce in Maryland, especially in Cambridge.
Chaves-DeRemer said she is committed to personally conveying state-level insights to the president and coordinating across agency leadership for implementation.
"You really cannot understand what's happening on the ground and how it affects the local economy, the everyday average worker in America, unless you can talk to them," she said. "So I wouldn't know about this laboratory unless I'm here on site to hear these reports, to understand the lovely woman who gave me the tour. She started off as an intern and 29 years later, here she is, talking about why the oyster industry is so important."

title: Wheatlands development agreement shapes up
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Wheatlands development agreement shapes up

 March 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 322
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEENSTOWN — The Wheatlands project adjacent to Route 50 is growing closer to fruition as the Queenstown Town Commissioners discussed developer rights and responsibilities for the proposed mixed use residential and commercial community development Feb. 28.A concept plan proposes 79 townhouse lots, 20 cottage court units and 77 single-family home lots for developers Waterman Family Limited Partnership to build Wheatlands on a 148-acre tract of land, directly across from the Queenstown Premium Outlets.
Queenstown Town Manager Amy Moore presented a development rights and responsibilities agreement draft for review including outlines of impact fees and donations to the local fire departments.
The town is currently working with the developer on infrastructure needs and the development's contributions are detailed in the agreement, according to Moore.
As part of the agreement, the developer will also give two one-acre storage land parcels for town use.
Wheatlands has been in the pipeline since 1992, when the Waterman Family Limited Partnership bought the land.
The land was annexed into Queenstown in 2014, which had the backing of the Queen Anne's County Commissioners at the time. But new members won election to the county seat later that year, and they reversed approval of the development.
Waterman and Queenstown fought the reversal but ultimately lost in court, with the Maryland Court of Appeals enforcing a five-year stay on the zoning of the property.
When those five years were up in November 2019, the development proposal moved forward introducing concept plans and architectural guidelines in 2020.
The master concept plan approved by Queenstown in 2021, showed no strong opposition to it from local residents.
Public hearings were held after planning commission members found the master concept plan consistent with the town comprehensive plan.
During those hearings in 2021, Barry Waterman, the proprietor of Waterman Family Limited Partnership, the property owners, told the commissioners, homes will vary in size but will resemble the historic architecture of Queenstown.
More discussion and potential agreement approval is expected at the commissioner's next meeting March 12.
